Textual Messages: Oh, Another year, another set of phones from manufacturers! I have been hooked onto get the latest phone every year syndrome and love reviewing specifics. Disclaimer, I love Android and have been using from very early days. I will not call Samsung Galaxy S5 as revolutionary, but it is certainly evolutionary. If you have an older phone more than 2 years old, absolutely get this. I love Samsung Galaxy S5 from its competitors for few reasons - removable battery, microSD card support and the maturity of the product. I have been using a S5 for past couple of days and have ordered a unlocked one from my local store. There are so many variants already in the market. So do check local specs. For example, in china market dual SIM S5 is available. Galaxy S5's back plate has a perforated dot pattern and a excellent matte finish. As a result, the phone looks far more sophisticated than its past designs despite its plastic build. Its surface feels nice to the touch without being too rough or too slippery. I really do _not_ care about the plastic, in fact the lightweight nature is what I care. Some people make a huge deal out of it. A high quality plastic is good for lightweight and I go with lightweight than a heavy phone in the pocket. A reputed tech site called recently Samsung as the “undisputed king of the Android smartphone space”. True indeed. With the plethora of devices in tablets/phones, they have iterated so much that they can produce truly stunning products. If you care for weight, the Galaxy S4 is lighter than S5. (please see my stats below). In fact pixel density is slightly higher in S4 due to a 0.1in size difference. So get an S4, it is cheaper and still same phone that came out last year. If you care for heart rate monitor, fingerprint scanner, and water proof, get the S5. Otherwise literally similar set and you can save a lot by getting S4 now. Last year when S4 came out it was a great phone. It still is, though S5 came out now. Obsoletion is in the mind of the us, not on the devices. In my opinion, following are key specs to consider when you buying a phone. Most of others are standard or does not matter at all. First size,weight and resolution are part of look and feel. RAM/CPU part of performance. external Storage is part of expandability. Camera is obvious! SAR (Specific Absorption Rating) is an often ignored, but I feel essential to making a buying choice. Manufacturers don’t advertize or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) Samsung Galaxy S4 (Intl version): 5.38 x 2.75 x 0.31 in, 130 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.0 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD, up to 64 GB, 13 MP/2MP, Exynos 5 Octa 5410 CPU, Quad-core 1.6 GHz Cortex-A15 & quad-core 1.2 GHz Cortex-A7, 0.85 W/kg (head), 1.55 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G2: 5.45 x 2.79 x 0.35 in, 143 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.2 in, 424 ppi, 2 GB RAM, no ext Storage, 13 MP/2.1 MP, Qualcomm MSM8974 Snapdragon 800, Quad-core 2.26 GHz Krait 400, 0.50 W/kg (head), 0.69 W/kg (body) Google Nexus 5: 5.43 x 2.72 x 0.34 in, 130 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 4.95 in, 445 ppi, 2 GB RAM, no ext Storage, 8 MP/1.3 MP, Qualcomm MSM8974 Snapdragon 800, Quad-core 2.3 GHz Krait 400, 0.92 W/kg (head), 1.23 W/kg (body) Apple iPhone 5S: 4.87 x 2.31 x 0.30 in, 112gm, 640 x 1136 pixels, 4.0 in, 326 ppi, 1 GB RAM, no ext storage, 8 MP/1.2 MP, Apple A7, Dual-core 1.3 GHz Cyclone (ARM v8-based), 1.12 W/kg (head), 1.18 W/kg (body) Samsung Galaxy Note 3 N9000: 5.95 x 3.12 x 0.33 in, 168 g

Textual Messages: THE CHARGER Please note that while the Samsung Galaxy S5 has a special looking port for charging (the new USB 3.0 design) it IS absolutely compatible with existing micro-USB chargers. You CAN use the old charger from one of your old Android powered devices! Just plug it into the right side of the port, the part that looks like a micro-USB port. It just happens to charge really really quickly if you use a USB 3.0 cable, but it's not necessary to do so. THE AMAZING SCREEN First things first, this display is nicer than any I have ever seen. It is so sharp I cannot see individual pixels with my naked eye. It's also bright, very bright! It's perfectly usable on a bright sunny day at noon without a cloud in the sky. I noted that when switching between the highest setting with and without auto-brightness, the screen actually brightened more with the auto-brightness feature enabled, but only in really bright conditions! So if it's extremely bright outside, leave the auto-brightness feature enabled, it actually appears to be able to reach a higher brightness that way. The auto-brightness feature is superbly implemented anyway, so I'd recommend leaving it on regardless. I upgraded from the S3, and I immediately noticed the whiter whites, darker blacks, extremely realistic and still vibrant colors, and even the capability of dimming the screen much more effectively (which is really nice when using the phone in bed). THE INSANELY AWESOME ULTRA-POWER SAVING MODE This thing is for real. With 10 percent power left, you get usability the rest of the day. The S5 has a super amoled screen, so black pixels don't draw any power as opposed to back-lit LCD screens. Ultra-power saving mode turns the screen black and white, and gives you a jet-black interface with up to six black and white icons. It reduces the screen frame rate, shuts down two of the four cores (the phone is a quad core phone), reduces in half the speed of the remaining two cores, shuts down almost all background processes, disables most apps, and sips power all the while letting you text, call, and surf the web. You can check your email via the web, but can't use the email or gmail apps. Basically it turns your phone into one of those old flip phones that lasted forever. That's pretty sweet in a pinch! You know, those moments when you're sitting at the auto-service center, sweating bullets because you're about to embark on the Ramen noodle diet for the remainder of the year? And on top of that your phone's about to die, and all you want it to do is hang on for another few minutes so you can get the invoice and make this call: "Honey, it's the flux capacitor. I guess a device that involves 1.21 gigawatts isn't cheap. It's gonna be 5 gazillion dollars. I think we're gonna be eating Ramen noodles for a while. Can you get one of the chili flavored packs ready for me? I'll be home in about 20 minutes. Don't let me forget to cancel the newspaper. That'll save us a few ... well, dear, I'm pretty sure we need the flux capacitor ... yes, I know ... but college isn't all that important these days anyway; they'll be fine ... Alright, will do. I love you too." At least with the S5 you don't have to worry about your phone. It's not gonna die before you get back. Right now my phone is at 91% power. I just activated ultra-power saving mode, and it says I'd get 11.4 DAYS of standby time. I figure with regular use I'd get a week. You could literally charge your phone to 100% before a week-long vacation, flip on ultra power-saving mode, use your phone normally and probably make it the entire week without having to charge it. I'd love to test that theory. But suffice it to say that gone are the days of needing to worry about a dead phone when you're out all day and don't have access to a charger. THE SECURITY OF A FINGERPRINT SCANNER It takes some getting used to, but once you set up your fingerprints, you can easily activate the phone by swiping your finger or thumb (I set mine up for one-handed use

Helpful: 60 of 73 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: My upgrade became available just in time to get the S5. I shopped around for the best deal and pre-ordered it at a local store. I really liked the phone initially. The fingerprint scanner is a great feature. I had no problems with the response or speed of the phone. Still had some network issues with calls but, I'm use to it with Sprint. After all that, I discovered that this phone does not allow you to Talk & Surf at the same time. For the entire week, I was on a call and made several attempts to get on the internet or do something data related and I would get a "no connection" error. I thought there must be a setting I was missing, so I tried changing the networks to all that was available (CDMA, LTE/CDMA, GSM, Automatic). Each time, I would make a phone call and try the internet and it never worked. Which means, there's no Facebooking, Instagraming, Hangouts, Google Maps/Search, BBM, Twitter, GroupMe...NOTHING data related while on a call. The only time it works is when the phone is connected to a Wi-Fi zone. This was UNACCEPTABLE for me! Hence, the reason I gave it 2 stars. I upgraded from an S3 to the S5 and never had an issue with surfing the net while on a call on my S3. I Talk & Surf everyday. Apparently, this phone was developed with the new 'Spark LTE' network which does not allow Talk & Surf. You can only do one at a time due to a hardware change in the phone from dual band to single band. If you're in the middle of downloading, uploading, surfing, etc., and a call comes in, the phone will immediately cut off your data and will not resume until you end the call. I Googled this issue and it is legitimate based on Sprint Community Forums. Also, I contacted the local Sprint store and they verified this as well. Therefore, I returned the S5 before my grace period was up and got the Note 3 instead. Now, I can Talk & Surf again!! If Talk & Surf is important to you as it is to me, I suggest that you stick with the S3, S4, or the Notes. Stay away from any phone that says "Spark LTE" until Sprint fixes it.

Helpful: 11 of 13 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Let's keep this straightforward and simple: Pros: - Fingerprint sensor works well. While the instructions say to swipe straight downwards, it is actually possible to register your fingerprint at an angle. Do it correctly, and unlocking it one-handed becomes easy. Here's someone who made a video of this: [...] - After a full day of super intense use, the battery is usually left at around 25-35%. This is far better than previous phones I've had. - The camera is excellent in daylight, decent in low-light situations. However, the daytime photos are stunningly good, gorgeous even. - plastic is grippy in hand, looks better in person than in pictures. - used in rain for a solid 30 minutes, the phone received a thorough soaking and still worked perfectly. water resistant claims hold true. Do note, though, that you must have the back cover on properly so that it can create a waterproof seal. - S health is useful if you make use of it. It can track interesting metrics such as the amount of calories you burn in a day, and the amount you walk around in your daily routine. However, the phone does occasionally get inaccurate readings. A vast majority of the time, though, it works fine. - swappable battery is HUGE. You know how your battery gets worn down over a two year contract, and by the time your contract is up, your battery life sucks so you need to replace your ENTIRE phone? Well, you can just replace the battery with a brand new one, and BAM, battery life back to as if it was new. - TV remote is cool and can be useful - Ultra-power saving mode, when on, can extend battery life to (claimed by Samsung) 10 or so full days. Let me repeat: 10 FULL days. I've tested it for one day, and the entire day killed only about 8-10% battery. Do the math and, well, it seems to fit. - One-handed operation can be done, and Samsung has created a few neat tricks to operate one-handed. Use one-handed modes when you need it, enjoy the larger (and gorgeous) screen when you don't need to use it one-handed. - AMOLED Screen for the S5, according to Displaymate's tests, is the BEST ever made. Anandtech also claims that the screen is pretty much superior in nearly every aspect to it's LCD counterparts. But you should see it for yourself, it is absolutely gorgeous and works well in full daylight conditions. - USB 3.0 port is BACKWARDS COMPATIBLE with your older chargers. You just need to plug in your older chargers into the right side of the port at the bottom. USB 3.0 port also means that, with the proper charger, it charges faster than any other phone on the market. Also, you can get usb 3.0 speeds for transfers, which can be anywhere from 2x-5x faster than usb 2.0 speeds (note, usb 3.0 only works with Windows at the moment). - MicroSD supports up to 128gb. I don't think anything else needs to be said. - Android is less restrictive than IOS, but they're both still good operating systems. Choose the one that fits you best. Cons: - speaker could be improved - camera, while amazing, does have some gimmicky features that can be ignored - USB 3.0 is cool, but bottom flap to cover it is not cool. I'd say look into getting a wireless charger ASAP, so you don't have to worry about the stupid flap. To be fair, though, the flap is needed for the IP67 water and dust resistance that the S5 has. - Touchwiz can be a pain sometimes, but for the most part, it doesn't detract from the overall experience Look up "Ultimate Samsung Galaxy S5 Water Test" on Youtube if you want to see the Galaxy S5 survive through both a 1m deep swimming pool, and a full cycle in a washing machine. Will update as I use the phone more. Edit: Pro - You could actually use a pencil/pen with the phone, as long as you enable high-screen-sensitivity in the settings. With a screen protector on the phone, I can now write/draw stuff fairly accurately. There's no palm rejection like the Note 3, but it's still a nice option to have when needed. Pro - phone notification window, where you can minimize incoming c

Helpful: 12 of 15 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I purchased the Samsumg Galaxy S3 when it first came out. Due to an unlimited data contract, I had opted to continue on through the S4 and just now decided to lose my unlimited data by upgrading to the S5. I must say, losing unlimited data is absolutely worth it. Likes The remote control feature. I have a horrendous habit of leaving my TV remote across the room. The IR sensor makes changing the channel possible with my phone. It also linked up to my cable provider to show me what is playing, and changes my TV to that particular channel. Gimmicky? Maybe, but I love it. Fingerprint security - very fast. Not as good as iPhone 5S, but still very viable as a means of security. Hopefully will be opened up to other apps and services, such as Google. A lot of people complain that you must be very accurate while moving your finger across the sensor. I have moved my thumb straight up and down as well as tilted 90 degrees and successfully unlocked my phone. In fact, the only angle I haven’t been able to unlock my phone is by having my thumb oriented upside down. Battery - I haven't had the opportunity to extensively test the battery life yet. However, worth ultra power saving mode on (turns off non essential apps and makes the screen greyscale) the phone reports 10 days of battery life with an 84% charge. IP67 - No dust, no water! I love feeling a little more safe around water. Although the charge port cover is quite annoyingly in the way when it's open. Camera is one of the best I’ve ever used on a smartphone. Clear, crisp pictures and a FAR more intuitive UI than I experienced on the Galaxy S3. The only complaint I have is that it takes a few seconds for the camera to start, which makes it hard to catch impromptu moments! Fantastic call quality. Beautiful screen. 5.1in full HD Super AMOLED Dislikes The capacitive button to the left of the physical button no longer handles settings/menu. Now it’s your multitasking button. My S3 handled multitasking by long pressing the physical button. It’s a small dislike, and something I’m sure I’ll get used to. But I don’t like it for now. Verizon has disabled the use of the download booster mode which allows 4G and Wifi to act together to enable faster downloads. Bloatware. This is becoming a staple with smartphones, and you can disable almost all bloatware in Android. It does still annoy me! No Lockscreen Widgets. At the time of this writing, it is impossible to add lockscreen widgets. Also, if you customize the current lockscreen, you lose the ability to have fingerprint security. The Fence Still plastic +Makes the phone lighter -Feels more prone to break Heart-rate Monitor -Gimicky. I don’t think it will see a lot of use, but only time will tell. Overall: It's a great phone with some very minor issues. If you're upgrading from the S4, I'd skip it, but anything older, and you should absolutely get in on it!

Helpful: 3 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I loved my S3, envied my husband's S4, and now adore my S5. The screen is great, apps work wonderfully and the phone feels powerful. I wish the speakers were a bit better, to be honest, but I mostly use headphones of external bluetooth speakers anyway, so it's not a big deal for me. I especially love the built-in power saving features. Kept my phone going for a 9 day camping trip, with just one recharge from a portable battery. The only thing I'm not crazy about is the camera. It's just kinda slow, and it kills your battery life. The quality of the pictures is good though, and I love that my phone puts everything right to Dropbox and G+ for easy backup and sharing. Overall, I'm very happy with this phone.

Textual Messages: I'm not super technical. I upgraded from my S3 to the S5 for Sprint and thought I'd have more capabilities. Turns out with Sprints new Spark network stuff that isn't the case. I don't know all the technical reasons, but for the time being on the S5 w/ Sprint you are not able to be on the phone and use the internet unless you are connected to WIFI. That means no driving and using the GPS and talking to someone simultaneously. To me that was complete garbage and reason enough to return the phone. The final straw was the fact that Sprint hasn't upgraded their towers in the STL area, so when I swapped phones I would no longer get 4G in STL. My S3 had no problem accessing it, but this new Spark thing really screwed up my connection on the S5. I'm sure eventually it will be fixed, but I didn't feel like paying for an upgraded phone to have diminished capabilities for who knows how long.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Back in January 2010 I got my first cell phone, a Net10 texting phone. I posted on Facebook that I felt like I was the last person in the USA to get a cell phone. Someone responded to that post, "You were!" By April of 2014 I was feeling like the only person in the USA without a smart phone. Even my dad had upgraded from a flip phone to a smart phone! So I took the plunge and got the then just released Samsung Galaxy S5. Upgrading from a texting phone to this smart phone has been an amazing experience. I wasn't sure if it would be worth the extra cost for a smart phone, as I didn't think I would use the "smart" functions that much, but boy was I wrong! I use the phone for a lot of things I hadn't planned on or even thought of. For instance, I go for walks regularly for my morning cardio. Previously I used an old-fashioned watch and a clip-on pedometer to measure my duration and distance, but now I use the exercise timer and pedometer on the S5, and I think it is more accurate than the pedometer. When I am away from my desktop PC, I use the S5 to check Facebook, Twitter, and Google News (my primary new source). I use the Smart Remote ap to turn my Toshiba 40-Inch LED TV on and off when the DVR is recording something, as I have the cable remote set to turn both the TV and DVR on and off at the same time. I jot reminders down in the Memo ap and keep appointments in the Calendar ap. I regularly check the weather with the AccuWeather ap. And I am becoming a real camera buff, whereas I rarely took pictures before; but it is so easy with the S5, and I always have it with me, so why not? And once I started downloading aps, that really opened the door for more stuff to use the S5 for. There was a free Bible ap, "You Version," available in the Play Store, so it was the first ap I downloaded. It works great and has many versions available including the NKJV, my favorite Bible version. I then downloaded a couple of Bible trivia aps, so I now use my S5 for reading and studying the Bible. Then in May I got lost in downtown Pittsburgh coming home from visiting my nephew, so I downloaded MapQuest's GPS ap, and that has been working great at keeping me from getting lost again. After I got my Roku 3500R Streaming Stick (HDMI), I download the Roku remote ap. That is much easier to use than the Roku remote when tying in data, like my user name and password for the Roku or searching for programs in Amazon's Instant Video. Then I downloaded aps for my favorite sports teams: the Pittsburgh Pirates, the Steelers, and Penn State. So I check schedules, stats, and other info on them on the S5. I downloaded the Weather Channel's ap for another "opinion" on the weather (although I've found AccuWeather to be more accurate). And most recently, I downloaded a "white noise" ap to use if I take a nap during the day (I use a LectroFan White Noise Machine at night, as the ap doesn't cancel out noise as much as the LetroFan does). I know this might all be basic stuff to you long-time smart phone users, but for those of us new to this technology, it is truly astonishing. Since this is my first smart phone, I cannot say how it compares to other smart phones. But I can comment on a couple of points I've seen mentioned in reviews of the S5. The first issue is the battery life. With my old texting phone, I only had to charge it up a couple of times a week, but I then I do not make too many phone calls or send very many texts. With the S5, I'm charging it about every other day. But with as many things as I use it for, I don't think that is unreasonable. As long as it lasts a full day, I'd be happy. Second, it is true that you can not multi-task with it. If I were to get a phone call while on my morning walk, I would need to pause the exercise timer to answer it. But no matter, as I'd probably do that anyway. I have had a couple of problems with it. First, a while ago, I was trying to listen to KLove (a Christian radio station) via their Web site on the S5's speaker whi
ID: Gary F. Zeolla "Author of Christian and of fitness books, Web sites, and newsletters"

Textual Messages: I am moving from an SII with T-Mobile and this is a big improvement. The battery life is uncanny, usually have 50% left at the end of a day of steady use. I work in a basement classroom where I was previously unable to make phone calls or use 4G at all, and now I have no problem (don't know whether to credit Sprint or the phone for that). I have seen numerous complaints about how long it takes for the camera app to open, especially compared to the LG G3. I went into a phone store and carefully compared--the S5 takes 2 full seconds, and the the G3 takes 1.5 seconds. I prefer having all the setting options and the superior image quality of the S5, so I can live with the .5 second loss. I do notice that the focusing is not always perfect in indoor closeup shots...definitely miss the macro setting from earlier Galaxy models. That's the only complaint so far.

Helpful: 2 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: After having an iPhone since smartphones became a thing, I decided to take the plunge and switch over to the Android universe. I really wanted Swype and to have a bigger screen and faster processing. I am by no means a techie, just someone that uses her phone for everything and wanted a change. I am writing this review for laymen like me. The Galaxy S5 does not disappoint. Pros: This phone is great. The camera blows iPhone's away. It's fast and I can have several apps open at the same time and it doesn't slow it down. The colors are so vivid and websites, photos, and games are crisp. I love the apps that I've found, including an app called Optimize that allows the user to maximize their battery life with a click of a button. I watch videos and read books on this phone and the screen is the perfect size. It's also not too bulky, as the phone itself is pretty slender. Another big difference are the widgets, which give you easy access to your favorite apps, and the ease with which the phone syncs with my Google calendar. I also love the Google Now feature, which can be accessed by holding down the center button and gives you a rundown of your day, scores from the game, recommendations based off your recently viewed, websites. I have had this phone a month and am still discovering things about it. Cons: The battery does drain pretty quickly, if you are using it all day like I am. But on the upside, there is an easy way to switch your phone to power saving mode (I've done that and had it last a day and a half with no charge). There are a lot of apps that come with the phone, many of which are similar to one another. My biggest gripe is that the charger on this model is different than the Galaxy S4 and most other models, so I recommended buying an additional charger or cord now. Finally, there was a pretty big learning curve, so just prepare to be frustrated at first. It goes away, I promise. Overall, I am extremely happy with this phone!

Textual Messages: I love this phone. I had the S3 and wanted to upgrade. I haven't had any Problems with it., I am able to figure out how to use it still as simple as the S3 was.

I had a iPhone 4S for 2 years and the 5S for a few months -5 or 6 maybe. At one point the 5s became unbearable: incredibly poor battery life, stupid restrictions on customization, unavoidable steps to reach certain functions that I routinely use, and a definite reduction in quality (that mushy home button). Went ahead and paid full price for a Galaxy S5. Oh dear, I wish I had started here from the beginning. This phone is better in every way. Faster, better battery, superb battery management, deeply customizable,... now I can do what I want the way I want and not the way Apple thinks I have to do it. The only thing I would add is about design. For some reason that escapes me some people say that this phone looks cheap. I beg to differ. I found this phone clearly elegant. If you want to know what ugly and kitchs look like have a look at the iPhone 6 (or 6 plus for that matter): that is what I call a joke of design. Having had both the 4S and the iPhone 5S I can say from experience that this phone is leaps and bounds better than Apple's.

I brought this phone after waiting months after it was released to get it and hands down it is the best Android phone I have dealt with! A few years ago I switched from Android phones to apples iPhone because iphones are such great quality and simple. But when I first seen the Samsung galaxy s5 I knew it would give iPhone a run. I am so glad I made the switch to the Samsung s5! The quality of the phone is all around beautiful! It moves fast and does not freeze or crash! The graphics are beautiful and the sound is crisp and clear (HD). The features are so easy to get use to and very convient. And the camera takes beautiful pictures and video. Honestly I can not put this phone down since I got it. I am in love with the finger print lock option it let's me know my phone is secured and I can also make purchases with my finger tip! Awesome! The battery give a good 9 hours before it hits 30% to 40% battery time left which is awesome compared to most phones. And you can get more time with the powersave mode. I am so happy with my purchase. No regrets as of now.

Great phone, a good upgrade from my S3, which was beginning to overheat (battery problem??) and had a cracked screen (user problem!!!). Good call quality, usually better signal strength, faster app execution, longer battery life. Camera is okay, but a few quirks, especially with my bank's app - framing the check is harder and it sometimes won't focus properly on the back side of the check (no lines near the center to focus upon). This is minor and I've adjusted (and perhaps the bank app has upgraded, too?). My only knock is that the security fingerprint unlock is not really ready for everyday use. I was able to store my primary unlock finger in two of the three profiles to get it to work better, but still had issues with sweaty or dirty fingers, or problems when the phone was not a quite the right angle. I cannot image anyone being unhappy with this phone.

Being water resistant is a plus also. Can take pics at the water park this summer without being paranoid and finally emojis without having to download an app

A bit on the touchy side. Camera is amazing. I like the big screen. I am not familiar with everything it does, but a few videos on youtube will help with that. I switched from an iphone and it was not painful. Just remember to tell your buddies who text you, you are no longer on an iphone so that the phone will not send you a text via imessage. You will not receive messages unless you tell your friends to send it via sms. Other than that. It is a pretty great phone. Ps. It will not do dishes or take the dogs for a walk but you can yell at it and command it to set dates and navigate you to the nearest #whereeveryourheartdesires.

Overall everything I expected. It's a fantastic device. The cover to the charge port can be difficult to get a fingernail under sometimes to open; which causes me to accidentally hit the power or volume buttons. The fingerprint recognition isn't perfect and sometimes can be frustrating but still a great feature. The emergency call feature is a really best idea but too many times I've accidentally sent emergency calls to my wife because the screen wouldn't turn on and I got the power button too many times.

I got the S5 the other day and it's awesome! Fast, consistent and what a screen! Of course you have to turn off all the bloat-wear to get good battery life. I'm at 25% battery now after 38 hours of Light to medium use! Again, you should be savvy with Android OS to get the best use and remove or archive the bloat-wear but man, 2800 mha never felt so good! The phone feels good in your hand too. Not too big, but I have big hands. And it's light even with an Otter Box case! I really like this phone!

I just upgraded from an S2 to the S5. The phone has tons of functionality (much of which I don't even know how to use yet). I love the fact that I can split the screen to use two apps at once. I also love access to the new LTE Spark network (something my S2 could not access). I do not like the fingerprint password option, as it seems to require too much work for me to perfectly pass my finger across the specified area of the phone. I also do not like how the menu key was removed from the phone's actual hardware. (There are now only three buttons: home, back, and toggle.) Without the menu key, I could not access anything I had saved in my Allrecipes app (b/c the app does not have a built in menu option). Other that that, I'd say the phone is wonderful, and I'm happy to have upgraded.

First off I would like to applaude the customer service...we had a snag with sprint and the guy was so helpful even took the time to call me and let me know updates on what was going on so they did amazing. We got it figured out late last night and I received my phone today. So amazing job there. Now I had the galaxy 3 and loved it. This phone is so much better. Its reaction time is amazing it had a fast powerup and ive been playing with the phone for about four hours now and my battery is still at 56%. I would recommend this phone to anyone who loves android. I have had nothing but good luck with samsung items. Phones tablets and more. Amazing product great job samsung!

This phone is a substantial improvement in features and speed over my S II.Can't find fault with the phone, except it appears there is an upgrade to the camera software, but I cannot find out how to get it. My camera has far fewer features than Samsungs e-mails to me show. Haven't had the opportunity to call tech support to see if it can be fixed.

Textual Messages: Why the Galaxy S5 is better than my old iphone 4: -It's bigger and texting is easier, but it's not so big as to be inconvenient -has more memory for a cheaper price. I have 5 times more apps and music on the galaxy -you don't need an itunes account -the graphics are wayyyyyy better. It's like a mini HD TV (great for the netflix lovers!) -the camera is much better for videos -it's supposedly water resistant for those that accidentally drop their phones in the toilet. I know too many girls with too-tight pockets that lose their phones this way, so this is a great phone for girls or women who wear tight jeans -fingerprint password is cool -lighter Now what's annoying about it? -I don't know if I can get rid of galaxy gifts and galaxy essentials. The ad for it takes up half my background and I don't find it useful. -it's been crashing from certain apps. How does one small app crash a phone with a hell of a lot more power than the first spaceship? -you need a light on to plug the charger into the phone because the slit is tiny BE WARNED! If you are switching from iphone to android, know that imessages will still go to your old iphone, even after it's been deactivated. Anybody with an iphone that imessages you (which is btw often automatic with iphones) will send a text to your old phone and your new phone WILL NOT GET IT UNTIL THEY MAKE IT A REGULAR SMS. I activated my galaxy myself instead of going to Sprint, so maybe they would have fixed that for me. But Apple is sketchy, so be sure to ask and make sure.

Textual Messages: 5/2/14 Google, Samsung & Sprint have a mix of bloatware they stuff into each generation of phone. Let me suggest something for the next update from each of these parties: Please include the ability to enable/disable all of your "cool" ideas. (And do not tell your boss that you do when you only do some.) For example, Samsung recently shuffled the set of software features between S4 and S5. Some good idea such as lock screen apps disappeared with other not so good things such as trial subscriptions were added. The core problem is that Samsung removes the original ability within Google Android to selectively disable (turn off) apps. It is great that Samsung tries to filter forward a set of interesting apps; Please allow me to disable or enable those apps that you filter forward. For example, Sprint (Softbank) continues to press in app purchase of subscription for voicemail to text conversion. The nagware in Sprint voicemail has no option to disable the nagging even though they think they have some basic options. Sprint has outsourced voicemail as a profit center. It is truly pressing boundaries for Sprint to insert advertisements in voicemail. Please allow me to turn off the nagware. How many times does one have to opt out? Let's encourage them to get a firmware update that benefits we their paying consumers so we can turn off the in app purchases and advertisements.

Helpful: 1 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Sprint Spark kills simultaneous voice and data. I went back to my Note 3 because I do a lot of tethering. Pros: -The new TouchWiz interface is clean. The floating/pop up box for incoming calls is great and doesn't take up the whole screen. -The camera is very clear. As a photographer, I am happy with the camera for use in well-lit conditions. -Battery life is great. I usually get extra batteries but the Ultra Power Saving mode has got me holding off on purchasing extra batteries. -The design looks cheap. The chrome bezel looks much cheaper and rounded than on the Note 3. -The screen is bright, sharp and looks great. Cons: -Low-light camera shots are disappointing. -No camera optical image stabilization, which is becoming a standard feature in high-end smartphones. -MTP via USB 3.0 can be buggy and has its limitations. It takes a few minutes to do simple tasks like renaming folders. USB 3.0 isn't on by default and takes three extra steps. Once on, it reverts to 2.0 after four minutes. -The water-resistant cover is flimsy and gets in the way. It would be nice if they made it water-resistant like the 3.5mm plug. -The fingerprint scanner makes it easier to unlock the phone but is tricky to use. It lets you register 3 fingers with about 10 imprints on each, so you can technically register about 30 different angles for multiple fingers. I registered my thumb at different angles so it would recognize it in one swipe. Still no fingerprint shortcuts to apps, etc. -The bezels around the screen are wide, making the screen look smaller than it really is.

Textual Messages: Like other that had posted on here, the phone was great when it was working, then all the sensors stopped working. He was going to swap the phone thinking that I bought it from BESTBUY, but when he found out the phone was purchased from AMAZON, he told me that I need to contact AMAZON. I had a chat session, a phone session and an email telling me that " Sorry it may be disappointed for me to hear but you just need to contact Samsung" . Sprint and Bestbuy will replace the phones for their customer but Amazon can't match that customer service level.

Helpful: 2 of 5 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: After two days of owning the Galaxy S5, I quickly found that I liked my S3 more than this phone. For one thing, this phone feels bulky. I don't know if it was because I was used to the S3, but it just felt awkward and squarish to me. The HTC One M8 not only looks nicer but felt more comfortable to hold when I saw it in store. The HTC also sports front-facing speakers and has very clear sound quality, while the S5 seems muffled because its speakers are in the back (why they are in the back, I do not know). After powering the phone on and doing the initial setup, I opened up the camera. I took a couple test shots using the normal back camera, and then I tried out the front camera. To my surprise, the picture was distorted! It stretched the top and bottom parts of the frame and creates an odd, enlongated appearance. A quick google search revealed that other people are experiencing the same issue, and there seems to be no fix. For a premium, flagship smartphone, this is unacceptable. Perhaps for those who don't use the front camera this is probably not a big deal. But I couldn't stand looking at my stretched out face. Moving on to the lockscreen: Unlike the Galaxy S3, you cannot add lockscreen widgets such as Dashclock. I don't know why it was removed in this phone. The only thing you can change is the wallpaper and the unlock method. The finger print scanner leaves much to be desired. "Swipe faster." "Swipe slower." "Swipe the entire pad." are the messages that I received when trying to use it to unlock my phone. I eventually had to use my backup password. Overall, I was disappointed with the Galaxy S5. I didn't like how some features were taken out and replaced by gimmicky features such as the fingerprint scanner and the heart rate monitor. I'm in the process of exchanging it with either the HTC One M8 or the LG G3 (soon to arrive in the US).

Textual Messages: My android experience has been exclusively the Nexus series. To which I can't say enough good things about it. With the new Galaxy, I throw a fit of rage on the very first day. First, that annoying port cover. Who designed a $700 computer with a flimsy port cover that is bound to break. It's not a matter of if, it's when, and how soon. Second, the Black screen after period of inactivity. I got this, especially if you are listening to music. When you try to turn it back on, the entire screen goes Black. And your only recourse is to pull off that battery, restart it again. Third, bloatware galore. 16GB of memory space, to which you you only have less <11 GB left. The other 5-6 GB is full of crapware from Samsung, you can't even remove. I can't wait to get the next series of Nexus, then I can dump this one to the dustbin, where it truly belongs.

Helpful: 317 of 328 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Samsung hit the mark with this flagship. All other flagships are a step behind.
Textual Messages: A little background on my love of smartphones - I used to be a major Apple fanboy from the first iphone to the iphone 5. Steve Jobs is still my hero. I made the switch when the Galaxy S4 came out, then moved to the HTC One, LG G2, Note 3, and now the Galaxy S5. I use two phones, one for work and one for personal use. I spent a decent amount of time with all of them and can say that most people would be happy with each and every flagship for daily use for 1-2 years at a minimum but most people come to read these reviews for the small details that make the major differences between just "okay" with your phone or "completely happy" with their device. I won't list out the specs of the phone since that type of info is listed everywhere. But this phone as well as the others listed here are spectacular at being fast, having good to great battery life, and all have good to great cameras. Probably the most polarizing topics of phones these days is the aesthetics, mainly due to the fact that hardware seems to have outpaced the software which means manufacturers cant really make phones noticeably faster than the previous generation. Okay I'll get to the review. Metal vs. Plastic - The HTC One and the iPhone are made from mostly aluminum. Aluminum without question looks fantastic on phones. The colors also look much better on aluminum because they can be anodized giving them a rich and even color that just look great. The main problem with metal is, sure it looks great on day one, but the material is so hard that is super easy to scratch and nick without ever dropping it. I am the type of user who hates cases. They add thickness and overall just make the phone look ugly, and to top it all off, cases are 40 to 50 dollars for a piece of plastic(major rip off). I carry my phone in my left front pocket without anything else in there to scratch it. After a good months use of the iPhone 5 and HTC one, i developed so many nicks and scratches that it really made me question, "Is metal really so great?" The answer is no. Have you ever seen someone with an uncovered black iPhone? After 6 months the sides look silver just from normal wear and tear. Most people who will read this review probably haven't seen an uncovered HTC One mainly because the volume of sales isn't there, but that phone has the same problem. Sure the metal is gorgeous, but it is only on the first day. And what is the point of buying a phone for it's looks if you're going to cover it in a PLASTIC case? Plastic - At first try with the S4 and LG G2, I HATED plastic. The glossy feeling made the phone feel slippery and cheap in my hand. And to top it off, glossy plastic attracts oil like white on rice, which just makes your phone feel nasty at times(or maybe I just have gross hands which I don't think I do because I am a scientist and wash my hands 10-20 times a day). But then the Note 3 came out with faux leather plastic. Sure it's not pretty like aluminum, but it's light weight, it has a nice texture, it doesn't attract oil, and it doesn't nick and scratch like metal. Maybe Samsung is onto something with plastic. Everyone seems so concerned with the way phones look vs how they feel or hold up over time. I can say without a doubt, my Note 3 looks the same way it did out of the box after a few months of hard usage. For the S5 they switched from the glossy plastic on the S4 to a textured dimpled plastic that feels slightly soft, which I think feels fantastic. It is slightly softer with a more grippy feel and it doesn't look at all tacky. I love it. The phone definitely feels sturdy in your hand. Software - The general perception of Android is that it is harder to use than iOS. After using iPhones for 5 years(iPads and macs), and now Android for just over a year, I can say that perception is absolutely false and anyone who says it probably has not given Android a fair chance. In fact, I think Android is easier to use than iOS. With google now built into the phone, it is always listening

Helpful: 39 of 43 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Glad I waited, very good phone
Textual Messages: I owned an S3 and skipped the S4, hoping the S5 would be a major upgrade--and it sure is. As other people are saying, one of the big surprises is the battery life. I went two and a half days of heavy use and still had 20% when I charged it. A few of the bells and whistles feel superfluous, but many of the new features are ones I want. For example, scheduled text messaging is fantastic. At 5:00 AM I can work my text messages and have my responses sent at 8:00. Or scheduling a text to send on someone's birthday is pretty cool. The screen is beautiful. The colors are bright and crisp. The feel of the phone is nice, too--not to heavy, but not so light it feels fragile. It impresses me also that I can use the new adapter for enhanced charging or my old charger if need be. That's the kind of smart design that sells me on upgrading. The only couple things I don't care for are: 1) the cover to the adapter jack is hard to open and 2) the fingerprint scanner takes 2-3 swipes usually to recognize my finger. Apart from that, I'm very happy with my S5.

Helpful: 23 of 25 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: After 2 weeks with the Samsung Galaxy S5, here is a *short* review for those thinking about upgrading. *Note I switched from an iphone 4S running IOS 6* Looks: The phone is very aesthetically pleasing. Though it is still a plastic casing, it does not feel cheap by any means. The dimpled back plate provides a great grip, making single handed operation easy. It is as sleek as it is sexy. The chrome edges are slightly raised providing screen protection that apple really should look into considering how many cracked screens you see with the iphones. DURABILITY: I titled this in all caps because I want to emphasize how durable this thing is. I've not dropped it too many times and the screen is wrapped in a GLASS screen protector. However, the drops that have occurd have not scratched any part of the phone. The best part is that the water proof housing is legit. The only issue is water gets trapped in the headphone jack and must be blown out. You also cannot make phone calls under water, but that is due to the water blocking your signal so that does not deduct anything from it. Screen: Absolutely beautiful. There is little to no glare and the screens auto brightness works perfectly. Plenty big enough to watch Netflix in bed. Videos are so crisp compared to the iphone. Camera: 16 megapixels + Loads of software for image correction and stabilization makes for a camera better than most off the POS cameras. Also, the front camera more than sufficient for you selfie lovers. Battery: I must say, the battery life is quite impressive for the processing power that this thing puts out. I've used it pretty intensely and yet to have it get below 5%. When it did get to 8% and I didn't have a charger, I threw it into Ultra-Power saving mode and it lasted 15 hours with minimal use until I got back to my apartment. Oh, and it was still at 6% battery. IOS to KitKat: The biggest fear for most seems to be learning a new mobile OS. I will be the first to say, it takes some adjusting. IOS made me lazy, but once you learn how to traverse the GUI you'll be asking yourself how you made it so long on IOS. So many features that you never knew were possible on a phone. It literally is a Mobile Computer. I mean, it can run an emulator without any hacks or jail-breaking. Features: - The health monitoring feature is pretty awesome for the active-lifestyle people. The heart rate monitor is a tad finicky, but accurate. Now that I have the hang of it, I rarely encounter issues. - The pedometer is pretty sweet. Set a daily goal and it keeps you informed on your status. Who knew I walked 10 miles on a 14 hour shift. - I haven't used the cal counter but I'm sure it could be handy. All of the SHealth data is plotted so you can see a nice lay out of your day and track progress. - The finger print reader is "Eh". I've been using it for a week. Makes one handed operation hard. I'm more of a fan of the pattern lock. If you could use the combo of the pattern lock and the fingerprint scanner I would utilize it a lot more. Overall, I am more than pleased with my switch the the S5. I would highly recommend this phone to anyone older than an iphone 5/ Galaxy S4. For those currently using the iphone 5 or S4, I wouldn't rush to upgrade as it would not be much of an upgrade. From a iphone 4s to the S5 though, the differences are incredible!

Helpful: 15 of 17 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Fingerprint reader is disabled if you encrypt device (all carriers)
Textual Messages: I have been using my new S5 for a few days now and am very impressed with this device. However I just found a flaw in its use of the fingerprint reader that I found quite disturbing and I have since verified with Samsung directly that this is the way it is designed. The issue is that if you encrypt your device all of the lock screen options go away except for password. In other words if you want to encrypt your device the fingerprint reader is effectively disabled. Samsung told me they would forward my concern on this to engineering but I think buyers should know about this. If you don't intend to encrypt your phone this is not an issue and I would admit most people probably don't. (though more should IMO) The camera on this phone is fantastic by the way.
