Helpful: 19 of 23 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I have only had this phone for a day but I absolutely love it. I owned the HTC ONE M8 for a few weeks and returned it for the S5. Without getting into insane technical comparison, I've listed some subjective comparison points. - Build: The M8 is a thing to behold. As people say, you haven't seen the phone until you've held it. That said, I was scared to death to scratch or drop the thing. I'm not a case guy at all and a part of me dies when I see someone slap a huge Otterbox case around a magnificent piece of hardware. To each his own. I understand people are clumsy and drop things, but I get irritated when 'fanboys' trash a rival manufacturers build....but then put an enormous case on theirs. Anyways, I just prefer the lighter plastic build of the S5. The back cover feels great in the hand and the buttons are all placed in the most convenient spots (for me anyway). I appreciated HTC moving the power button to the right-top side....but it's still very difficult to reach. I've changed phones a lot in recent years and one thing I've learned is that you need a solid week or two with a phone to really form an opinion on a build. Battery: Seems pretty even here. Both get excellent battery life that you'll get entire day out of. Really excited for the wireless charging covers to be released. Don't think people know how convenient wireless charging is if their device allows for it....especially if you have to remove a cover every time you want to connect a cable (which I know isn't the end of the world, but it's the little things, right??) Unless you're some crazy heavy user that plays games all day and watches movies on a 5" device.....you'll love the battery life. Camera: GS5 takes this one but not by much. For normal day to day Instagram photos, both devices are excellent. The selfie front camera on the HTC One was surprisingly awesome! Felt like they should have used that lenses for the back. Keep in mind this phone take high res pictures that turn into large files.....so send with caution. (5-6mb files) TouchWiz: I typically DESPISE Touchwiz. I've used a Note 1, 2, 3, Galaxy S3, S4...and now S5. This is the first time I've actually considered it a viable option to stock Android. Samsung has definitely cleaned things up. My favorite fixes include the messaging app. They've changed in subtle ways to bring it up to date. Kit Kat allows you to choose your default messaging app now (which is awesome!) but this is the first time I've wanted to stick with the stock app. (priority senders is a cool option) Speakers: The BoomSound speakers obviously crush the GS5 here. However, unless this is a feature that you absolutely need....the GS5 speakers are serviceable. I found it very fun to show off the HTC speakers to friends.....but in normal day to day life I keep my phone silenced almost the entire time. (nobody can stand hearing your notification sound go off constantly). ALSO, nobody has brought this up, but when you leave the HTC ONE M8 in your pocket any kind of small dust or dirt particles get jammed in the speaker grill!!!! I wish I could attach a photo of this but it was irritating! That freshly drilled speaker hole look goes away in about a few days. Tried blowing on it but didn't seem to work. Just a heads up. Misc: Wish the headphone jack was on the bottom. Had gotten used to that on other devices. Conclusion: Just wanted to give a few points to those on the fence. You can't go wrong with either phone. It really comes down to build quality. The HTC was something that will definitely turn heads and feel nice and cold in the morning, but remember that summer is coming up. The GS5 will be much more friendly in the elements. Hope this helps.

Helpful: 7 of 7 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I used the iPhone and other Apple devices since I've used cell phones, and I always liked them. When this phone came out and it was time to conveniently upgrade, I took the plunge into the Android world. I have a Macbook Pro, Air, and an iPad Air, and was nervous about how I would like an Android and if I would be able to get used to it fast enough. A little over a month later, I am in love with this phone (and was since I turned it on). Apple's iOS gets a lot of attention for being simple and pretty, but this phone (Android) makes tasks that would take three or four actions on an iPhone take only one or two. There are more customizable features, you can delete preinstalled apps, it is faster and has a great screen on it. For me a big selling point was larger real estate on the screen. It is fantastic and is great for reading, watching sports, gaming, etc. Much preferable to the iPhone. When I hold an iPhone, it feels much smaller, and very comfortable, but I find myself missing so many features that I am now accustomed to on my GS5. There are a few cons, such as a few recurring notifications (volume control and power down) that I don't need and can't turn off, but everything else is seamless.

Helpful: 6 of 6 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: My first Android phone and I am satisfied with one notable exception. I am a 7 year iPhone user. Switching to Android took some adjustments but I am happy to say that Galaxy S5 is better than my iPhone 5 in many aspects, but not quite as good in two aspects. What I like about Android is that it is flexible. Android is open source so each manufacturer can make adjustments to the generic Android OS. With the S5, Samsung has made Android little more useful than the generic version. Samsung has introduced many in-house software for photos, phone, emails, and texts. The result is some very useful features such as regularly updating the local weather and showing it on the front screen, dual zone international clock, quick location/wifi/blutooth on/off switches etc. What I really like about this phone are two things: the screen and the battery life. The screen is simply stunning with colors that really pop out. It is full HD (1080p) and even the smallest icons show their details. All games come fully to life. The battery on this phone with regular use lasts me around 36 hours. That is about 12 hours more than what I get out of iPhone 5 with comparable usage. I initially had some reservations about the size of this phone. I am happy to say this phone is not too big. But I wouldn't want my phone to be any bigger or else I would need to buy pants with bigger pockets. What I don't like about this phone are two things: mediocre image stabilization in its camera and the clunky music player. I took several pictures with this phone and few images came out blurry. Sometimes I took repeated photos and they still came out blurry. Plus, the pictures came out fairly grainy. In my opinion, the camera on S5, especially its image stabilization, is not as good as the one found on iPhone 5 and 5S. I also did not like the music player. The iPhone, in my view, was designed to be a music player from its very inception. This is apparently not so true for Android. Synchronizing iTune music with Android requires separate software purchases (iSyncr for me) and is a definite downgrade from the iTune synchronization with the iPhone. Plus, my car audio does not recognize my Samsung S5 as a "USB Music Player". My iPhone 5 worked seamlessly with my car audio. I still can, however, play music on my car audio using the Samsung S5's blutooth feature. But the sound quality isn't quite good as the USB plug-in. Pros (compared to iPhone 5): 1)Awesome battery life. 36+ hours for me. 2)Awesome screen. Independent tests showed this screen to be the best ever tested (3 months ago), and I believe it. 3)5.1 inch screen is perfect and makes the phone lot more usable. Browsing the web and using apps on this phone is a superior experience to the iPhone 5. 4)Android offers lot more flexibility and adjustments to the user's preferences. 5)Performance is very snappy and significantly better than the iPhone 5. 6)It is waterproof. I have no problems taking this on water related sports such as white-water rafting. Cons (compared to iPhone 5): 1)Image stabilization of the camera is definitely a downer. I had more blurry images with this phone in 2 months than I had with my iPhone 5 in 18 months. Plus, the picture quality is not quite as good as the iPhone 5. Megapixels be damned, I would MUCH rather take pictures with the iPhone 5. 2)Music player is clunky and is incompatible with many car audio systems. Synchronizing music with iTunes can be clunky and needs an after-market software which costs around $5. Even worse, trying to play music via car audio using USB cable simply does not work for me. I can, however, use the blutooth to play music, which has an inferior sound quality. 3)Micro SD card (for extra storage) is significantly slower than internal flash drives. I am using top-of-the-line Samsung micro SD card.

Helpful: 7 of 8 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: My wife and i recently purchased the Galaxy S5 and coming from IPhone I have to say i'm on the fence about keeping them. I enjoy the ease of use of the Iphone, it makes everything simple and quick. On the other hand i like the customization options on the Galaxy S5. I can't help feel like i'm being ripped off every time i get an IPhone. $100 for an extra 16GB of storage is crazy. An extra $100 on the Galaxy S5 would get me a 128GB Micro SD card bringing the total storage to 144GB. My biggest irritation is that there is NO AMAZON INSTANT VIDEO APP(Amazon i hope you read this!) but i don't hold that against the Galaxy S5. PROS Screen - The screen is outstanding. Usually Super AMOLED displays are terrible in sunlight but Samsung did a great job making it work. Everything pops and playing games and watching movies on this device is outstanding. Built Quality - Usually I would knock a phone for being plastic but it works well for this device. The phone is very comfortable to hold and the water/dust resistance is a great bonus. The black model looks pretty good as well. Battery - The battery life is good. On a typical day i take the phone off the charger at 5:45am and put it back on the charger around 11pm. I do some web browsing, text messaging, push email to a Gmail and Exchange account and watch about 35 minutes of Hulu or Netflix. Also, the phone is set to auto brightness. By the time i put the phone on the charger it's at about 10%. CONS TouchWiz - TouchWiz is garbage. I can't be any nicer about it. Both my wife's phone and my phone have froze during phone calls. It simply just goes to a black screen and stays there. To fix the issue the battery needs to be removed for a couple seconds. Same with the Message app. Upon rebooting after the message app fails it tends to send the message you were trying to send at least 10 times in a row. I would understand if the phone was rooted or it was just a third party app giving me trouble but these are core functions of the phone that aren't working correctly. In my opinion the TouchWiz skin takes a good OS and trashes it. Fingerprint Reader - The fingerprint reader is an unfinished and worthless addition to the phone. Trying to use it one handed is a waste of time as it will only work about 10 percent of the time if you try to do a vertical one handed swipe with your thumb. Using it with your pointer finger will give better result, maybe 60 percent success, but requires both hands. Heart rate Monitor - This is pretty much a gimmick to begin with. It works about 75% of the time in my experience. Probably not a deal breaker as I don't see many people ever using it. UPDATE: The freezing issues were caused by the default message app. Having it opened caused the dialer and other apps to freeze. Switching the default to Hangouts fixed the issue. Still not good that a core app doesn't work but i feel that Hangouts should be the default anyways.

Helpful: 3 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I haven't had this long, but I'm really liking it, so far. I could still make a long list of cons, but it wouldn't be as long as my list of pros. The main thing I want to concentrate on is all the dumb apps that AT&T and Samsung feel obligated to push on it's customers. I thought Samsung was getting away from doing that years ago, but my last few phones have been Motorola's and they were much better at not pushing their apps on you. It's just frustrating, because no one wants to use an app that's poorly supported and probably won't be around long, anyway. At least not when there's usually far greater alternatives out there. It takes a lot of time to filter through and identify all the junk, before finally removing it, if possible at all. The sad thing is that all the effort that goes into these apps could have been used on improving the GUI software on the phone. There are simply things that would be easy to do, that everyone would likely enjoy, such as better notification methods. I've always been disappointed in the slow development of mobile phone software, and while it's finally gotten much better in recent years, it still has much room for improvement. Update: That was my initial review and I know it was quite cynical. It's been 5 weeks and I'm still sorting through all the apps, but some of Samsung's are actually pretty good. Still too many junk apps, though. To keep this update short, I won't go through the long list of things I've fallen in love with about the Galaxy 5, along with this version of Android. But I do want to mention that I really like the default keyboard. I'm really missing my HDMI port and FM tuner from my Atrix 2, though (internet radio apps can be great, but they require bandwidth and don't have every radio station.)

Helpful: 3 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Samsung S5 upgrade... a true upgrade
Textual Messages: I switched phones from a Droid Maxx on verizon's network to a Samsung S5 on At&t's network. I'll start off by saying I already really liked the Droid Maxx especially for its great battery life which the S5 just hasn't come close to. That is unless you factor in the different power saving modes which make up a lot of ground on how long you can push your battery. There are so many new features that come with the phone that it is almost overwhelming yet at the same time it really feels like an upgrade. Many people have already gone over the specifics so I'll just give my overall opinion. The basic settings and features that come standard with the phone are fine but once you take a closer look you can see how Samsung really tried to make this phone customization for a wide range of different lifestyles. That said, there is also a bit of a learning curve to get all the settings tailored to your needs. No bugs, and no problems with the operating system. Even though there are some settings that seem gimmicky there are certain situations I can see myself using some of them; like the wave over screen setting to scroll while cooking or any time my hands are dirty, the high sensitivity touch screen setting when I'm wearing gloves in the lab, or pause video when I look away feature when I'm taking notes on a video/lecture. I wouldn't say it's a perfect phone for everybody but there are so many options and settings that you can get pretty darn close.

Helpful: 5 of 6 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: If you've done any research about the Galaxy S5 yet, you probably found at least a few people claiming that it has very few improvements from the Galaxy S4. I can honestly say that this is not the case, and that, coming from a Galaxy S4, this is probably the best decision I could have made for an upgrade. The screen alone, if not anything else, makes the product worth buying, is critically acclaimed and has been praised as the best consumer screen available by Displaymate, a long-running display reviewer. The back has also received some negative buzz; if you've ever held the first generation Nexus 7, it's very similar to that. Personally I find that it makes holding the device much easier, and combined with Samsung's build-in "One-handed Mode," the device is as convenient as ever. Ergonomically speaking, this device beats the HTC One (M8) in just about every aspect, as the M8 that I was playing with slipped out of my hands and onto the table a total of three times, at which point I had to rest it on a surface and use it like that. Samsung also included their USB 3.0 charging port on the device which comes with a special cable, but the port was made so that it can support typical Micro-USB cables as well. The camera is also out of this world, and though it takes some getting used to navigating around the different options and modes available, I think you will be impressed with how quickly it is able to focus on a subject. If you create a Samsung account, you also have other camera modes available for download from the Samsung store, some of which are somewhat gimmicky, others are pretty neat. To date, these include Animated Photo (essentially a GIF creator), Sequence shot (a slow motion viewer), Surround shot (which creates a spherical panorama), Sound & Shot (which adds a few seconds of sound to a still photo, actually kinda neat), and Sports shot (which takes pictures of fast moving objects). All of these are free, by the way, which is really cool. As of writing this review more may have been added! Using the device is super snappy and quick, and going back to my old phone I don't know how I ever survived! Only one app has ever force closed on me while using my S5, and that app was in beta so it's difficult to tell whether it was the phone or the app itself. The IR remote is also pretty cool, and the app "The Off Button" is recommended because it outputs every TV IR code in a sequence so your device can act as a universal off remote. Perfect for turning off loud TV's at the bar! I've also used it to remotely trigger my DSLR, a Pentax K-30, with the app "Camera Remote", which also works great! All in all, there's a lot to be praised about this phone, and I intend on keeping it around for a while!

Helpful: 5 of 6 people found the following review helpful
Tags: I used to be a strict Apple user until....
Textual Messages: So this coming from an Apple junkie I was extremely skeptical of getting this phone and one of the primary reasons was that I have the AT&T Next program and can upgrade every year or so too a new phone. My idea was to get this phone and next year get the iPhone 6 but the 5.5 inch screen that is only going too be released later next year due to the fact that they couldn't find a suitable battery to power the phone. I saw the S5 and was pretty much drawn too it because of the way it looked. It didn't have that cheap feel that the previous galaxy's had (I've owned the S3 and the Note 2) and it looked really slim and really light. I decided to purchase this phone and I've actually been pretty happy with it (considering that the battery kind of drains pretty quick). The visuals are extremely beautiful and I can do 1080p video and it also has a 16mp camera. My one biggest problem that I had with previous Samsung phones was the enormous amount of bloat ware that was included with the phone and that obviously hasn't changed because Samsung refuse to make anything simple. The phone is extremely quick and the 4G LTE makes it extremely easy too surf and play games or run documents. It comes with a dual core 2.5 ghz processor which is pretty interesting considering barely any phones can run this type of hardware without the occasional lag and frustration but this one does really good. All in all a solid build just wish I could uninstall programs that came with it that I'll never use.

Helpful: 3 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: This is my first Android phone; I purchased this to replace my Windows Lumia 900, which in turn replaced my iPhone 4. I think this is the first smartphone I have used that really sets itself apart from the competition. The screen is large, bright, and vivid. There is an adjustment process for new Android users, but nothing that would discourage me from recommending this phone to others. The rear camera is very high-resolution and takes beautiful photos. I have had the phone for a few weeks and I still discover new features and settings almost every day. In short, a great phone that should easily position itself at (or near) the top of any smartphone comparison chart.

Helpful: 7 of 9 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: As a mobile developer who uses a lot of handsets on iOS and Android, I am an iOS user as my primary device. The most difficult thing for me when using a large Android phone is that I find them slippery and relatively impossible to control with one hand. It continues to confound me why manufacturers continues to use slippery chromed plastic rather than attempting to have something which remotely allows you to retain a grip. Related to this is my constant tendency to unintentionally launch apps and/or navigate away from what I am doing while handling the phone thanks to the giant screen with then bezel, and super sensitive capacitive buttons. This hasn't changed a bit with the S5 - I even dialed 911 accidentally the first day I had it - but the performance, features, and display on this device are all so amazing I have been using it as my primary for the past week nonetheless. I also tend to get lost as to what app I am in, especially when using apps with ambiguous names and interfaces (like 'gallery' and 'photos' and Samsung and Google camera apps and editors which launch each other). Being constantly asked for default apps is seemingly a neverending dialog no matter how much I select 'always' - just give me some good defaults and let me change them in settings when I want. I really do feel that at some point, Android needs to bit the bullet and move away from the button arrangement and keep all the controls on-screen or limited to one button like iOS. That display - that display. My word. Its simply gorgeous and so high resolution, I haven't even been using my iPad lately - and I do feel that there will be a sweet spot with phablets where I will eventually not want to bother bringing my iPad mini with me, even though it is easier to do work on. Its also really weird that, although these phablets are outstanding to watch video on, there are so few solutions for propping the device up like the kickstand on the original EVO - much less included with the device. As for tech, the camera on this phone is amazing in terms of features, most notably the 60fps 1080p and 30 FPS UltraHD video modes - wow. Both modes look outstanding and work perfectly - iMovie handled the UltraHD video perfectly, although it only outputs 1080P movies. UltraHD is really hard to appreciate without a 4k display anyway - but while it may not be a very cinematic choice, 60FPS 1080P is just mind-blowingly realistic. I have also been using this with a Gear Fit and Fear 2, and the setup and interoperability has been flawless so far, despite the arguable value of the software. I might have seen my last day not wearing a smartwatch just for the convenience of not having to take out my phone so much. Sorry this isn't a proper review, but more of a stream of consciousness, but wanted to share my impressions of this very cool device.

Helpful: 2 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Very Fast, Wish These Came With Owners Manual...
Textual Messages: My previous phone was a Samsung S2, which I really liked & intended on keeping, but the charger port went bad and it would do all sorts of bizarre things, including drain the battery in 2 hours. So I took the plunge. This is a great phone, but here's the beef & why I didn't give it 5 stars... ATT is why. I'm not singling ATT out for any particular reason other than the deceptive way they treat customers. The price you will be quoted here on Amazon is NOT the price you will actually pay. They warn you there are other fees, but will not tell you what they are other than the $40.00 initiation fee. Well, people, there are so many fees you'll pay a huge amount over the online quote. And the $80.00 a month charge for the 2 gig mobile sharing plan listed here is likewise not really what it's going to cost you. All those unlisted fees and surcharges will cost you $94.88 in the end, almost $15.00 a month, or $180.00 per year, over what you thought you were signing up for. This has gotta stop. Won't one of you politicians submit a bill requiring service providers to tell you up front EXACTLY what all the charges are going to be? This is like living in the Ukraine. That said, the S5 is a great phone. More bells & whistles than you can ever use. Samsung, why can't you pre-load all your phones with a pdf of the owners manual? That shouldn't add hardly anything to the cost & would really help your customer base. For the uninitiated, these phones come without directions, so you'd better have a PC at home so you can go to Samsung's website to see how to install the SIM & memory card, 'cause the included Quick Start Guide doesn't tell you that important procedure. The camera is a fantastic improvement over the S2. Much clearer and many cool options, but a digital camera will take much better pictures, so don't expect miracles here. The size of the lens does matter, so while the marketing data on the camera has impressive numbers, my 1994 Canon 4 meg digital camera takes exponentially clearer pictures than this phone. It's all in the lens. The phone is really thin. Take an S2, make it thinner, stretch it vertically, and you have the S5. Some complain it feels cheap. Really? Not to me. It's light, thin, and compact. Considering what this phone does, I'm impressed with it's diminutive size & weight. One change that I'm finding difficult adjusting to are the Home & Back buttons, and the new one on the left you press to dispaly which apps were recently in use. This last one is really handy, as we all tend to use mostly the same handful of apps, and this is a really quick way to open them up. The battery life is wonderful. A charge lasts me about 2 days with substantial use. The battery is about a third larger than in the S2, charges very quickly thanks to the higher tech charging plug, and even still accepts the old version of a mini usb port charger so in a pinch you can still use your old charging cables, especially if you have a car charger. I really like that.

Helpful: 2 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Made to move from IOS to Android
Textual Messages: I've had the iPhone since day one (The ugly 2g!) I've always been a fan of IOS but after the last few version of both IOS and Android, I have to say I'm believing there is parity. NOTE: The AT&T phone cannot be rooted (at this point, see review date). I didn't know this at the time of purchase. I purchased my phone from AT&T for the full purchase price no contract. Pros: The camera is a vast improvement over the iPhone 5s, we have a toddler and taking pictures with this new phone has been great. Faster focus, more options and better video. Galaxy S5 – 16MP, 2MP front camera iPhone 5S – 8MP, 1.2MP front camera The screen is great, I was worried about getting a phone this big but a week later, I have no regrets. I find myself using this phone more than my tablet. The resolution is amazing and the black levels on the phone are so much deeper than the iPhone. Galaxy S5 – 5.1" Super AMOLED, 1080 x 1920 iPhone 5S – 4" IPS LCD,1,536 x 640 I'm only highlighting the two main pros for me, there are many others but the two above were the most important factors for me. Cons: Specifically for the AT&T Version: The phone came carrier locked even though I purchased it with no contract. The next day, however, I was able to chat with AT&T online and the rep gave me the unlock pin and instructions so my phone is now carrier unlocked. You will need a sim from another carrier to complete this process. (I used a Verizon sim from an old phone in the office and cut it fit. Worked like a charm) The plastic back cover of Samsung is taking some getting used to. I don't keep my phones in cases so I'm used to the feel of the iPhone's solid construction. Don't get me wrong the Samsung Galaxy S5's back dimpled cover does provide a good amount of grip. If you're putting this phone into a case the the construction or rather feel of the construction shouldn't be an issue. Also, a pro for the S5 is the waterproof rating (30 minutes at 1m)! That is a huge plus for me. Learning a new OS took a bit, however, there are dozens of great guides on how to make the transition from IOS to Android as painless as possible. You can get 3rd party apps to modify your desktop screens and dock to behave more like IOS if you liked the way they worked. Also, you can get the parallax functionality of the wallpaper with another 3rd party app.

Helpful: 2 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Samsung Galaxy S5 on Straight Talk with 4G LTE
Textual Messages: I wanted a phone with new technology and would work with Straight Talk. I just plugged in the SIM card and searched Google for the Internet settings. It was that easy. Now I have a 4G LTE phone with a cheap phone/data plan. The phone has all the gimmicky features you could ever want. I disable most of these for the sake of battery life. I use wifi, bluetooth and location enabled. I use various chemistry apps for calculations and a stop watch to time experiments. I get a full day (8-5) on a charge. Also buying full version apps saves battery life because of the constant server queries to display ads that support free apps. Another reason for buying this phone is the guarantee of getting the new version of android. Don't forget your Antivirus. Android is an open system and you keep a lot of personal information on your phone. It just makes sense to protect yourself.

Helpful: 6 of 8 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I did not purchase this phone from Amazon, but I wanted to let everyone know how I rate the new Samsung S5. 1. Weight of the phone. Its light, but not feather light. 5 of 5 stars 2. Processor Speed. Holy cow! Smooth and fast. There simply is no delay with any application. 5 of 5 stars 3. Music Sound with Ear Phones or buds. Excellent bass and overall range. If you have a good quality set of head phones or ear buds you will really enjoy this phone's MP3 capability. 5 of 5 stars. 4. Internal speaker. Its a bit quiet probably because of the extended battery life. 3 of 5 stars 5. Screen Quality. The screen is simply beautiful and large yet its not clumsy to hold on to. 5 of 5 stars 6. WiFi Range. Quite Excellent - It will grab even the most distant WiFi networks. 5 of 5 stars 7. Built In Apps. The email and other built in apps are flawless. 5 of 5 stars. 8. App Stores. I had no problem with Google Play or Amazon App Store running at the same time. 5 of 5 stars 9. Battery Life. The battery lasts all day for me and then some to spare. I usually have about 50% battery life after a full day of work. 10 of 5 stars! 10. Pulse Sensor, The S5 has some built in apps for health and a finger heartbeat sensor. It works ok, but its a little temperamental. 3 of 5 stars 11. Kit Kat Version. Its awesome! Lots of really cool embedded functions like looking at two apps at the same time on your screen. 5 of 5 stars 12. Built In Cameras. Holy Cow! Its the best I have ever used on a smart phone. 10 of 5 stars 13. Phone Microphone. The people say my calls are very clear, the clearest of any cell phone I have had ever! 5 of 5 stars. This phone is a quantum leap ahead of any other Android phone or device out there. It simply runs like the fastest computer you ever owned. I highly recommend this phone!

Helpful: 14 of 20 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Buggy and terrible considering how long the S-series have been out
Textual Messages: For most people this phone may be OK but not for me and probably other tech geeks: GOOD: Best build quality I have seen in a phone. Water resistant not waterproof but still very cool and it works. After it gets dropped in water pop the back off you will see places where water will collect you will want to dry these places off. Despite this the OEM seal on the back cover did a great job of keep water out of the vital components. Phone is very resistant to most drop damage compared to competition. Heat rate monitor is pretty neat and the screen is the best on any phone I have ever seen. BAD: Samsung tried to pack a lot of technology into this phone and a lot of it does not work well. Most if not all of the following problems are common just do a google search and you will see. Firstly, as with a lot of locked DROID phones this one (at least the ATT model) has a bloated user interface over KitKat. Just look at the free space on this phone vs others. I went from a nexus5 to this phone and the difference between OS/KITKAT fluidity was night and day. This phone is constantly locking up and hanging and at least once a day required me to remove the battery to do a hard restart. Even the boot graphics are glitchy...really samsung? When the phone is locked sometimes the screen will no come back on when you unlock it. The finger print lock requires you to stroke your finger at a very specific angle or it wont work. I had about only a 60% success rate after using it for about 2 weeks so I went back to a pin lock. Camera has a really hard time focusing on really close objects and constantly hangs while taking pics and switching between picture modes sometimes locking the phone up. KITKAT has limited the user's ability to write to an external SD card so forget about copying music to it and popping it in your media player wont be able to read the songs. A root could easily fix this and the other issues if one were willing to forgo their phone's warranty but guess what not only is the ATT boot loader locked but it is encrypted so forget about trying to root it for now. Such a shame too with a root I think this would be the best phone out there but no way to really tell if the phone hardware is buggy or the User Interface. Personally I would avoid this phone it is a classic example of what looks good spec wise on paper does not always translate into how good the device is. Very very buggy phone which is unacceptable given this is the 5th series in the samsung S line.

Helpful: 4 of 6 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: The only smartphones I've had have been I phones (3,4, and 5). I loved how intuitive everything about the ios was and the stability of it. I was super nervous about switching, but it was time to upgrade and to be honest there hasn't been anything new and exciting about the iPhone in a while. My husband and I both made the leap. There's very little I don't like about this phone, and since there are plenty of technical reviews, I'll just tell you what I like vs don't like in comparison to the iPhone. The first thing that I noticed upon turning it on was the screen. My god the screen. It is so. .. crisp. The colors are amazingly bright and clear. It's really beautiful. Let's not forget the size. Looking at it on the store shelf, I didn't think it would be that much bigger than my iPhone. It is. I have rather small hands, so I can't really use it one handed like I did my iPhone. There's some sort of setting that's supposed to shrink it down, but I haven't messed with it. It's not that big of a deal to me. Next, the camera. The 16mp rear facing camera takes amazing pictures. I no longer feel bad about my son's moments being exclusively captured on a phone camera. It seems a little slower than the iPhone, but the quality is so much better it's worth it. Now, the front facing camera is another story. 2mp? ! Really? It's the age of selfies and I have a 2mp front facing camera. Pictures taken with it definitely leave something to be desired. Oh well. App selection is awesome, obviously. I did notice a free app on iPhone is like 2 dollars in the play store (genius scan). I also really like kid zone, as does my three year old. I can just hams him the phone and not worry about him getting into other stuff. I did have to download a visual voicemail app. This is such a convenient thing that I don't understand why a phone would not have it already. My husband and I both were displeased about it enough that we found the app and downloaded it separately. It being made out of plastic isn't a big deal to me. Are there really people walking around wit phones not in cases? The fingerprint scanner sucks. It hasn't recognized my fingerprint the first couple tries ever, so I don't use it. The heart rate monitor also seems superfluous. The os takes a little getting used to. Mainly because there's just so much more that you cam do. Most of the stuff you'll be using on a day to day basis is easy. Oh and swype? Yeah it is fantastic. The phone is just so much faster than the iPhone. Now...I have had to restart it a couple times to get it to stop acting wonky. That was one of the biggest reasons I stuck with iPhone foe so long; none of this stupid turn it off and on again bs. Hopefully it doesn't become a regular thing. Overall there's much more I like about the phone than dislike. Apple would needed to do something drastic to get me back and I really just don't forsee that happening!

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I love my Galaxy S5. I went from iPhone 5S to Galaxy S5 and I am glad I made the switch. Now the iPhone 6 is out and this is the first iPhone release I'm NOT excited about. Now I am anxiously awaiting for the next Galaxy S release.

I've had my AT&T S5, purchased from Amazon on sale for one week. I am very pleased with my purchase and find the phone to be a great improvement over my old Sky Rocket S2 in every way. Pros: Battery life - Average 1.5 days between recharging with moderate use. Big beautiful screen - The color and sharpness are amazing. I keep the brightness turned way down which probably helps the battery life. Speed - This thing is fast!! KitKat - Wonderful improvement over Jelly Bean. Everything just works and integrates well. Fingerprint scanner - Provides a reasonable amount of security with ease of use. It has worked well for me. Cons: Size and Weight - this phone is large and heavier but this is a reasonable trade off for increased screen size and battery life. Samsung apps - Turned almost all of them off. Not really of value to me With Nova Launcher installed this phone has exceeded my expectations. Combined with a under ninety dollar sale price for a two year contract and I have IMO the best value currently available at AT&T.

Still not without its glitches, but it seems they're ever closer to approaching the seemless experience I've had on Apple products. That may sound like a dig, but its not. Apple may be seemlesss, but they're also very limiting in my opinion. That said, there is also a bunch of what I'd consider, useless Samsung apps that come with it. They're easy enough to ignore/disable/uninstall. It feels like Samsung is trying to build its own version of a lot of the various cloud services that frankly, a lot of other companies do better. Textual Messages: I love the display and resolution of this phone. Battery life is very good compared to my previous Samsung Galaxy Nexus.

I was so looking forward to getting this phone; all the reviews were great! I am so disappointed in it. For some reason, Samsung changed the port for the power adapter so it required me to purchase a new car charger, extra power cord for my office, etc. It doesn't hold a charge as long as the reviews say. I have practically everything turned off that sucks energy and still need to plug it into the charger every four or five hours with minimal use. It turns on easily in my purse, using up valuable battery time if I'm not watchful. The little plug cover that is supposed to help it be water-resistant came off within two months of my using it (and flipped into a sewer vent, so no hope of recovery). The camera is so-so as is the speaker. The resolution is stunning, however; and the microphone (for voice texting/searching) works really well.

This is a marvelous phone. Switching from my older was a breeze with the Smart Switch Mobile app. It transferred everything. It was seamless. I must say the ultra-power-saving mode on the S5 is nothing short of brilliant. I was in a hurricane warning, and a storm was approaching. I charged my phone and turned on the ultra-power-saving mode, because if the storm hit, I would not know how long I would be without power. I was lucky that the storm changed course and went south of my location. I did not lose power, but there are areas that have been without power for 12 days. That could have been me, and the ultra-power-saving mode would have given me power for my phone for 12 days on stand-by. I love that the apps are all in alphabetical order. It makes them easy to find. This phone is really very good.

Helpful: 0 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I agree 100% with the reviewer Kevin Jarboe. I have experienced many of the same issues. Been using Samsung Galaxy S Series for a few years (S, S3, S4 and S5 now). I usually love Samsung phones but I am very disappointed with the S5. It is the worst user experience I have had with this series of phones. I was excited about the S Health App and used it religiously. However, Samsung forced updates often that caused the app not to work anymore or loss of health data I took extra time to record everyday. This happened at least 3x so I finally removed the app. Sad because this was my favorite app and also one of Samsung's selling points. There are way too many taps required to get to the options or page destination you need. Example: While listening to music, I turn up volume, the phone stops 1/2 way up with a notification 'listening to music at a high volume can damage hearing..blah blah' then you must tap continue before the volume will crank up any higher. I don't like to be disrupted when I am enjoying my music. There is no option given to NOT show that message anymore so this happens everytime. Another example: Texting or browsing websites, if you receive a link via text from someone in your contacts, then tap the link to open, a msg displays with about 5 options, then you select, then a warning msg displays, then you tap continue, then the option of what browser to use displays, select and finally your page shows up. WTF!?! That is 4 taps just to view a web page sent from a friend via text. Why not just use my default browser, let the system autoread whether msg is from my contacts and eliminate the question of whether I want to open this link. This should be more user friendly as the previous versions were. Many of my photos are blurry due to camera having issues focusing. I could go on but I think the reviewer I mentioned above nailed it. These issues annoy me so much that I am thinking of switching over to iPhone. Never used one but I would try it due to the bugs and ridiculous changes with the Galaxy S5 at the moment.

Helpful: 0 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Overall, this is just an okay phone. I have been using iphones for the last 6 years and wanted to make a switch due to all the comments I've heard about how great Android was and the Galaxy phones offer more features. However, after purchasing this phone, I decided to return it. Here are my highlights: PROS: - S Health: Works great. The heart rate monitor works most of the time but you have to be still and in a quite area - Fingerprint Scanner: I read a lot of reviews about people knocking the scanner and saying it doesn't work well. I haven't had this issue, it works great - Beautiful HD display - Expandable memory via SD Micro Card - Replaceable Battery - Tethering for Free (if you download the right app) - Customization: This is a big + with Android. Not happy with the keyboard? Change it. Not happy with the layout of your phone? Change it. There's a lot of room to modify and change your phone to make it unique. CONS: - Poor Battery life (it drains 1% of my battery every time I play a 3-4 min clip on youtube). I've read tons of articles on tips and tricks to improve your battery life and nothing has helped. I possibly could have a bad battery. - No visual voicemail: Yes, you can download apps on their Google Play Store that support visual voicemail, however the quality of the visual voicemail is not as good as the iphone - Sound: The speaker on the phone isn't all that clear. Also when you put the phone on speaker, the phone itself feels like it vibrates based because of the sound, it makes the phone feel cheap even though I very much like the design of this phone. Furthermore, call quality is just so-so. Again I felt my old iphone 5 was more clear when making calls - Camera: When used outside, the pictures look good, however, when taking pictures inside the house or low light settings, this camera is very bad. I was shocked to see that the iphone 5 had much better picture quality and color tone. I can't help but make comparisons between the phones I've had in the past few years and this one I recently purchased. The Galaxy may offer 50+ more features than the iphone due to customization, however it appears that things that iphone can do, they do extremely well and is of high quality.
All I expected and more, easy to use.

Way better than any iphone. Love it
Amazing! Best phone on the market.

Helpful: 3 of 8 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: So, here's an honest review; I don't know if I got a bad unit or not, but I didn't care enough to have it replaced; I just sold it at a loss. Let's get the obvious out of the way; the design and materials on this thing are terrible. The camera bulges out, and if you don't put this sucker in a case, you are going to scratch up the glass. The whole unit looks like it was designed by fisher price; perhaps I'm a bit spoiled, coming from an iPhone, but c'mon, even that fake metal ring around the phone looks cheap. The flap for the charger takes some getting used to; start growing long nails! But if you are willing to overlook the design, the real kicker is the touchwiz monstrosity that is preload on this phone. If you are used to a consistent user experience, well, it got up and left the building, and brought all his friends with it. Colors, circles, squares, ripples, oh my! I have a pity on a fool that opens up the settings menu! Endless sea of circle icons! This is the most complex UI I've ever used! But on the other hand, one might say, it has the horsepower to chew through all those layers of gummy bear UI, right? Wrong! Touchwiz stutters, lags, and sometimes crashes and restarts; watching Netflix heats up the phone enough for you to cook eggs on! That brings me to another topic; battery life. I can't relate to any of the glowing reviews on here about battery life, but the battery life on this thing lasts for 8 hours; on stand by. Yeah, there are no rouge processes running in the background, the signal strength is OK, and yet, by 3pm, I have about 30% battery left, and when I get home, the phone is dead. I'm now tied to a charger everywhere I go; I have one at home, at work, and 2 in the car, just in case I get stranded somewhere and one of the chargers breaks. Also, the unit does have some physical defects, the front facing camera wasn't seated properly, and there is a small piece of plastic covering the top portion of it. Whenever I try to do a Skype or the likes, the other person enjoys the view of my neck. I would assume this is a defect or a phone for ugly people; I don't know! The device also fails at basic phone functionality too; whenever I receive a call, sometimes the screen would remain dark. I would wait 1 ring, 2 rings, 3 rings, I would tap the screen a couple of times, shake the device in a voodoo fashion, hit the power button, and then eventually the screen would turn on, and inform me that I missed the call. Hmm... One would think that these reasons are enough to avoid this device at all costs, but it's not over yet. Bluetooth stack on this thing was probably written by a 6 year old; it doesn't work! It's Snap, Crackle and Pop all the way to the magic forest, with occasional Bluetooth crash here and there. At first I though it was incompatibility, but then I realized, it's the same with any Bluetooth device. It made Bluetooth audio useless with this device! I couldn’t list to music in the car, in the house; my only other option was to run an audio wire, circa 1970’s. The speakerphone is on the back of the phone and is tinny; crank it up during a conference call, and it starts to crackle. But it’s not all gloom and doom; perhaps a device can be forgiven for all its innumerable flaws, once you gaze upon the gorgeous AMOLED screen! It is truly a sight to see, no doubt about it. This is perhaps, the only advantage that this phone has going for it; this, and the camera. It does take good-looking shots, whether indoors or out, so you aren’t going to be disappointed by the pictures you take. Overall, it’s hard to recommend this device over something like an iPhone, or an HTC One; heck even Xperia Z2 is eons ahead of Samsung! If it weren’t for that screen, this phone would have flopped!

Helpful: 47 of 56 people found the following review helpful
Tags: The Galaxy Series is finally Getting there (Sprint Edition)
Textual Messages: Ok, First off, I had to get my phone through Sprint, since they only offer the "Easy Pay" plan online or in store... (I would go with an Amazon Easy pay in about 2 seconds of it existed.) **Update 5/9 - I had my first experience of the IP67 Waterproofing Yesterday... I was working in my yard and had my phone in my shirt pocket, while up about 4 feet in a ladder my phone slipped out and dropped straight into a bucket of water! Honestly despite the certification I thought my phone was toast... But Nope, it didn't miss a beat, it was still working and playing Pandora without a problem. I was worried so I took off the case and back cover and found no water penetration into the phone, (The phone was submerged for about a minute) This was very satisfying to see and definitely increased my happiness with the phone....** Also this review won't go into Tech specs or Vs the major competition, Specs have been covered and "Vs the competition" is pretty subjective.. I owned an S4 so I'll compare it to that. Size: no major difference, it has decent hand feel, no it doesn't have a metal case and it isn't perfect but it works for me just as well or better than the S4. OS: I haven't rooted it yet or replaced the OS. The stock touchwiz seems to do fine in normal operating mode (It does stutter a bit in heavy power saver mode) Battery: It performs as well as my S4, and on most days a bit better... I used to get 8 hours even before I got the 15% battery warning, Now I go between 8 and 11 depending on use. Screen: It is significantly easier to see in sunlight than the S4. It does seems like it gets brighter... Samsung Features: Air Gesture and Smart Stay seem to work well. At least I should say better than the S4. I still have trouble with smart stay as I wear glasses, but it does seem better. The heart-rate monitor is a neat feature, and works well, but not something that influenced my decision. The Fingerprint scanner works better than the one on my work PC, but it is still more of a hassle (IMHO) than just punching a code or swiping a pastern. If I could just press my finger tot he screen and it would unlock then it might beat out the other lock methods for me. So in general I think it's a decent upgrade from the S4, but nothing that can't wait a year until the "S6" in 2015. (Except the inclusion of Tri-Band LTE which the S4 doesn't have). That all said if you have a sprint S4 and your LTE signal is good, you are safe to stay, but if you are on an S3 I would recommend the upgrade. It does do wireless charging either with an adapter or with the "Charging Cover" just like the S4, and I can't see any difference in the speed of charging between the S4 and S5... One caveat I found: The Tri-Band LTE no longer allows SVLTE (Simultaneous Voice and LTE Data) This means like AT&T you can no longer use data while you are talking on the phone (While on the network, Wifi still allows it)... So no checking a website while talking is out) Overall I give the S5 4 Stars: 5 Stars to start with. -1 Star for no SVLTE -.5 Star for Fingerprint Scanner Quirkiness -.5 Star for Plastic Design again +1 Star for Smoothing out Touchwiz Android Skin So 4 Stars overall, It's getting close to what I want a phone to be, but falls just short. It has replaced my S4 and I won't be switching back, but I Really hope the "S6" Addresses some more of the design quirks and brings battery life up significantly Just my thoughts, AK

Helpful: 4 of 4 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Read my review before you buy it. Beware!!!
Textual Messages: ATTENTION FUTURE BUYERS Read this before buying. I just got this phone 2 days ago and I will return it. 1st: this phone is not VOLTE which means you CAN NOT use the data while you are in a phone call. That's because Sprint use the one antenna for calls and data, so when you are call someone the data is turn off. 2nd: since I updated my firmware to android 4.4.4 my phone is getting terrible reception, showing one bar the majority of the time (Lame) . I tested the S5 against my Note 3 and it was mind blowing the Note 3 was on 4g LTE 80% of the time while the S5 was in and out of 3g the whole time didn't connect to 4g at all. 3er: The speakers sounds distorted when you turn the volume up. Coming from the S4 to the S5 i feel like i downgraded. I will keep using it for 3 more days before o return it. The reason why they are selling it so cheap is because they have warehouses fill with this phone and they have to get rid of them before the new Samsung Galaxy comes out on February. Im really disappointed I knew between the S4 and S5 weren't much different but I didn't know I was gonna take a step backwards. I've done my research and found out that At&t and Verizon S5s do support VOLTE. Sprint have the capability to do it but they aren't allowing us to use it. For more info Google Samsung S5 Cnet review. If you want a phone that wont have to worry about for the next two years get the Note 4. The Note 4 have been voted by most phone critics out there the best phone out right now. it has better screen than the S5, better Battery plus it comes with latest Android Lillipop installed. I returned my S5 and got a Note edge.

Helpful: 19 of 25 people found the following review helpful
Tags: The first time in years I've been absolutely stoked on a new phone; Samsung's best Galaxy
Textual Messages: So, being a relatively practical smartphone guy who admittedly doesn't explore the world of apps or features nearly enough - the most important things first: (Sprint PCS 16gb Black Model, Phoenix Area) **upgrading from an HTC One** 1. The mobile data, which previously was erratic 4g coverage in my house/neighborhood or 3g only, has gone from averaging 1-2mbps to 7-12mpbs. There are about 4-5 spots in my house that I use when running SpeedTest on any device, and the S5 kills it. I've had the HTC One and the Galaxy Note II/S3 over the last 3-4 years and they all seemed to struggle with the data network in my actual home or surrounding area....2mbps on Sprint was the best I usually got. 2. The size and the casing of the phone finally feel "right' - imho, the S3 felt a bit too cheap and the Note II was a bit gigantic. The screen size, whatever it is, is exactly in what I consider the sweet spot (and looks incredible). It's not made of metal or the heavy material that I associate with iPhones, but it feels durable in all the right areas. 3. If I end up being wrong about this, I'll update the review, but it appears to not have nearly as much pre-loaded garbage apps or bloatware as some of the earlier Samsung models. Out of the box it's lightning quick, and after about 5 minutes it was customized to my liking with all layouts/widgets/apps/feeds in their proper place and all security features configured and ready to go. 4. Keyboard input is noticeably better than other phones I've used lately. The default layout has a Swype-like feature on it, but also is surprisingly accurate when typing on the standard qwerty layout as well. Swype's keyboard was on the phone when I first checked, so either Google synced it up immediately or it was standard on the phone (I suspect the latter, as my account wasn't linked to it....gotta re-enter all of my dirty words). There seems to be a lot more to this phone and the OS is inviting enough that I may finally cave and start dinking around with apps and sHealth and all of the Web 2.3 (or are we at 2.4 yet?) toys my friends are obsessed with. But regardless, I can sum up how I feel about this phone with two sentences and the TL;DR: TL;DR - if you're used to Galaxy phones and like Samsung's previous models, consider this to be their best without question. All of the small upgrades seem to work as expected and have a clear purpose, and the Sprint network itself has massively improved functionality on this model (vs. the HTC One or Galaxy Note II).

Helpful: 4 of 4 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Its thinner than I expected, which makes it light enough that holding it up to your ear isn't an annoyance. The textured back makes it easier to hold on to, so you don't drop it. The sound quality on a call is great, and its pretty good listening to music too. It came with a pair of headphones with a mic that also work really well for calls or music. The phone is plenty powerful, applications are quick to respond, and the recent apps button that replaces the menu button lets you swap between recently used apps, and it happens so fast, it almost feels like multi-tasking. Its really an amazing phone. My only complaint, was very minor, in that I couldn't find the sd card slot. It is right on top of the sim card slot, which makes it easy to miss. There is an icon indicating you can put an sd card there, but before I looked it up online, I didn't even notice the icon. Not really enough to deduct a star.

Helpful: 3 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Most advanced phone I ever own so far.
Textual Messages: I was eyeing this phone since it 1st came out. I've had it now for about a month and I had decided it was time to upgrade from my still working Epic 4G(S1) phone. I really like the waterproof feature as I have killed a couple of phones in the past to water damage. My old Epic suffered minor water damage on a few occasions but always seemed to work again in the end. Samsung made a well sturdy phone with a lot of features. This phone is guaranteed to stay working even if you were to drop it in the sink as long as you have the back cover and charging port cover tightly closed. With the quad core cpu I do more now in less time with fewer reboots or lock-ups. Keep in mind it has a fm radio, fingerprint scanner for screen unlocking as well as so many other features as I'm still learning it. There is no paper manual but you can download it from the web. This is also a sim card phone, and if I understand sim phones, this one can be used with any carrier just by swapping the sim card. There is no sdcard installed but it will take a 128gb sdcard, I took the 16gb out of my Epic so I would have the extra space until I am able to get a bigger card. If you used foxfi or pdanet for a hotspot program like I did in my Epic, this phone will only work in Bluetooth and usb modes (wireless tested but no connect) but it will give you 4G-LTE speeds, which is faster than dsl, but about half as fast as cable. Highly recommended for those wishing to upgrade to the best that money can buy. Make sure you pair this with a good case and I recommend a tempered glass type screen protector as well.

Textual Messages: Upgraded from my Galaxy G3 which had become a charge addict. Let's face it - all modern smartphones get the job done. This one is no exception - it does everything fast, nothing lags, and has an amazing display to boot. BUT, what sets this phone apart is the battery life. I can use MapMyRide (GPS, bluetooth heart rate) and Pandora for my morning bike ride (2 hours starting at 7:30 am), use the phone during the day for about 45 minutes of calls and still end the day at 11 pm with 45% battery life showing with no charging during the day. Finally..... Now, I Have to figure out what to do with all the extra USB batteries and chargers.

Helpful: 2 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Oh, Another year, another set of phones from manufacturers! I have been hooked onto get the latest phone every year syndrome and love reviewing specifics. Disclaimer, I love Android and have been using from very early days. I will not call Samsung Galaxy S5 as revolutionary, but it is certainly evolutionary. If you have an older phone more than 2 years old, absolutely get this. I love Samsung Galaxy S5 from its competitors for few reasons - removable battery, microSD card support and the maturity of the product. I have been using a S5 for past couple of days and have ordered a unlocked one from my local store. There are so many variants already in the market. So do check local specs. For example, in china market dual SIM S5 is available. Galaxy S5's back plate has a perforated dot pattern and a excellent matte finish. As a result, the phone looks far more sophisticated than its past designs despite its plastic build. Its surface feels nice to the touch without being too rough or too slippery. I really do _not_ care about the plastic, in fact the lightweight nature is what I care. Some people make a huge deal out of it. A high quality plastic is good for lightweight and I go with lightweight than a heavy phone in the pocket. A reputed tech site called recently Samsung as the “undisputed king of the Android smartphone space”. True indeed. With the plethora of devices in tablets/phones, they have iterated so much that they can produce truly stunning products. If you care for weight, the Galaxy S4 is lighter than S5. (please see my stats below). In fact pixel density is slightly higher in S4 due to a 0.1in size difference. So get an S4, it is cheaper and still same phone that came out last year. If you care for heart rate monitor, fingerprint scanner, and water proof, get the S5. Otherwise literally similar set and you can save a lot by getting S4 now. Last year when S4 came out it was a great phone. It still is, though S5 came out now. Obsoletion is in the mind of the us, not on the devices. In my opinion, following are key specs to consider when you buying a phone. Most of others are standard or does not matter at all. First size,weight and resolution are part of look and feel. RAM/CPU part of performance. external Storage is part of expandability. Camera is obvious! SAR (Specific Absorption Rating) is an often ignored, but I feel essential to making a buying choice. Manufacturers don’t advertize or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) Samsung Galaxy S4 (Intl version): 5.38 x 2.75 x 0.31 in, 130 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.0 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD, up to 64 GB, 13 MP/2MP, Exynos 5 Octa 5410 CPU, Quad-core 1.6 GHz Cortex-A15 & quad-core 1.2 GHz Cortex-A7, 0.85 W/kg (head), 1.55 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G2: 5.45 x 2.79 x 0.35 in, 143 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.2 in, 424 ppi, 2 GB RAM, no ext Storage, 13 MP/2.1 MP, Qualcomm MSM8974 Snapdragon 800, Quad-core 2.26 GHz Krait 400, 0.50 W/kg (head), 0.69 W/kg (body) Google Nexus 5: 5.43 x 2.72 x 0.34 in, 130 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 4.95 in, 445 ppi, 2 GB RAM, no ext Storage, 8 MP/1.3 MP, Qualcomm MSM8974 Snapdragon 800, Quad-core 2.3 GHz Krait 400, 0.92 W/kg (head), 1.23 W/kg (body) Apple iPhone 5S: 4.87 x 2.31 x 0.30 in, 112gm, 640 x 1136 pixels, 4.0 in, 326 ppi, 1 GB RAM, no ext storage, 8 MP/1.2 MP, Apple A7, Dual-core 1.3 GHz Cyclone (ARM v8-based), 1.12 W/kg (head), 1.18 W/kg (body) Samsung Galaxy Note 3 N9000: 5.95 x 3.12 x 0.33 in, 168 g

Helpful: 2 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Tags: Are they making them too fast to quality check them, now? Or did I just get unlucky?
Textual Messages: Since receiving this phone, I get occasional blank screen. The lights will come on for the application selection and back back buttons, but the phone does nothing. Sometimes I can tap it just right (a gentle nod to the old days when smacking a TV would make it come back to life) but I do no more than a typical tap. Ultimately I end up either pulling out the battery and putting it back in which seems to work so far, or I have to try to do a hard restart by holding the power button in until it gives up, then turn it back on. With those seeming to work and the occasional tap, I must assume that the issue is an electronics connection on the motherboard or between the video card and display. Another, unrelated(?) issue is I will occasionally get an error message that either the SIM card or SD card are disconnected, but when I check it, it appears to be as snug as possible. I have been a huge fan of Samsung phones owning the Epic, S3, S4, S5 and even the Note 2014. I don't know if the supplier gets "potentially unwanted" batches and takes a gamble or if this is an issue I have so far been fortunate enough to avoid, but some research suggests I'm not alone. Some home remedies include resoldering the motherboard, but I don't want to risk warranty voiding. I was also told by a Sprint rep that phones not purchased directly from the store or website are not supported by the representatives in the store. So where do I go? I give it two stars because it has some really convenient features that I love using when it works, but then I get a phone call during "Blank Screen" and I sit there helpless wondering who called and if it is important. Am I alone or did others have this experience with their Amazon s5 purchase?

Helpful: 8 of 11 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I know I wont cover everything that this phone has, pro and con, so I will just explain what I've noticed. First off - the plastic. Seems like every review has a gripe with plastic as a material on this phone - Ive owned iphones (1,2,3,4s,5s), HTC's (one), and Galaxy's (SIII) - and I enjoy the feel of this phone. The back is dimpled soft, if youve seen or held a (Asus) Google Nexus 7 2012 the back is exactly the same, soft to the touch and provides great grip. The plastic sides may scratch, but honestly not as easy as a HTC with its brushed finish. When I first opened the box, I held the phone in one hand and the battery in another and couldn't figure out how, together, they would create a sufficient weight to 'feel' like a phone. You get used to it. I didn't like the riveted bezel in pictures, and while its grown on me, I still don't think aesthetically it was the best choice. The phone is IP67 which means dust and waterproof, something I have yet to voluntarily test. After a few minutes the phone felt just like it should in my hand. I can operate almost all features with one hand (6'1" / normal hands). The S5 is truly a slab of a phone, thin with an exquisite screen. The screen pops with color and is hypnotizing when you throw a good image or video on there. The camera is great, though I would highly recommend the Google official camera in the play store. The stock Samsung camera is good, but has so many options and settings a nerd like me gets too lost in technical aspects. Google camera uses the Samsung's 16 megapixel sensor beautifully - the panorama and photo-sphere modes blew everyone away at the beach. No matter the camera app you use, low light is a large problem for this sensor, and it shows in most pictures I've taken inside. The video is 4k, though I've read its not technically 4k playback, fact is, I don't have a 4k TV so it doesn't matter. The video looks good on my 23" monitors and that's good enough.The s-health app is pretty much useless with its heart rate sensor constantly unable to measure or reporting vastly different readings, and the pedometer was different than a few other fitness wearable I've compared. Touchwiz is less bloated, but since I've used Cynogenmod 10.2 on my SIII and stock Android on my HTC I still see allot of unneeded stuff there. The reason I haven't tried to flash this S5 yet is that some of the features really are cool, like power saving mode, right now with my S5 @ 88% it estimates 11.0 days of standby time in 'Ultra Power Saving' mode. This may come in handy soon, because the screen (as gorgeous as it is) hogs the battery. Right now its using 32% of my systems battery resources and its set to about 45% brightness. The Touchwiz over Android KitKat is snappy as hell, only lag I get is with my Google Voice integration stuttering when I open the Google Voice app to text. One other thing that is trivial but worth a mention is that the USB 3.0 charger is bulky and tough to attach to your phone, you first pull off the sealed port on the S5 (b/c of waterproof) that is held on with a small piece of plastic, and to get the USB male end into the port, youve got to be firm. It does charge fast, about 2 hours to full charge from 3% for me so far. I think that the Samsung Galaxy line is truly a workhorse of a phone, and plan on having this for at least a few years.

Textual Messages: Fast and reliable. I upgraded from a Galaxy s2 so it was a major difference for me. This is the first time I've purchased the "latest" phone and I'm pleased with that decision. The Bluetooth connected easily to the Microsoft Sync in my car, though it's not compatible with the text feature (2010 model basic ford sync) - this was true with my s2 as well. Features I like have more to do with software upgrades such as the widget allowing you to track your data usage with the option to warn you of reaching your limit (if you have a limited data plan). Similarly, it tells you which apps are using the most data allowing you to adjust your usage. Automatic back ups to the cloud only kick on with wireless connections (smart). Oh, and it's FAST! Set up with my work email accounts on Microsoft exchange servers was a breeze compared to past phones too. My only gripe is the text feature in my car - I would've hoped that with so many ford cars on the road the software developers would've found a way to make that work on the android side. I'm sure it's complicated, though.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Amazing deal. Great phone. I've recommended ordering it from Amazon to many of my friends and family that use Sprint. Ordering through Amazon: Worked seamlessly through my existing Sprint account. It sucked up one of my upgrades from our plan, and I got a disgustingly good deal on the newest generation of phone. A big thank you Amazon for being awesome and offering us such a good deal. The phone itself: Overall: It does all the normal 'phoney' things. So that's nice. Size: It is big, which makes it slightly cumbersome to handle with one hand. But for me, the extra screen size is worth it. Signal: For some reason my signal bar is typically lingering at 1 or 2 bars. This would normally concern me and make me give the "signal strength" a bad review. But wherever I go, I can still access the web/data and make phone calls like normal. So that's strange and seemingly concerning, but it doesn't end up effecting me... so I'm a little torn on that one. Features I actually use: *I use the finger print scanner to unlock my phone. So great! *I put a message on the lock screen that has a note with my friends phone number on it. Now if someone finds my lost phone, they'll have a way to return it to me. *I organize all my apps into folders from the home page. And put those fancy stock ticker widgets and weather widgets on the second page. *All the standard smart phone stuff, phone calls, pictures, texting, taking pictures, making videos. *I actually edited a video earlier with an app in there. Someone in the background called someone else fat during the video, so before I could upload it to facebook I had to crop out that section of the video, then merge two videos together. It processed all that pretty well and wasn't painfully laggy.

Tags: Powerful, thin ... if only it were rich!
Textual Messages: OK, I am not an expert on all things electronic and digital, but this is one seriously impressive phone. Read others for tech details, but be aware of this happy fact: it comes GSM enabled. Slip out the SIM card, slide in a GSM card and it is ready to play internationally (as long as you have an international plan in place). Bought as gift for family member who just returned from England. Wish we had bought it a year ago before the study-abroad year! Powerful processor provides lightning-fast downloads and uploads. Display is crisp, bright, and BIG. On-screen keyboard is larger than most and enables fewer input errors. Thin profile. Battery holds up well, considering the robust processing speed and large display. Practically plug and play. Activation was nearly hands-free, requiring only two response clicks. Excellent delivery time and value. Looking forward to a lot of fun with this phone. At time of purchase, this model was 50% of the price at the carrier's store, and came GSM equipped. If you had doubts about ordering your next mobile this way, dispel all worries and dive in. The experience has been completely positive, loads better than dealing with a salesperson face-to-face in a brick-and-mortar store.

Helpful: 2 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Upgraded to this from galaxy S3, so many improvements. I'm an extreme critique when it comes to everything, and this phone has minimum downsides. First off, I was tired of paying Sprint for phone insurance, because they wouldn't fix my S3 when it was obviously bugged and broken, even though I paid $11/month for a year and a half. That being said, I wanted to save $11 a month which adds up fast. Well luckily this phone is water resistant and known for being very strong. So I took a chance and bought this, never paid for insurance, and never will. Finally engineers had more influence than businessmen. Along with a Spigen case, this phone works perfectly after many big drops, spills, and even swimming with it. This is a big deal for anyone on a budget as you can save a lot by not buying insurance, where you might need it for other phones. Note it's not water proof so don't have it underwater for long periods of time, and take any case off after. As I left mine on, which trapped water underneath case, and phone glitched out for a few days, but returned to normal. The battery life is amazing, better than any phone I've ever seen or used. I know there are a few others recent phones with similar quality battery life, but the extreme power saver mode which I use if I'm near out of battery and don't have charger is extremely useful. Plus with the usb 3.0 charger, it's charges EXTREMELY fast, 20 minutes will get you a substantial charge. This also is nice for transferring pictures/movies to/from phone to computer. As an audiophile, the audio drivers are great and provide amazing sound to my high end earphones. The included equalizer has a simple mode and advanced mode which both work nice. It's nice not to need an additional app for that. Literally the only downside to this phone that I can think of is that the "drop down menu" does not include a mobile data toggle button. Which is extremely retarded of the software developers (May be an operating system flaw). Because along with Wi-Fi and location (gps) it is one of the few buttons I would use. I used a third party app to make a homescreen widget to do this, but why not include it in drop down menu like my old phone? After my S3 which I found a little big for my liking, the S5 which is even bigger doesn't annoy me size wise, it seems just right. If desired you can even shrink the screen for "one-hand" use. Conclusion: Get this phone, you won't be disappointed. - Sorry for long review, May it be helpful.

Tags: Great Phone with a few overlookable flaws
Textual Messages: Love this thing! The screen is absolutely spectacular. The colors are brilliantly amazing and clear. Watching videos on this thing is by far the best mobile video viewing experience I've had. I had an iPhone before and don't think i'll be going back. I love how this device allows you, with many different platforms, to intergrate everything you do; from your packages being delivered, calenders, S Health, Google Pictures, GMail, the list goes on. The one downside is the bluetooth module they put into their "flagship" phone is pretty weak. Considering it's Samsungs flagship device, I would've expected stellar specs across the board but the bluetooth is a bit lackluster. Another problem I have with it is that I have set all the apps and pretty much all my data as limited to Wifi only, but for some reason, the only time I get notified for updates is when I leave wifi. As much as I am over Apple and iTunes, I gotta hand it to them. The OS we beautifully simple and bug free. Unlike Samsung Andriod.

iPhone Killer, If you still have a iPhone, you are missing out. The Best S phone yet... I'm happy with this phone. And it is FAST.... And some thing phones should have had years ago and if you have a iPhone you will NEVER GET IT... Maybe on iPhone 50...lol No, I'm loving the camera for my "HAPPY SNAPS" I do have a high end camera but, tis one on the phone works GREAT. The S Health with the phone App is cool.... It has a thing to check you heart beat and a Pedometer. And a way to keep trace of your calories. And many other thing I have not started using yet. It is waterproof, I would not find out if it works. But many already have done it and have posted it to YouTube and it works GREAT.

Tags: It runs much nicer now but the battery life on both stock rom and CM11 suck. Ended up getting an extended battery yesterday so .
Textual Messages: So far it's ok. I got sick of the samsung software very quickly and put CM on it. It runs much nicer now but the battery life on both stock rom and CM11 suck. Ended up getting an extended battery yesterday so we'll see how that goes. Everything else is really nice. The camera and screen are great, very little memory as I was expecting the 3gb ram as originally intended in which i found out it only had 2gb again. It works though and a nice upgrade from my s3.

Tags: this is probably the greatest samsung phone so far but

I was duped into upgrading to this phone by sprint saying that it is a lot faster than my galaxy 3 and this phone has a better antenna than the 3 which will make my phone perform a lot faster. but if you have crappy service the phone can't perform as promised.
