Tags: It's nice, but some may question that
Textual Messages: Upgrading from a HTC EVO I was blown away by the options this phone has. Sadly Sprint's hit-and-miss cell coverage in various parts of Metro Phoenix, AZ leads me to deduct one star. I ultimately went to the GS4, as the cost for a new phone was $0.01 on Amazon, and as of the date of this review Sprint has an option to use Wifi calling; allowing the phone to text and call anytime with no restrictions if placed to domestic numbers. I did have problems with the Samsung fit application, it kept resetting causing the memory to delete. Also the pedometer was a tad bit sensitive as the steps would creep up as I had the phone sitting on the console of my car. I can't find anything wrong with this model except to say a fool like myself would break the screen quickly, thus I bought an Otterbox Defender Series to prevent my neanderthalish ways of causing damage to the phone; specifically the large screen.

Helpful: 2 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: It's a great device, without a doubt. After 2 successive HTC flagships on Sprint, I decided to join the masses with samsung. A power user, and rom geek, I've learned that the biggest user base gets all the development attention. And accessories. So it didn't take a lot of pondering. So far, the experience has been top notch. Everything you would expect from the top dog. Snappy response and a worthy platform for all that android supplies. My only whine? Better low light photography, please. I don't really care if it takes a higher ISO, larger aperture, or whatever. I'm ready for the Olympus Stylus or Yashica T4 of the Android universe to emerge!

I cannot complain. This is an amazing phone that has so many features. It's funny to see how many features they include on these little suckers. The S5 is super fast, easy to use, and most important, IT'S NOT AN IPHONE!!!

Tags: Good phone, waterproof is best feature
Textual Messages: I've had this for about a month now. Pretty good reception compared to other sprint phones we've had. I've been happy with the battery life and it charges quickly. I've been able to take some super nice photos with the camera. fingerprint sensor always works (except when wet). I could care less about the health apps + heartbeat sensor. I only really used a few of the 'app extras' that samsung bundled in, most are like a few months free premium access and then they want you to pay for continued use. Waterproof is great - i've had people asking what phone this is, i took it to hawaii and submerged it in hot tubs and the ocean, took video underwater of fish with it. The controls are difficult or not really able to be used under water. The headphone jack did get some gravel in it + was hard to clean, and while it was drying out it kept giving me the headphone notification which was annoying. I'm not giving it a 5 star because the phone still lags at times, probably samsung's software and other apps causing it, and the chrome band around it nicks pretty easily - they could have used tougher plastic for that. You should probably still get a screen protector or cas... somehow i managed to get a decent scratch on the gorilla glass, and that would also help the dents on the rim. All in all, i really like the phone, if you're on the verge, get it.

Tags: but this phone was still great for my son
Textual Messages: Even though every S5 is physically the same, the Sprint S5 will be different from the other carriers. Verizon phones are often unlocked, at least in part since the S4 came out. In other words, if you put a T-mobile Sim card or AT&T sim card in a Verizon phone you can make a phone call. However, data speeds will vary. In may area service with others carriers is a little bit stronger than it is on Sprint, but this phone was still great for my son. All S5's are water resistant. 3 feet, 30 mins. I can be under water really longer than that, but I would not recommend it! The great thing about Samsung is that you can stop by a best buy on Mon, Thur or Saturday for free classes also!. For those not use to the newer version of Samsung there is also a lot of videos under Samsung Mobile on youtube. However, all the how to for the S5 and Tab Pro (Same button set up) is under SamsungmobileUK not samsung mobile US or sammobile. Oh, I have been all over the US with this phone and it works great. Also the samsung people can do a software update for you in about 10 mins in a best buy store versus waiting an 30 mins to an hour to download an update at home! The only phone I used that was faster than the S5 was a note 4! Enjoy!

Tags: CANT USE VOICE AND DATA AT THE SAME TIME WITH SPRINT
Textual Messages: This phone is pretty sweet.. i switched from a s3 and fell in love with it. Problem is the Sprint network. You CANNOT use the phone (voice) with data (internet) at the same time. What does this mean? If you are using the GPS and you get a call the GPS will drop. IF you are on the phone and need to look at an email, you cant. If you want to look up something on the internet while talking on the phone you cant. This is finally the straw that broke this camels back.. I purchased this phone through best buy and then three days later took it back to BB and returned it. I have left Sprint and went to Verizon where you CAN talk and surf at the same time. Sprints says they will have this feature once they update to the Spark network but that it will take a while to reach all areas.. much like it did for 4g I have been with sprint for over 10 years now and they are always behind. I will miss unlimited data but I still have 2gigs to play with unlimited text unlimited talk at about the same price as before.

Helpful: 3 of 7 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I had a Samsung Galaxy S3 for 2 years and loved it. When I had the chance to upgrade I was read all the reviews and thought the S5 would be the best choice. I get the phone at BestBuy through Sprint service, paying the full price of the phone through their "Easy Pay" plan, and was at first happy with the speed, the functionality, and the features. Then I try to use the camera. A black spot in every picture. I look and under the camera glass is some particulate. Obviously something from the manufacturer since it's sealed under the glass. I contact Best Buy: Sorry, can't help you since it's been over 14 days. Go to the Sprint store. I go to the Sprint store in the mall: Sorry, can't help you here, you have go the OTHER Sprint store. The next day I go to the other Sprint store: Sorry, it's been 31 days so you have to contact the manufacturer. I contact the manufacturer by phone: We don't do replacements, you have to mail the phone to us at your cost, and we'll fix it and send it back to you. Leaving me without a phone for at least 4 weeks. I'll never get a phone from Sprint or Samsung again.

Tags: CAN'T TALK AND SURF AND THE SAME TIME! SPRINT IS DISPICABLE!
Textual Messages: Any Sprint Spark device like this (or the Note 4, etc.) does not allow voice calls and data at the same time (ie. you can not use navagation, surf the net, etc. when you are talking on the phone). Sprint should be ashamed for releasing something so poorly planned. I switched from AT&T with my old Samsung Galaxy S (before they even had a number following it) which worked with voice and data at the same surprise. Imagine my surprise when I "upgraded" to the S5 and changed to Sprint. I had the newest and "best" phone available, but I couldn't talk and surf (UNLESS I WAS ON WIFI!!!!!!!). After discovering this problem and the fact that it probably won't be fixed for a couple of years, I cancelled while within my grace period and went back to AT&T... Absolutely disgraceful and deceiving on Sprint's part. Why couldn't they give the customer this disclaimer up front??????

Helpful: 7 of 19 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Pros: Decent camera; great shots in daylight. Not so great in lower light. It does OK sending pictures, and once you find the picture file location, it's easy to grab and copy pictures. Removable battery. External memory extension slot. Cons: (so very many) Finger swipe security feature takes several swipes, and recent (May 2014) update will not lock the phone completely for 30 seconds after 5 swipes (Previously it force a password entry). Been trying for days to find a way to back up, but no go. Backups fail, restores fail, and doesn't sync well with outlook. Sync feature will lose data from phone to Outlook on a computer, particularly Contacts. Tasks are hidden within the calendar feature, making them all but useless. Backup will say "complete" but onlly phone log and alarm will actually back up. Samsung apps like S-Health will randomly erase all data, and apparently can't be downloaded. It takes several tries record a pulse (the sites will say, "don't press too hard" but I found I don't press hard enough). You're forced to sign up and share the data with Samsung, yet it keeps getting erased from my phone, and I can neither back it up nor restore it, despite having it set up to automatically back up every three hours. If you set up Picasa, you cannot delete pictures that have synced. Samsung's support is aggravatingly useless. The Kies software has options for synchronizing Tasks, but their support says it's not supported. Based on searching the Samsung site and other forums, along with using the Kies software, it's clear that the app isn't fully supported by Samsung itself, and they have no documentation at all, except basic "how to." If you try to get answers from them, they'll insist on getting carrier-specific model information because the phone is supposed different for each carrier. I have a hard time believing something so basic as Tasks is different. It will continually tell you the back cover is loose when it's clearly not. There are also multiple on=board apps for things; Samsung's brand, Google brand, and the amount of bloatware is insane. I regret buying this phone, and Samsung's responses to technical support requests have guaranteed I will not purchase another Samsung product again.

Tags: PHONE NOT WATER PROOF! AND IF FUALTY MERCHANDISE BREAKS, IT IS SAMSUNGS POLICY NOT TO REPLACE IT!
Textual Messages: If you want a phone that can break and when and when/if it does, there is no guarantee you can get it replaced, than this is the phone for you! I can talk about all the things on this phone that would be good features, but what does it matter if the phone is broken. What does it matter that the phone is supposed to be "water resistant" YOU CANNOT PUT THIS PHONE IN WATER!!!. If you close the phone properly and water still gets in, they will tell you that it was still your fault that it doesn't work. Because there in unfortunately and conveniently almost no way to prove that the phone stopped working due to faulty merchandise. I bought one of these and through my warranty plan replaced it for $200.00 when my first phone broke due to water damage. Then I got a second one, of which I had for about 3 days, before it broke too. that phone broke when I went swimming. I was in shallow water, and for a very short amount of time. I made sure that everything was closed securely on this phone before I went swimming due to previous experience. When this phone stopped working, I took it to a certified Samsung repair store. The phone failed the pressure test, proving that the faulty merchandise was in fact not "water resistant at all" they also said that the corrosion in the phone was irreparable. When I called corporate with these findings from their OWN store. They said it was not SAMSUNG POLICY to replace THEIR phones even the faulty ones. That replacement can ONLY be done through your phone service provider. EVEN THOUGH THE PHONE WAS ONLY IRREPAIRABLE BASED ON THEIR FAULTY MERCHANDISE TO BIGIN WITH! We tried going through our service provider to return this phone. They wanted us to give them another $200. We would not agree to this! We decided to cancel our service completely and go with another phone service. NO one wanted to give us a working phone, or our money back! They sent us a faulty phone and offered NO GARANTEE. This phone can and will sometimes break in water. IT IS NOT a WATERPROOF PHONE! They will not replace it should it become irreparable, EVEN IF IT IS THEIR FAULT!! Who wants to spends hundreds of dollars on any phone without any kind of guarantee the phone will work. IT IS SMASUNGS POLICY TO NOT STAND BY THEIR PRODUCTS. I am never buying anything Samsung again. AND not just because I am angry with how they "resolved" my issue. But also because I am concerned that I will have to deal with SAMSUNGS POOR POLICY and NO GARANTEES again! DONT BUY THIS PHONE!!!

Tags: Please be aware of the phone's compatibility
Textual Messages: It took me a while to figure this out. Those who plan to purchase an unlocked phone and intend to use it inside US please be careful. Most S5 models came with LTE capability, but not all of them are compatible with the US provider. For example: G900A is specific for AT&T, 900T is for T-Mobile etc. Some of them are interchangeable but you need to be aware of the compatibility. For example, 900F model (this one) supports LTE 850 / 900 / 1900 / 2100 (these numbers are actually frequency like in the radio channel), but AT&T provide LTE using 700. The reason I rated 4 is because I think they should provide more information like this to the customers.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Brilliant! Came in the box. Has a nice sticker over the side that states "Do not accept if seal is broken" Inside the box is a shiny new S5 SM-900FD phone with all the plastic still in place. Under that is the SN and ID data sheet / sticker... (don't loose). Under that a quick start guide. Below that you find the Charger (Euro), cables, earbuds and a Euro to US plug adapter for the charger. But since its basically a USB adapter any USB Phone charger 'should' work fine (check the voltages though). Some people seem to have been confused by the Euro charger. Im guessing the term "International" didn't quite hit home for them. The screen is untouched, the back is untouched and apart from the addition of the US adapter its a perfectly fine almost straight from the factory box. Just make sure you check the UPC on the box "Before" you break the seal. My only quibble is the packaging.. No kind of bubble wrap or shock material at all. The package was snug around the box so it didn't "bounce around" in the box. But there was little in the way of shock absorbing materials. UPS delivered the package un molested though.
That's ok with the product and delivery

The phone came in a sealed box and was definitely completely new. It was unlocked as expected, however branded to Vodacom (only noticable by the flash screen on startup). Not sure what that means for the warranty but I assume Samsung will honor their warranty no matter the original carrier. Since that is the only noticeable thing about it and it works fine with my SIM card, I don't care, but if it bothers someone, you'd have to root it to get rid of it. Another thing is that it came with an European charger and a cheap chinese adapter. I had some other Samsung chargers lying around, and bought it for Europe anyway, so I was happy about that. If you want to use it mainly in the US, you may want to get another Samsung charger. I used the phone in Dalvik for a while and noticed a significant improvement in speed after switching to ART. It turned hot briefly after the switch, but after that it ran smoothly and I had the feeling battery life improved also (although it was already great to begin with, it lasted 2+ days playing music, watching movies, using navigation plus mobile data and WIFI). I was at first worried that some apps would not run, but non of the apps had a problem, in fact, they almost uniformely ran better, except for the Kindle app which is incredibly slow for some reason and was from the beginning (did only try the Samsung version). Amazon music on the other hand runs perfectly. The design of the phone is beautiful, the colors of the screen are great and it is easily readable in bright sunlight. A joy to watch movies. I was also impressed with the sound quality of the included headphones. The camera makes great photos even in low light, and does not have the lag I had on my old phone. The front camera is gritty in low light, but that is to be expected. The fingerprint sensor works amazingly well. I have one on my HP laptop, and did expect the one on the phone would have the same problems with sweaty fingers, but it worked well even when I was biking. That said, it also works great as a phone ;). Overall, I'm very happy with this phone, and also with the seller. Delivery was speedy (arrived three days before the Amazon predicted date). I should mention that I got this phone from Top10Cell, since there are different sellers for this. As I said, Top10Cell was selling the African (Vodacom) model.
Good!!! A++++

Tags: Works on T-Mobile U.S.A (in depth network/phone review)
Textual Messages: Works with T-Mobile U.S.A I live near Seattle WA, unfortunately there is no 4G or LTE connection that is establishable and I get 3G and a very good HSPA+ connection with average Download speed of 22mbps and upload of 7mbps on 3G. 29mbps download and 11 uplaod on HSPA+. I have a Galaxy S3 LTE (T999L) version for T-mobile as well and I get 35mbps download and 15 upload on T-moblies 4G LTE network.There is not a big gap at all between the different network speeds, call quality and text messaging is liquid smooth, no complaints there. If your a big network buff then this shouldn't be a huge deal because I also did some testing with my Galaxy S3 and this Galaxy S5 side by side and the speed difference is usually a 1-2 second delay. The place where 4G and LTE outperform is when downloading and uploading big files, not small files like updates from the playstore etc. My advise is not to buy this phone based on network, rather on the phone itself, it is a amazing device and I highly recommend it to friends. Don't let things like network speeds that load your webpages 1 second slower get in the way from the amazing user experience that the phone itself has to offer. If you really want a good stable connection then switch to WiFi this phone has a killer network connection to Wifi it's super fast and very stable, mobile networks too. So whoever may be reading this review this is a fantastic phone the best i've had the privilege of having it works on T-mobile U.S.A and there is no noticeable network difference from a pure T-mobile device. So if you want a Galaxy S5 then i highly recommend this one because if you don't live in the U.S. then you may have 4G LTE. I have no complaints at all hands down best phone out there. I hope this helped anybody, and helps with your purchasing decision.

Tags: If you are buying this for use in any country ...
Textual Messages: If you are buying this for use in any country except the UK then be aware that warranty repairs are a total pain. This model is from the UK. We bought one and had a problem with the screen (vertical lines running through it). Samsung US won't fix it as they claim to use a different firmware load so we have to send it to the UK. Samsung UK won't accept it directly from the US (customs issues?) so we have to ship it to a friend in the UK ($35 each way for shipping and customs) who ships it to Samsung UK who repairs it under warranty who ships it back to our UK friend who ships it back to us. Once we get it back it will be a tough decision as to whether we keep it or sell it. UPDATE: We received the phone back from Samsung in the UK with a letter that reads: "Thank you for sending your mobile phone to us. James, one of our engineers at our approved service centre, has tested your phone and they have found that it is not working because your handset has been found to be of non European origin. Samsung products are covered by a regional warranty and therefore only protected by the warranty specific to that region. Our records indicate that your handset (Samsung SM-G900F (GS5) 16GB white) was originally manufactured and shipped outside of Europe and is therefore not covered by the European warranty. We would recommend that you contact your supplier from where you had purchased your handset to discuss the matter further. Kind regards, Samsung Electronics UK. So, despite giving the UK service center my phone's model number, IMEI and serial number BEFORE I sent it on a lovely journey to the UK and back, they returned it and denied that it was of European origin. I have spent countless hours with Samsung UK and US and neither can help me figure out exactly who will fix this problem under warranty. I bought it from a private party who purchased it from Amazon so my next call will be to Amazon to see if they can somehow help me.

Helpful: 400 of 410 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I got a chance to test a Galaxy S6 out and immediately bought one for my wife. I'm a complete phone nerd (XDA Developers Recognized Contributor, if that means anything to you) so I massively over analyze these things. It's a VERY nice phone but it's got some things that I consider drawbacks. For my wife, all the drawbacks listed below were non issues. She didn't care about these issues. So understand that my 'drawbacks' are completely subjective to your personal needs. But they are things that you should be aware of and consider if they mean anything to you before purchasing. ?????THE UPSIDES????? ? The screen is incredible. Like really incredible. The resolution is better than my eye can see. I use a Galaxy S4 as my regular phone and it has great resolution where you can't see individual pixels. I thought the S4 screen was as good as you can get, but the S6 screen takes it to a whole new level. Even though you can't see pixels on either screen, the higher resolution of the S6 screen makes everything look so sharp that it's nearly impossible to tell you are looking at a screen. It's that incredible. ? The design of the phone just feels more 'expensive'. I mean that in a good way. It feels just higher quality than previous models in the Galaxy S line. The S3 and S4 for example are often critiqued for having a plastic shell. The S6 has a metal band around the outside that just makes it feel 'premium' in your hand. It should also provide more protection for the device as well. ? TouchWiz is HEAVILY scaled back. I hate TouchWiz (Samsung's version of Android) It adds a layer of UI that is neither helpful nor intuitive. And it's a resource hog which slows the phone down for important tasks just so it can make the scrolling smoother, and other such useless tradeoffs. On the S6 TouchWiz was barely noticeable. The UI looks more like the standard Google Android Lollipop interface. It was all just much smoother and simpler and better and wonderful. ? Camera. 16 MP. And the images it takes look stunning on the super HD screen. Those photos on a larger high resolution monitor are simply stunning. ?????THE DOWNSIDES????? ? The battery is not removable or easily replaceable. A cell phone battery has a life of about 500 charge cycles. I tend to keep my phones for 2 years as daily users, then I keep my old phones for a variety of other purposes around the house. (My old HTC Sensation is hooked up to my stereo for use as a nice wifi streaming media player with a touchscreen UI, for example) I eventually have a need to replace batteries because I wear them out. I like being able to go on Amazon, spent $20 on a replacement battery, pop it in and be done. Additionally, even if you don't keep your phones that long, batteries fail sometimes. The stock batteries on the Galaxy S4 had some problems. They were minimal, but for those affected the battery absolutely had to be replaced. On the S4 it took 8 seconds and the problem was solved. On the S6 I'm sure it would be covered by warranty but it'd be a pain to take it somewhere to have it worked on should the issue come up. So no replaceable battery is a deal killer for me. This might not be an issue for you. If not, great! But be aware of the issue before making purchase decisions. ? You can't expand the storage with an SD Card. I don't want to live in the cloud. I hate the cloud. Sometimes I'm not on an LTE network. Sometimes I'm in the middle of nowhere but still want to show someone pictures of my kids. I got my wife the 32GB model. That sounds like a lot, but keep in mind that some of that is dedicated for the operating system and user apps. So you don't get to use all 32GB. The S6 is going to be available in up to 128GB, which ends my problem with not liking the cloud option. Again, you might not care. If not, great! My wife doesn't keep a lot of stuff on her phone. She moves all her pictures to her computer and never loaded video to watch on her phone, so the storage thing wasn't a big deal to he

Textual Messages: the Galaxy s6 is the best phone that has released this year. Here's why: -screen resolution : Samsung has updated the screen resolution from full hd(1080p) to qhd (1440p or 2560*1440) so the screen now is much sharper than before. -finger scan : the finger scan is much improved over the previous model , now you only have to tap or hold the button like the iPhone 5s and 6/6+. Previously you have to swipe the button to get verified , a lot of time is wasted and uncomfortable doing this way assuming you're using it a lot . -battery life : the battery life is not much improved than the previous model , but it is enough to get you through the day . -the build: the build is now really a big update since the s4. It is now much thinner at 6.8mm thick and it has metal frame so it feel really good in the hand just like holding a premium phone as it is tend to be. It is also lighter from 145to 138 g due to its thickness , so you feel now more comfortable in the hand . -camera : the camera remains 16 megapixel like the previous model , but that doesn't mean it is like the previous model . Samsung has updated the sensors and pixel size so you can make better shots and better 4k video!! The processor : the processor is also updated with Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex-A57, but this wasn't much of a problem as the previous model already ran pretty fast The sacrifices& conclusion : Samsung did sacrifices some awesome features from last year in order to get this phone done . Like removable battery and water resistance , but without these features galaxy s6 is still the best phone on the market as for now !!

Helpful: 12 of 12 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I’m going to start this review with full disclosure: I am more of an Apple guy than an Samsung guy. So, this review has the potential to a little biased. With that said, I did try to maintain an objective opinion about this phone and used it daily for a couple of weeks before writing this review. Design If design were the only criteria for this review, the Samsung Galaxy S6 would get 5 Stars. However, it seems that Samsung was ‘inspired’ by the iPhone 6 design and I’m a big fan of that style. In all fairness to Samsung, this is not a cheap knockoff of an Apple product. The phone feels nice in your hand and it is well made. One thing that I dislike about the S6 is how large the camera lens area is on the back of the phone. I tend to have my index finger in that area when making a call and it makes the S6 feel more bulky than it actually is. Screen The screen on the S6 is lovely. It’s main display resolution is 2560 x 1440 (Quad HD), which compares to the iPhone 6 with 1334×750 Retina HD display. Its color is very bright and is definitely on par with the iPhone 6 in my opinion. I found the touch screen to be responsive and saw no performance issues while using the phone throughout the day. Camera I hate to admit it, but I think this phone in general takes more crisp pictures than my iPhone 6. Sometimes more megapixels and the quality of the image sensor matter and it looks like Samsung found a nice paring for the S6. The Galaxy S6’s camera has an impressive 16MP, while the iPhone 6 has an 8-megapixel iSight camera. Software Because this is the latest and greatest hardware from Samsung, it runs comes equipped with Android 5.0 – Lollipop. It’s important to point out that the phone used for this review was a Verizon device. So, this was not stock Android. However, after personally experiencing some nightmares with bloatware installed on Verizon phones, I can honestly say it is not too bad on the S6. The one thing that did irritate me is that the default messaging app is Verizon Messenger. But, this can, of course, be changed. I have read online that it is possible to install stock Android on the Verizon S6 if one desired to do so, but we did not test this. Using the S6 The S6 was pretty intuitive. If you have used Android before, it will be easy to find your way around because the bloatware is limited and the nuts and bolts are pretty similar to a stock Android experience. Call quality was great and I experienced no issues with connection speed on WIFI or Verizon 4G. Final Thoughts If you’re in the market for a new Android phone, the Samsung Galaxy S6 is probably one of the best Android phones on the market right now. It’s fast and offers a solid alternative to Apple’s iPhones. This product was received at a free or discounted price in exchange for this review. I am a technology journalist and pride myself on providing fair and honest reviews. Please feel free to ask any questions you might have.

Textual Messages: First of all this is an reasonably good phone. The reason i gave it two stars is for many reasons one of which is because the battery life is terrible. I have uninstalled most of the pre-installed apps and disabled the bloatware i cannot uninstall. Additionally the screen brightness is low and all automatic updates are turned off. I charge my phone to 100% unplug it and go to sleep in the morning sometimes it is as low as 40% remaining. In addition to having to recharge it in the morning i have to charge it again at around 2-3pm to ensure it lasts till i get home at night. The second problem i have is that the OS takes up 1.2GB of ram the apps which i have on the phone with isnt many, it is mostly mail clients. Take up another 1GB leaving only 600mb of ram free, I can easily see this phone slowing down quickly in future android updates that would eventually utilize more of the available ram. If you have the S5 there is no need to upgrade to this phone.

Helpful: 20 of 26 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Admittedly I actually have the t-mobile version, which does automatically unlock 45 days after purchase and as far as I know should be the same as this version. Since I make the vast majority of purchases on Amazon, I thought I would share my initial thoughts on the phone here as well Samsung went and did it, no more "plastic is stronger than glass" or "Apple fans are wall-huggers" commercials from them! Pros: -For those who care, this phone has terrific build quality, and both looks and feels great in my hand -Excellent camera, probably the best Android phone camera to date -Display is just beautiful -Hardware, this will likely be the only none Snapdragon 810 flapship this year, that combined with Samsung's other hardware advantages gives this phone the fastest SOC, memory, and harddrive on the market. Mediocre: -Samsung supposedly made removing bloatware easier, you can just click on anything with a (-) sign to "remove it". but for a lot of the real bloatware both from samsung and other companies, this only disables the useless apps. So in the end Samsung made disabling bloatware easier, but not really removing them. -Back camera protrudes quite a bit. Cons: -the LED lights to the "return" and "multitask" buttons to the left and right of the home button cannot be controlled. this may seem like a small issue, but they light up for about 1.5 seconds EVERYTIME you touch the screen, it is a minor annoyance during the day and a major issue at night. Not to mention this wastes battery. I hope this will be fixed with a software update soon. -Battery-life is mediocre at best. This phone will last you through the day as long as you're not playing games or watching movies, and only write a moderate number of emails. Samsung wasn't lying when they said this phone charges fast, so for those of us who have a desk job this isn't a problem, but if you're outdoors all day you should carry a back up battery -that reminds me, did I mention no more removable battery and microSD? I didn't but other people did? good enough Comments: I don't understand the obsession with making a phone thinner every year, especially when a camera sensor need to protrude significantly to capture a nice image. Honestly this phone could've been perfect for me if it was 2mm thicker, without the protruding camera, and had approximately double the battery life (2mm thicker is enough space for it)

Helpful: 9 of 11 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: For Verizon edition. Read plenty of online reviews about the Edge before preordering it, most mentioned the "gimmick" that is the curved screen because of lack of functionality. To my mind this is a little like saying flat panel computer monitors were a gimmick because they did everything a CRT did -- they showed the picture, after all, they were just skinnier. "All show, folks, nothing here to see, move along" Not so much. Now, what is a gimmick is the software that has been developed in order fend off complaints that the curved screen's real-estate isn't used efficiently. Edge contacts? Not all that essential or useful. Edge notifications? Same deal. What is really impressive is the effect the curved screen has on my viewing experience. One reviewer on another site wrote "gives the disturbing impression that the screen is falling away from me." I balked at this because my experience is precisely the opposite, specifically that the screen is rising up to me. I hesitate to call it a 3D experience because that cheapens a true 3D display through something like MagicLeap, but it truly gives the impression that the screen has depthbecause, well, it does. This is particularly noticed when using "carousels" to swipe through items on mobile websites & apps, e.g. Netflix. The items roll up one side of the screen then off the other to produce a more immersive experience. Same can be said about scrolling on Web pages while in landscape mode. Another cool/useful effect is when watching videos the "edge" is blacked out preventing distortion of the image but also provides a little extra screen space for widescreen movies. Also when swiping down to check notifications/battery life the notification & progress bar make use of the edge; in effect using less screen space & obscuring less of the video. The QHD display is also excellent with no pixellation visible under a hand lens. Enough about the screen. Processor & RAM make Android 5.0 run like a dream. I owned an S5 before picking up this gem & seriously regretted updating to Lollipop because the S5 just didn't handle it well -- abominable battery life, laaaaag, & it required multiple restarts through the day. None of these problems are evident on the S6. Battery life is good, but not excellent. Can stream videos for about six hours before it needs to be charged & survives a typical day with intermittent usage for ten to twelve hours. The real improvement here is the inclusion of wireless charging. I decided to forego the add-on backplate/battery for the S5 so I picked up a few wireless charging options this go around & I'm thrilled with the functionality. I have one in my car, on the end table, the bedside table & my desk. The convenience of being able to just drop/dock-&-go cannot be overstated & as a result my battery is seldom below 70%. The only improvement I can imagine is if they could figure out how to make my body a wireless charger. TouchWiz is a bit of a let-down, but not significantly so. It is stripped down so I'm not completely inundated with an UI that had the feeling of being added to with each iteration to "improve" it, as if adding every spice in the cupboard makes for a better soup. The app drawer is my biggest irritation because it is entirely inconvenient. Newly installed apps are added to the end of the list but apps can be sorted into alphabetical order by touching the A-Z at the top of the list. Now why is this irritating? First, it needs to be done each time you install an app. Second, while you can customize the app list to include your most frequently accessed apps on the first page so you don't have an entire screen dedicated to app icons that should properly be housed in the app drawer, the customization process is poorly designed, unintuitive & languid in end-user implementation. Third, after spending a great deal of time customizing the first page of the app drawer the next time you want to sort your apps alphabetically you lose all of your customizati

Helpful: 6 of 7 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I cannot give this phone high enough praise. It is a beautifully designed device, easily handles even the most demanding apps, and has more features than I will ever use. The reduced Touchwiz interface is a joy to use, and greatly improved over previous versions. I can say without a doubt this is my favorite phone I've ever owned. I do want to note that this is an international version. As such I was surprised, though I shouldn't have been, to discover upon opening that I'd received the Italian version of it. This means the manual and the wall charger are both the Italian versions, too. The seller was kind enough to include an EU to North American adapter so I can plug it in. Initial setup was a breeze, with language selection being one of the first screens upon powering it up. The utilities folder was still named instrumenti, but aside from that localization switched entirely to English without any problems. I read a different review that said they got the French version, so it seems there's no way to know what you'll get until you get it. I still think it's an excellent product and well worth carrying an adapter around with me since my carrier doesn't sell the S6 yet. Five stars!

Textual Messages: 7:28 0:00 This video is not intended for all audiences. What date were you born?  Submit Adobe Flash Player is required to watch this video. Install Flash Player I bought the Samsung Galaxy S6 directly through Verizon. Myself and my family tend to be Samsung users - smartphones, tablets, camcorders, Blueray players... so yes, I do have Samsung loyalty, yet I have to say the non-expandable internal memory is a bit of a bleah. I purposely got the 32GB as a) I am not one to fill up memory (never have been) and b) the extra hundred bucks for a 64GB seems ludicrous. Initial available memory is at approximately 22GB after all the updates... and the updates just keep coming, day in, day out. Some you can remove completely (if its listed under the APP windows, you can), rest you can disable, yet at times I have noticed there are ones that will suddenly re-activated and download the updates again. I have had this issue with my Samsung Tab 3 10.1", too. When you plug the S6 into a PC (mine is Win 8.1 64Bit), you should be prompted to download and install a handler program for PC/S6 data transfers. I did get a very odd error though with some Amazon music tracks I transferred this way - standard MP3 format, but for some reason an error popped up as corrupted files. These were from two specific album collections (Instrumental Beats), yet the other album collections play fine. I can only assume it had something to do with the Samsung transfer software since I have the same tracks on multiple other Android devices, and never seen that error before. This can get quite warm with prolonged use. It gets a bit uncomfortable to the hand if no case is on. I currently use a UAG military-drop case, so it's no longer an issue. Strong, quick Bluetooth connections. Has NFC pairing - something I only discovered today while exploring the settings. Cool! The camera is great, of course, and the included photo editor is as robust as many Android Photo Editor I have evaluated. Fantastic display - fairs very well even in direct, bright sunshine. No problems with phone audio. I have to scratch my head in perplexity over other reviews say terrible reception. I can only guess it's a carrier-to-carrier issue? As for the "bending" complaint, that one also puzzles me. Yet I do have mine in a case, so perhaps that is the needful thing. Contact list includes Auto-Reject (something I had really wanted on my last phone) 4G support of credit card transactions. Has made my laptop home-visit repairs a better, more assured experience. ;) The aspect I personally love the most is the wireless charging - that is a pretty big plus in my book. The batter can dwindle relatively quickly, but by surrounding my self with wireless QI charging options (home, car travel, even a wireless charging power bank), it really is a moot thing. Standby time is strong; Samsung does shine in that respect. I hadn't known about the non-replaceable battery until after purchase... not sure how I feel about that. All in all, it's the slight doubt about only going with 32GB that bothers me, and I will burn the non-replaceable battery aspect bridge when I come to it down the line. Aside from that, I am quite pleased with this.

Textual Messages: Wow, what a difference a year makes. While last year's S5 took many steps in the right direction(being somewhat waterproof with better material and craftsmanship), it still wasn't there to make it a mouth-watering phone yet, like what HTC did when they first introduced their One M7, or whenever Apple introduces a new iPhone size. This year, Samsung has finally learned from both of their competitors, and made a phone that has all the good qualities of both, plus some of their own. Finally, this is the Galaxy S that you've always wanted and been dreaming of. * The very first thing you notice when you handle the phone, is its new design and form factor - finally Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful. The metal fully wraps around the edges ofthe phone. The back is beautiful, the sides are beautiful - heck, even the buttons are beautiful. It feels great in the hand, and oozes style and sophistication. * The very next thing you notice, of course, is the screen. I am continually pleasantly surprised at the evolution of Samsung's AMOLED technology - it has now became the best screen in the industry, hands down. I used to defend the LCD technology of the HTC M7, and at that point it was in fact overall superior to the Samsung S4 because the AMOLED then had issues in the sun, and color reproduction(it was too saturated and not natural). But now, they have fixed those issues, and the S6's screen is just quite simply the best. If you don't believe it, just compare an LG/Samsung OLED TV to any LED TVs today. I still think 5.1 inches for a screen of a PHONE is still too big, but overall, for what smartphones represent nowadays, it is acceptable - we have conditioned ourselves to accept the bigger sizes of smartphones(I remember when I first held a 4.2" smartphone when it first came out - the HTC HD2 - and thought, "what the h3ll is this monstrosity??"). * It doesn't hurt that Samsung boosted up the resolution to 1440 x 2560 pixels, which is approximately 577 ppi in pixel density. Although this is quite overkill right now, it's always nice to have the latest and greatest technology - that's the reason why we buy these overpriced phones in the first place, isn't it? It is also very bright, and sunlit legibility is excellent. Color reproduction is quite accurate, and like the S5, you can choose different color modes to suit your liking. * An important aspect to discuss is the battery life, now more than ever because there is no removable back cover to make replacing the battery easily like before, not to mention there is no microSD slot for you to add memory space to your phone. Comparatively, the S6 Edge is supposed to last a little less than the S6 regular, which I've read is less than last year's S5. But I'm one of those who are always around a charger, and I always carry external battery packs in my backpack when I travel, so that's never a concern. Seriously, who even buys an extra battery anymore - which you can only use for a single specific phone model - when your external battery can charge ANY and ALL phones and tablets?? This scenario only makes sense if your work is so demanding that you don't have extra time to charge the phone, and need to swap batteries IMMEDIATELY. I don't think that scenario is realistic nowadays when external batteries are so small, light, and cheap. My S6 goes from 100% at 10 am to about 20% at 10 pm with moderate use - so no complaints there. I get home, plug it up, and there are no issues. * What's better this year, is the wireless charging standards are already built into the phone, so you can just buy a charging pad for about $50 and feel even more cool. * The missing microSD expansion issue is a legitimate concern, since everyone loves to store their music, videos/movies, and all their apps in their phones. Now, you have to be selective and choose what to include or not. But I also have

Helpful: 2 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: The first thing you will notice about the new Samsung S6 is that is weighs much less than it's predecessor. It just feels much more comfortable in the hand. Secondly, the screen looks much crisper and cleaner than the S5's although both have very good displays. Other main changes: The power button on the right hand side has been lowered down so it naturally sits where your thumb is most likely to be. The finger scanner is now press and not swipe. This makes it a much more accurate and quicker too. Whilst you lose the waterproofing, the annoying charge cover is gone, as is the wider charging port (if you have the wider charging cable you can't use it!). The speaker has been moved to the bottom and is much much more powerful. I was really surprised by how big the sound is from this. The battery is now sealed and the back cannot be removed. Whilst this is a slight nuisance, in the long run it will benefit users by making the lifetime of the battery longer. No Micro SD card slot. That's right. This is the most annoying feature of this phone and if you bought the 32GB model you will probably run out of space sooner or later. There are some external micro USB memory sticks out there though so all is not lost. Gorilla glass is now sported on the back too, which also happens to be a finger print magnet because of it. Fast charging! It really does charge fast now which is an absolute godsend. Wireless charging. Yup, if you buy the wireless charging pad that is. 8 cores, 64bit. Okay, so the more obvious differences aside, the phone has benefitted from a much better camera which actually does take great pictures that are noticeably better than the previous model. The extra screen pixel density also allows you to squeeze more out of your home screens. Talking of the home screen, it feels much more responsive too, gliding between screens much quicker and smoother. In my particular model the app tray doesn't feature a way to sort the apps so that is a minor niggle that will no doubt be fixed in the future but it is a surprising oversight. So, overall this is a really great piece of kit from Samsung who seem to have really made an effort this time around. The previous model seemed to be more about cramming in new features instead of making a really great phone. Everything about this feels well engineered, thinner and more ergonomically tuned. I really was annoyed about the memory and battery but after having the phone for a mere 24 hours I am absolutely sold.

The Samsung Galaxy S6 is intended for any smartphone customer who is looking for a new phone with the latest technology. When I reviewed this product I took into consideration the durability, camera, resolution of the screen, storage, size, price, and battery. I compared this phone to its leading competitor, the iPhone 6s. At the end of the day I give this phone a 4 out of 5 rating. After purchasing my Samsung Galaxy S6 in April, I immediately put a case on it. I haven’t had any issues with the durability for the short time I have owned it, but it is tough to justify with a case on it. The camera offers a 16 MP primary camera and a 5 MP secondary while the iPhone 6s offers a 12 MP primary and a 5 MP secondary camera. The display has been phenomenal and offers a 577 ppi (pixels per inch) which blows away the competition in this category. The iPhone 6s is at 326 ppi which is far below the Samsung Galaxy S6. The price of the Samsung Galaxy S6 is a competitive price when comparing it to other newer smartphones. The battery has been a slight letdown for me because it hasn’t allowed me to get a full days use out of it. Also the battery is non-removable which I see as a negative because you can’t buy back up batteries to replace your dead battery. The positive in the battery of the Samsung Galaxy S6 is the fast charging the phone offers. This phone charges fully in 1.48 hours which is the fastest 0 to 100% charge any smartphone offers. This phone offers quick processing and high quality components at a reasonable price. I didn’t give this phone a 5 out of 5 because of the battery, but the fast charging element makes up for the non removable battery. I would recommend this phone to anyone who is in the market for a new smartphone because of the exceptionally high quality components of the Samsung Galaxy S6.

Brilliant device! This is the finest phone I have ever seen... period... end of story. As so many other people and reviewers from various magazines have said the screen is stunning... the highest resolution I have ever seen or need to see! I have the 32 gig model, plenty of storage for me despite the device lacking a micro SD card slot. Given that could storage is so prevalent today the lack of a slot isn't much of a player. The tech specs on this device are top shelf and blow me away (note: I work for a HUGE competitor and this phone tops what we offer...). It's beyond capable for the average user and even techno geeks! I've seen a ton of reviews claiming the need for a skin because both sides of the thing are glass and will get covered with fingerprints within seconds... WRONG! The glass is oleophobic... it repels oil and, thus, fingerprints. I can't get a print on it to save my life! Now, there IS an issue with glass on both sides, at least for me... it's SLIPPERY! Regardless of which side is down the phone wants to run away. Park it on a sofa and, like water would, it heads for the low point. It's hidden itself from me on a couple of occasions leaving me a bit tweaked at myself for sitting it where I did. So, a skin might help in that regard. The camera is the best I've ever seen on a phone. The 16 megapixel sensor means fantastic resolution on photos and allows for remarkable poster size images should you want to get them printed. It has an f1.9 lens and that does mean less depth of field but, hey, it's phone... not a DSLR. I"m very impressed with the bells and whistles, though. Burst mode is fabulous. Hold down the on-screen button and it captures as many images as you would like... select the one you like most and dump the others! Also, it has a 'virtual shot' mode that allows you to position an item and move the phone around it in a circular fashion to produce what is, in effect, a 3D tour of the subject. Video is shot in true HD with results that rival my JVC... nice. Now, you need to take this with a grain of salt. I know our company's devices extremely well and now I know the S6 really well. Most likely other phone have similar features but I'm not aware of them. What I DO know for sure is that it's tough to beat this phone out.. end of story. If you're thinking about getting an S6 do it... the device is over the top!

Helpful: 2 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I am evaluating the Galaxy S6 920F through a narrow lens. We upgraded to Galaxy S6s from Galaxy S2s, and until now, we have purchased our phones on contract through AT&T as our carrier. We bought two phones through Amazon (Tek Deals). The phones arrived on time and in sealed boxes with a separate two prong European to US power adapter that fits on the European round pin charger. In both phones, the adapter fit too loosely over the European pins, and appeared unable to stay connected with any kind of minor jostling of the cord. Fortunately, the adapter was easy to take apart and I used a pair of pliers to squeeze the spring clip legs together, which easily fixed the problem. Of course, the adapter does make the charger stick further out. Our old S2 chargers will work, but the charging rate is lower, because they are only 1A chargers, rather than the standard 2A fast charger that comes with the S6. We took the phones to our local AT&T carrier store, and obtained SIM chips; I was pleased that the SIMs and switch over was free ( at least in our area). Coming from the Galaxy S2 to the S6 constitutes a big uptick in speed of everything, from downloading to app loading and operation. The screen is not only larger, but as expected, much sharper. We downloaded the Samsung Smart Switch mobile apps to the new and old phones to transfer as much information as possible. The app worked great. Google accounts transferred seamlessly, but some other accounts manually updating the username and passwords. Of course, all the wifi routers passwords had to be added manually. One feature missing on the phone, which apparently exists on US carrier branded phones, is the ability to alphabetically arrange apps with a one button click. At this time, apps are organized by when they were downloaded. App reorganization is a manual operation that can take quite a bit of time. I was used to seeing 4G/LTE on the notification panel on our old branded S2s, but on the 920F, only "4G" shows up. This worried me, despite researching that the necessary channels for 4G/LTE are active on the phone. From reading, and I believe, editing out misinformation on some sites, the international version only shows "4G", which is "4G/LTE". As noted by others, updates seem to just keep coming over a couple of days, but compared to an S2, the updates happen several times faster. The phone is slippery; wife already dropped hers once, and it was only one day old! Fortunately, no damage. New case will help. A concern, like for others, was battery life. It is often very difficult to compare usage from other users, who too often complain about battery life, without a hint about their usage. We live around 1/4 mile from the nearest cell tower, which is line of site, so 4G communication is quite good. Our wifi routers are generally within 50 ft of where the phones are used in our multilevel home. Wifi is used on an intermittent basis for updates or adding apps or heavy browsing sessions, to ensure staying under our carrier plan data cap. I am definitely a low level user, checking weather several times a day, reading and composing a few messages a day with or without attachments, an occasional email, and taking several camera shots a week. Syncing is set to automatic. I do not listen to music on the phone, or watch videos during the test periods. I may average a couple of calls a day. I may use a browser several times a day in either 4G/LTE mode or wifi. There were a number of updates or apps downloaded during the test measuring periods.. With power saving mode activated, I monitored my average battery usage over several charges. After 32 hrs battery reserve was down to ~65 %. Somewhere between 46 hrs to 67 hrs, battery reserve was 53%-56%. A worst case was leaving wifi on for about 10 hours, which drained the battery to 65% capacity in 23 hrs with minimal use (mianly overnight). Obviously, as a low level user, close to a cell phone tower and wifi routers, these values represent a minimal

Helpful: 2 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Oh, Another year 2015. Another set of phones from manufacturers! I have been hooked onto get the latest phone every year syndrome and love reviewing specifics. Disclaimer, I love Android and have been using from very early days. Samsung Galaxy S6 tries to be a revolutionary, but it is evolutionary. If you have an older phone more than 2 years old, absolutely get this. So do check local specs. I played around with both S6 and S6 Edge for few days and my opinions are based on this. There are tons of reviews going into lot of details, so I am focused on few other aspects like what’s out there and how to compare specs. First Big Changes: No microSD or removable battery. I know many of you loyal Samsung fans says BUMMER! I was a die hard fan of Samsung till S4, then I went to LG G2/G3. I think this is the best bet for S6 to pull it off after a dismal year for Samsung last year. I was very curious to try out S6 and HTC One M9 as they are most talked about now. Many manufacturers are going away from microSD card slots and this is absolutely a must and is a key differentiator from iPhone. I am really sad Samsung decided to drop microSD card slot as well as no removable battery. Why?! Screen is a beauty on S6 – Just Gorgeous. Just go to a retail store and feel it! The Edge feature is still gimmicky. Unlike Note Edge, this has both sides so less dorky but still I am not sold yet. Unless you have loads of money, I will shy away from it for one more year and get it next year when they polish it up. It is certainly fancy and nice to show off, but I would rather buy an Android wear watch like Motorola 360 or Samsung Gear or LG R series. I like Motorola 360 but waiting for version 2 to appear. I like Round watches. IF YOU HAVE LAST YEAR model of any phone, PLEASE DON’T upgrade. Phones are becoming so standard and power packed it makes no sense to upgrade and waste money every year. I buy and sell so many phones as it is like a hobby for me, but I stick to one phone as primary for couple of years now. My main requirements are a 128 GB microSD, good screen, battery life and performance. I am trying hard to see if I can live without one. S6 and S6 Edge comes in a 128 GB variant and I will wait for prices to stabilize on this model. In my opinion, following are key specs to consider when you buying a phone. Most of others are standard or does not matter at all. First size, weight and resolution are part of look and feel. RAM/CPU part of performance. external Storage is part of expandability. Camera is obvious! SAR (Specific Absorption Rating) is an often ignored, but I feel essential to making a buying choice. Manufacturers don’t advertise or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S6: 5.65 x 2.78 x 0.27 in, 138 gm, 1440 x 2560 pixels, 5.1 in, 577 ppi, 3 GB RAM, NO MICROSD SLOT (bummer), Internal Storage upto 128 GB, Exynos 7420 Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex-A57, Gorilla Glass 4, 16 MP/5MP camera, SAR 1.15 W/kg (head), 1.16 W/kg (body) NANO SIM Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge: Slightly lower dimensions, 0.01 in thicker, 6 gm less weight, Same resolution, Curved Screen, HTC One M9: 5.69 x 2.74 x 0.38 in, 157 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 3 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 20.7 MP (rear), 4 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 810, Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2 GHz Cortex-A57 Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G3: 5.76 x 2.94 x 0.35 in, 149 gm, 2560 x 1440 pixels, 5.5 in, 538 pp

After trying my hand on everything from symbian to ios to windows phone to android, I was not going away from android any time soon.In terms of hardware also I have tried them all and the only problem with android phones was that they were kind of ugly.Then came this phone.They have been calling it the best android phone ever and I can even dare say its the best value you can get for a phone presently.I really don't have anything remotely down the negative side from my experience of 2 weeks.some say the battery wont last long,its as good as any other phone I had and its definitely not super but 12 hours average with normal usage is enough for me (and using the power saving mode can squeeze out a couple of extra hours).Another thing that some people may find a negative is non expandable memory, well again atleast for me 32 gigs is pretty cool and you always can dump stuff on your computer and the cloud (dropbox,google drive,onedrive so on..).Paying for storage (its the cheapest component in any device) in not something anyone should be doing (unless you are a corporation). I will be surprised if any phone in the near future will be able to beat this one in terms of value.

I purchased the S6 from Tmobile since they were giving away a full YEAR of Netflix along with it as an incentive. I'm sorry I did, and for one reason only: Poor Battery Life. I've been using smartphones for many years as an early adopter. My first smartphone was the Treo 600, which I began using the day Sprint introduced it. Over the years I've used them all, and each year they get thinner, and the batteries get smaller. I cannot go a full day with this phone without plugging it in, and this is after TWO updates from Samsung, via Tmobile, to address battery life issues. It's a shame, because this is an amazing phone. But if the battery dies, its not a phone at all--It's just a lump in your pocket that has no value whatsoever. People I've spoken with make the same complaints about their Iphones, the problem is even worse with them. I'm going to get a new phone just as soon as I can find one with a big battery, perhaps a Blackberry Passport, which supposedly has very long battery life.

Works with T-mobile in the US and works with swedish sim-cards. Got a European charger, and a small adapter for US/JP. The device is very good looking compared to the other phones in the Galaxy S family. The fingerprints on the back however are easy to spot. But that is probably because i chose the Black color, the other ones probably won't have that issue. The biggest downside is the non-removable battery, which means in about 2-3 years when the battery turns into s***, you'll need to send it in to samsung or whatever for a replace. Not being waterproof like its predecessor and not being able ot use an SD-card sucks too. But i can live with that. It feels good in the hand, but is a bit slippery, especially if you put it on your lap etc. but a good phonecase will solve that issue. Right now i have the Neo Hybrid case from Spigen. It keeps the metallic look of the bumper and has a textured back for grip.

Samsung Galaxy S6 SM-G920F 32GB (Factory Unlocked) 5.1" - International Version - Black I bought this phone to use for Straight Talk and it works perfectly and the transfer only took like 20 minutes. Everything works and everything was included in the box that should have been included. My phone was not working at first and I was about ready to go ballistic. Googled the problem, troubleshooted, fixed in like 5 minutes. Bought from DeltaMobiles and the phone arrived early and tamper sticker was still intact. It doesn't say I have 4G LTE on my phone but its going as fast as my old phone that said 4G LTE so its working for me. Impressed with the phone and the updated OS. Camera is insanely good and the video is awesome. The screen is so beautiful I cry. Loving the phone so far.

After almost 1 hour of driving in heavy traffic and searching for parking, I was only told by the girl in front desk that they do not service international model. After that, I called customer center and asked what to do, the girl simply give a simple instruction to turn on the phone on safe mode, then promised me to call back within an hour, which has never arrived. After I called second time and repeating my phone's problem, I was given another ticket number and told that a technician will call me within 24 hours. Again it did not arrive. I will never buy a Samsung products in any kind. It is not surprise Samsung company profit and stock value went to record low. I just bought a Chinese made P7, which is much better in quality although the hardware is not better than S6. But the price I paid is only half of what Samsung and service I am getting is way better experience. So long, Samsunk!

Textual Messages: The galaxy s6 edge is everything you could ask for in a phone. I bought this phone after being an iPhone user for 3 years. I was looking for something new and the galaxy edge did not disappoint. It comes in three colors black, gold, and white with two versions the regular one and the edge version. The basic model starts with 32gibs with a price of 699. The new slim design sets apart from any other phone. You will get attention anytime you pull it out. It fits in any type of life style. If you’re looking for a phone with a fast processor or just a very sexy phone for everyday use this is the phone for you. When you have it in your hand you can really tell it was well worth the money. This phone has many positives and very few negatives. The only real complaint about this phone is that it is hard to find a case and the edge doesn’t have any real use except for giving the phone a whole new look. POSITIVES Appearance The galaxy s6 is totally different from any other android phone in that it is now made out of all glass and not just any glass gorilla glass. This glass is one of the strongest glasses for phones out there. One reviewer said,” Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful.” I agree completely android is known for using cheap plastic for their phones but that is not the case for this phone. Even though it is gorilla glass I would still strongly recommend getting a case. I know a naked phone galaxy s6 looks appealing but you shouldn’t take that risk. The camera on the back is raised out of the back of the phone which can get the lens scratched but is highly unlikely. The phone fits perfect in your pocket and hand. I would say it is the perfect size for a phone. Camera The galaxy s6 has one of the best cameras a phone could offer. It comes with many different camera modes that you can have a lot of fun with. I personally find no need for my 300$ sony camera no more ever since I got this phone. It really makes the picture come out just like you would want it. Every time you use the camera you will feel like you’re a professional camera man. This camera will not disappoint and will make sure you will get the best picture for you to cherish for years to come. NEGITIVES Edge uses The galaxy s6 comes in two versions the regular and the edge version which is just extra screen that curves over your phone a little. The price difference is 100$. It does not have really any major use so it leaves you wondering is it worth the extra 100$? I personally thought the look it gave the phone was good enough to convince me to get. If you’re not worried about looks then maybe the regular version is for you. Yes the edge can’t do much for now but I am 100% sure big things will be coming soon that only will be offered with the edge version. Finding Cases Since the phone is an awkward shape there are not many cases out there on the market for it. For instance the two major case company’s otter box and life proof do not make cases for the edge model. Yes its heart breaking but it is not the end of the world. It might take you longer to find a case that fits your needs and style but the phone is worth the extra time. OVERVIEW/CONCLUSION I believe the positives weigh out the negatives 10 folds. The phone is amazing with tons of features that are mouth dropping. You might spend an extra 100 dollars just to have your”fav 5” contacts on the side but it will not disappoint in the long run. You are really getting a bang for your buck. Anything of this quality is well worth the extra time and effort. In conclusion, I would recommend the galaxy s6 edge to anyone. The appearance, performance, and camera are all top of the line. If you do not want to waste your phone on a phone that is going to be out of data in a year then get this phone. The galaxy s6 edge will still be one of the top phones for years to come. So get you a galaxy s6 edge and co

Textual Messages: It is amazing to me that Samsung has succeeded in creating an absolutely horrible device out of such great hardware. The hardware is indeed state of the art: Amazing camera, plenty of storage, great processor. Yet the Samsung bloatware and their security settings have made it the worst phone I have ever had. The bloatware is merely annoying, using up all kinds of resources and generally buggy, so that it's interrupting things you're trying to do with some sort of bs that Samsung wants to notify you about. And the security policy is truly unbearable. At the moment, I'm deleting without backup (because impossible without unlocking) all my user data because the fingerprint security stopped working. And Samsung FORCES you to create a backup password that's so secure that you can't possibly remember it. Having tried the one I had written down as well as all of my normal passwords, I finally gave up and am now going through hours of wasted time setting up the phone again (the setup process is also unnecessarily tedious), won't have my photos, won't have numerous custom notes. I can't say enough bad about this phone. It's kind of like making a Mercedes but then adding some sort of elaborate key system that doesn't work very well and requires contacting the manufacturer to start your car when it doesn't. I will never by a Samsung phone again after this experience, and, since I have a contract for this one, I guess I'll just keep it for a little while (only have had it for a few months) more but with no security at all, assuming that's possible.

I had to return the phone several weeks after I got it (2/4 phones had a defect, both being camera) and then I got a vrand new one and it has the SAME defect! The rear camera does not focus. I tap on the subject I want and it focuses on the background. It sucks because I really was looking forward to the camera. Now I have contacted samsung to return it AGAIN because aside from the camera and the sound it makes when ever it opens, it does not charge. I have to charge it wirelessly everynight and it's annoying to have to hold the pad up to it. I cleaned it properally to the best of my electronic knowledge and it still doesn't work. They want me to do a hard reset to prove it won't work but it's a MAJOR inconvenience and I can't sync it via a cord because it does not work. I'd do it via the cloud but on niether phones my pics and vids don't want to sync and an error comes up. So I will probably have to deal with it for the next 1.5 years but the camera issue bothers me so I'm doomed to unfocused pics and videos that when they focus have a "lazy eye" and it refocuses on the background. Aside from those issues, good speed and everything. I like the fingerprint scanner and audio settings (I'm an audiophile). I like it but I'll probably go back to Apple as I thought I would try a Samsung but this has been a horrible experience.

Textual Messages: Numerous people are complaining about the lack of removable batteries, external microsd card slot, and no waterproofing. I love the Galaxy's previous generations and have them. Losing the battery replacement does suck, but there are plenty of compact battery backups reasonably costed. Samsung states the S6 will be able to charge for 10 minutes to get 4 hours of use. Of course I don't expect that from the battery backup, but it is an amazing new feature that will really help eliminate the need for another battery. I get that a lot of people want to keep the product well past their 2 year contract, or pass it on to someone else and the battery life degrades over time. Most will not though and upgrade as their contracts expire. Plus the battery can still be replaced with a little effort. Also my iPhone 3 still works after years of use for a full day. It doesn't have a removable battery. Yes, I actually use it. My Galaxy broke a month ago from my own misuse and am waiting to upgrade. Losing the sdcard slot is a plus in a lot of ways. Don't get me wrong because I am sad to see it go. Being able to change out music, games, and audiobooks etc on the fly was great. Especially when there is no signal while hiking and I can't stream. However, with my devices it rarely functioned the way it was intended. Not all apps could be moved over to it, some updates would still be downloaded to the internal storage, and certain apps would only read internal storage opposed to where the content was stored on the external card. Plus Samsung is providing cloud storage free for 2 years up to 115GB. Way more than you could store before. The S6 is able to access the cloud content quicker than an sdcard too. Now with that being said it is crucial you don't store sensitive data on the cloud. Nothing is truly secure. Those who want to imply security is greater on the sdcard are somewhat correct, but that is only because people usually aren't attacking individual devices. It is far easier to get the data from an sdcard form those that know about exploiting rather than pentrating tons of servers even when encrypted. I also understand others complaint that they do not have signal or unlimited data. For those the lack of sd capabilities will hurt more. I'm glad Samsung reworked the design of the phone to give it a better look. The previous versions have always felt cheap and dated. It does suck to lose the waterproofing feature in the S5. I also wish they went with an aluminum case than glass. I hate seeing fingerprints everywhere. For the most part its no big deal. The phone will be in a case. I prefer the caseless feel, but after losing 2 phones without them you learn your lesson. The phone's specs are a beast compared to most of the current market making it a real contender.

Textual Messages: That cloud storage will do you absolutely no when you are in a area getting low to no signal. Plus people who are on limited or shared data plans will end up having overages, plus once that time is up you will have to pay eventually for cloud storage. plus I WILL not put my data on servers. no thanks. Plus that battery estimate is only for general usage. when you are out and about and watching a stored or streaming movie, or taking several hours of 4k video, the battery even new, will wear down quicker. There was absolutely nothing better than slapping in a slim fully charged battery from my jean pocket to phone in less than 5 seconds, and being good for the rest of the day. If you're out and about and you are taking a lot of video, on the beaches or the trails, you will not find an outlet so you can plug in which you still need an outlet for "wireless" charging. want to carry a bulky, non water proof external charger, oh yea you still have to plug that too into the phone and that will only get you so much. Don't even want to get started on the NO micro sd slot issue. After being a Samsung Fanboy for years with owning Galaxy S2, S3, S4, Note 3 and preaching to everyone to get a Samsung, now you might as well preach to the choir. !00% absolutely will not be getting the Samsung Galaxy S6 for the first time ever. They are putting their money that more sheeple want basically an Iphone 6, which they copied features, might as well go and get one then as this former Fanboy won't be getting either.
