Helpful: 44 of 48 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: As my name suggests, I am a college student so I mostly use my phone for texting, Facebook, Instagram and other social media. Thus I would say I'm not an intensive user of all of the phone's features. I also do not play any games on it as I prefer to use my iPad for that. That way I keep my phone's storage pretty much at less than 50%. I switched from a Galaxy SII the T-989 version two weeks ago and have never looked back. I had a 16GB microSD card on my old phone and at first was wary of not having an option for expandable storage but soon realized since the Galaxy S6 has 32GB of storage that's more than enough for me and my daily needs. Thus, the non-removal battery and lack of the microSD slot is a non-issue to me. This phone is certainly a huge upgrade for me, basically everything is different about it. My personal favorite features are the LED light which my previous phone lacked, the fingerprint scanner, and the fact that I am able to reply to a text message from any app because there are pop up notifications. Previously, I wanted to switch to the iPhone because it had those notification features like pop-up notifications and notifications on the lock screen but now that the Galaxy S6 has those too I no longer feel the need for an iPhone. As previously mentioned, I do not use my phone extensively so I've had no issues with it so far. It is smooth, responsive and fast. I haven't any issues with apps crashing or the phone freezing (knock on wood!). I also really enjoy the battery life. With my previous phone I would have to charge it twice in one day if I used it constantly, thus I resorted to using airplane mode to salvage my battery life. With this phone, I charge it every other day if I let it go from 100% to 5%. It also charges very quickly. 1 hour at the charger without using it can get me somewhere between 20-40% extra life (I haven't paid very careful attention to how much I get from an hour). As far as the design and the exterior goes. It is not as gold as I had expected. It's definitely not as flashy gold as the iPhone but I still like it. The phone is thin and light weight and took maybe a day or two to get used to from my previous phone. I do have a clear case on it from Best Buy which protects everything it needs to protect and has a good grip. I also noticed that the screen is less fingerprint prone because I can easily wipe it with a shirt or my pant leg and all my fingerprints are gone. Also, I bought this phone from the seller SHOPEBEST and there was absolutely no hassle. With Prime shipping the phone was in my hand in 2 days as promised. THERE WAS NO BROKEN SEALS OR DAMAGE TO THE BOX. The phone is international so I was expecting a foreign charger, my phone is from the UK which I am actually thankful for. It IS the model SM-G920F. Everything was in the box, the little thing to open the SIM slot, the headphones, all the little booklets of information, and the UK charger with an American adapter. The phone was in perfect condition, no scratches or little nicks. I have Walmart Family Mobile as my service provider and I had no issue switching my service from my old microSIM to the nanoSIM. It took maybe 5 minutes on the phone and 15 minutes later my service switched and the phone worked like a breeze. My 4G is also working perfectly. I ran a speed test on my old phone prior to the switch and on this phone and this phone has much faster download and upload speeds. I am attaching screenshots of the speed test results from the SpeedTest app as well as pictures of the phone.

Helpful: 40 of 47 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Wow, what a difference a year makes. While last year's S5 took many steps in the right direction(being somewhat waterproof with better material and craftsmanship), it still wasn't there to make it a mouth-watering phone yet, like what HTC did when they first introduced their One M7, or whenever Apple introduces a new iPhone size. This year, Samsung has finally learned from both of their competitors, and made a phone that has all the good qualities of both, plus some of their own. Finally, this is the Galaxy S that you've always wanted and been dreaming of. * The very first thing you notice when you handle the phone, is its new design and form factor - finally Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful. The metal fully wraps around the edges ofthe phone. The back is beautiful, the sides are beautiful - heck, even the buttons are beautiful. It feels great in the hand, and oozes style and sophistication. * The very next thing you notice, of course, is the screen. I am continually pleasantly surprised at the evolution of Samsung's AMOLED technology - it has now became the best screen in the industry, hands down. I used to defend the LCD technology of the HTC M7, and at that point it was in fact overall superior to the Samsung S4 because the AMOLED then had issues in the sun, and color reproduction(it was too saturated and not natural). But now, they have fixed those issues, and the S6's screen is just quite simply the best. If you don't believe it, just compare an LG/Samsung OLED TV to any LED TVs today. I still think 5.1 inches for a screen of a PHONE is still too big, but overall, for what smartphones represent nowadays, it is acceptable - we have conditioned ourselves to accept the bigger sizes of smartphones(I remember when I first held a 4.2" smartphone when it first came out - the HTC HD2 - and thought, "what the h3ll is this monstrosity??"). * It doesn't hurt that Samsung boosted up the resolution to 1440 x 2560 pixels, which is approximately 577 ppi in pixel density. Although this is quite overkill right now, it's always nice to have the latest and greatest technology - that's the reason why we buy these overpriced phones in the first place, isn't it? It is also very bright, and sunlit legibility is excellent. Color reproduction is quite accurate, and like the S5, you can choose different color modes to suit your liking. * An important aspect to discuss is the battery life, now more than ever because there is no removable back cover to make replacing the battery easily like before, not to mention there is no microSD slot for you to add memory space to your phone. Comparatively, the S6 Edge is supposed to last a little less than the S6 regular, which I've read is less than last year's S5. But I'm one of those who are always around a charger, and I always carry external battery packs in my backpack when I travel, so that's never a concern. Seriously, who even buys an extra battery anymore - which you can only use for a single specific phone model - when your external battery can charge ANY and ALL phones and tablets?? This scenario only makes sense if your work is so demanding that you don't have extra time to charge the phone, and need to swap batteries IMMEDIATELY. I don't think that scenario is realistic nowadays when external batteries are so small, light, and cheap. My S6 goes from 100% at 10 am to about 20% at 10 pm with moderate use - so no complaints there. I get home, plug it up, and there are no issues. * What's better this year, is the wireless charging standards are already built into the phone, so you can just buy a charging pad for about $50 and feel even more cool. * The missing microSD expansion issue is a legitimate concern, since everyone loves to store their music, videos/movies, and all their apps in their phones. Now, you have to be selective and choose what to include or not. But I also have

Textual Messages: Pros: over all is a great phone and for most novices they won't miss anything. The 16 megapixel camera is great except for that it's hard to take pictures that don't blur from time to time. The 6+ edge plus add stabilization features. This comes in handy and is quite in addition but it's not on this model. Cons: Too much bloat ware. Especially with the Galaxy S6+ Edge, since you can't get as much options for storage memory (no 128GB) (and the infrared was removed) but at least it has more RAM by 1 GB, and a stronger processor, the Exynos 7422 which this model could have used both -especially the extra RAM with all the bloat ware. ( hint going and turn a lot of it off in application settings.) The BIGGEST CONS all the new flagship Samsung phones, the S6 line and the note 5 line of phones, is that Samsung stupidly, and with much resentment in the Samsung loyalist phone community, killed the removable battery and the external SdCard memory slot. This makes your need for upgrading your phone or repairing it much greater every year, as a typical battery depletes in recharge ability between 25 and 35% a year. that means if you got 20 hours a daythe first year by the second near your get maybe 14 worth of life a day, and you can't just replace the battery for $30 by ordering it on Amazon. The same is true for memory they want hundreds of dollars for upgrading your memory from 32 GB to 128 GB. When a 64 GB sdCard can be used for much of the storage for under $50. Their goal is to make money at the cost of the user and the convenience of the user. It should make you angry. if you keep your phone for 2 to 3 years he may have to repair it to three times to get new batteries installed and to keep the phone charge up, if you need it at max every day. I ordered a new battery every six months to do that. AND to keep memory off the main phone I just copied files from the main phone to the SDcard, Eventually when I got home or rather when I got time I would copy it off to my secure home network. But I also have a lot of apps. Samsung uses most of the main memory themselves. So you almost have to get the first upgrade if you're to use the phone in any way imaginable except as they recommend senior citizens do. Consumer reports words not mine. If you had an SDcard you can use an app to copy most of the apps memory to the SDcard. this saves too much money when it comes to options of memory upgrades. The other con I have is the sound is not the greatest on these phones. I really had hoped they would be a vast improvement from the previous version. I'm of course talking about the external sound for playing music. Yes I can use earphones but that's not what I'm referring to.

Textual Messages: I mistakenly failed to trust the reviews on the poor cellular reception and now I have discovered the same. I live in an area with good to excellent LTE service and I have never had LTE on the Samsung S6 after four weeks of use. I am lucky to see three out of five bars for 4G. While at home, my Samsung S6 automatically defaults and enables Wi-Fi because of the very weak phone antenna. Bluetooth is another story because it crashes and then starts to repeatedly crash, recover, crash, and recover. Because of this, using the phone to talk in the in the car over Bluetooth is useless as well as playing music. The Samsung takes beautiful pictures and easy to navigate, however; as a reliable phone, this is questionable.

Helpful: 3 of 4 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Oh, Another year 2015. Another set of phones from manufacturers! I have been hooked onto get the latest phone every year syndrome and love reviewing specifics. Disclaimer, I love Android and have been using from very early days. Samsung Galaxy S6 tries to be a revolutionary, but it is evolutionary. If you have an older phone more than 2 years old, absolutely get this. So do check local specs. I played around with both S6 and S6 Edge for few days and my opinions are based on this. There are tons of reviews going into lot of details, so I am focused on few other aspects like what’s out there and how to compare specs. First Big Changes: No microSD or removable battery. I know many of you loyal Samsung fans says BUMMER! I was a die hard fan of Samsung till S4, then I went to LG G2/G3. I think this is the best bet for S6 to pull it off after a dismal year for Samsung last year. I was very curious to try out S6 and HTC One M9 as they are most talked about now. Many manufacturers are going away from microSD card slots and this is absolutely a must and is a key differentiator from iPhone. I am really sad Samsung decided to drop microSD card slot as well as no removable battery. Why?! Screen is a beauty on S6 – Just Gorgeous. Just go to a retail store and feel it! The Edge feature is still gimmicky. Unlike Note Edge, this has both sides so less dorky but still I am not sold yet. Unless you have loads of money, I will shy away from it for one more year and get it next year when they polish it up. It is certainly fancy and nice to show off, but I would rather buy an Android wear watch like Motorola 360 or Samsung Gear or LG R series. I like Motorola 360 but waiting for version 2 to appear. I like Round watches. IF YOU HAVE LAST YEAR model of any phone, PLEASE DON’T upgrade. Phones are becoming so standard and power packed it makes no sense to upgrade and waste money every year. I buy and sell so many phones as it is like a hobby for me, but I stick to one phone as primary for couple of years now. My main requirements are a 128 GB microSD, good screen, battery life and performance. I am trying hard to see if I can live without one. S6 and S6 Edge comes in a 128 GB variant and I will wait for prices to stabilize on this model. In my opinion, following are key specs to consider when you buying a phone. Most of others are standard or does not matter at all. First size, weight and resolution are part of look and feel. RAM/CPU part of performance. external Storage is part of expandability. Camera is obvious! SAR (Specific Absorption Rating) is an often ignored, but I feel essential to making a buying choice. Manufacturers don’t advertise or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S6: 5.65 x 2.78 x 0.27 in, 138 gm, 1440 x 2560 pixels, 5.1 in, 577 ppi, 3 GB RAM, NO MICROSD SLOT (bummer), Internal Storage upto 128 GB, Exynos 7420 Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex-A57, Gorilla Glass 4, 16 MP/5MP camera, SAR 1.15 W/kg (head), 1.16 W/kg (body) NANO SIM Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge: Slightly lower dimensions, 0.01 in thicker, 6 gm less weight, Same resolution, Curved Screen, HTC One M9: 5.69 x 2.74 x 0.38 in, 157 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 3 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 20.7 MP (rear), 4 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 810, Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2 GHz Cortex-A57 Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G3: 5.76 x 2.94 x 0.35 in, 149 gm, 2560 x 1440 pixels, 5.5 in, 538 pp

Helpful: 3 of 4 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: This iteration of the Galaxy series is gorgeous, period. Computing power wise, it runs all its applications smoothly and flawlessly. Has a true dual-screen feature. The specs I'm not going into- they are published and lauded everywhere. I moved up from a Galaxy S4 and am glad that I did. Thank God that I skipped the S5. I was tempted to switch from a long run of Android phones to the Apple iPhone 6 and iOS but after actually comparing the two hands-on, I think Lollipop 5.0 is the best Android version yet. Essentially no different from the Apple in actual experience. I do not bemoan the discontinuation of the micro SD nor the removable battery. There are simply too many data storage options today to worry about the lack of an SD card. Don't care for company-provided off-site storage? Fine-- then get yourself a private home cloud. As for the battery, I love the addition of wireless charging; it's so simple and convenient. I never really had battery issues with my S4 battery life anyway, so I don't expect any with the S6. Besides, hasn't anyone else noticed the public charging station machines that are starting to pop up? Sure, it costs, but so did that extra battery. Long story short, if you were waiting for the right time to upgrade, this is it. I don't think you'll regret it at all.

What a phone!!!!! First of all, I've not bought the phone from Amazon. I have bought it from a local retailer. I'm not a Samsung Rep. who would give a biased opinion. By the way, i have always preferred LG devices than Samsung before S6 was introduced. Somehow Samsung UI was so cheap and the camera colors were too harsh!!! I've been using LG G2 for over 2 years and had been pretty happy with it. Have also used 5s in the past but was a turn off to me. Wanted to upgrade from there. Was stuck between Iphone 6, LG G4 and S6. Saw each of them quite closely in the shop and read a lot of positives and negatives of each: LG G4: A great phone with lovely display and camera and a sleek UI. But totally no value for money because it is being sold at around USD 600. Again, the pastic build looks terrible. Have been tired of it since the time I bought G2. Yes, I could have bought the leather one but personally I like metal over anything else! So, LG G4 was not for me!!! Iphone 6: 1. Is too expensive for what it offers (Screen size, resolution, camera etc.) 2. Poor resolution compared to the peers 3. Camera doesn't even come close to G4 or S6 4. IOS is so unfriendly. I read a lot of PDFs and I'm on the go most often. So, damn! how can I transfer the files from my office laptop to iphone without headache - I cant install anything on my office laptop? 5. Screen size is way too small (4.7) or way too big (6 Plus) bcoz of the stupid design - large bezels 6. I don't live in the US so anyways I cant make the most of IOS and I'm not even into gaming or an app freak! so Iphone is totally useless for me and offers a very very poor value for money, unless you want to sell phone every other day for which iphone has the best resale value:) S6: 1. Was a STEAL DEAL - I got it for net value of USD 465 because of the festive season sale. I bought 32 GB Gold and man - it looks such a killer!!! 2. Camera - Perhaps this is the most important thing I see in any phone - Brilliant Pics - I would say ditch your DSLRs and just go with S6, you will be 99% right in most lighting conditions. Bokeh effect is amazing as well and the macro pics are so so so lovely!!!! I took pics in very low lighting condition and they couldnt be any better 3. Build quality - Its all metal but still very light weight since its only 5.1 inches 4. Download booster - What a terrific idea - WiFi + Cellular to download huge files - I download large movie files with my S6 and it is super fast! No other phone offers this feature! 5. Amazing screen - Super Amooled screen is terrific - see it to believe it - Watching movies is a bliss! Non expandable storage? Is that a problem?? Not for me for sure - Why? I have APOTOP which can help me connect to my android phone and stream media files. I can connect my 1TB external device to APOTOP and can stream movies, music, pics etc. and even transfer pics from phone into the external disk without having a laptop. So, space isn't a concern at all for me!!!!!! (By the way, this is again where IOS frustrates the users! - My Apotop app in IOS opens but cannot play all movie formats!!! it only plays .MP4 format while the Apotop App for Android plays all formats) Battery - I was skeptical about this but to my pleasant surprise, I never found any issues with my devise. Today at 10AM, the battery was at 100%. Then I have been using the phone to check my emails and make / receive calls with some net surfing. Right now, its 4:30PM and the battery is at 71%!!! In fact, two days back when my battery was at around 75%, I started on to watch the movie FOCUS on my phone and when the movie completed, it was down to 54% - That's it???? For such a high resolution screen and display that kills Iphone in every way, shape or form, a drop of only 20-25% for a whole HD movie? I'm extremely satisfied with my purchase and can confidently recommend S6 to everyone (S6 edge isn't value for money for me since it was around USD 750 in my country - I dont find it worth spending extra US

I just recently got the S6 and I was a bit hesitant about doing so after coming over from the iPhone5 which I loved. At first the size of the phone can seem a bit overwhelming but in just a day you begin to adapt and realize how much better (by better I mean both the size and clarity of the screen is astounding). After a few weeks of usage I really love the android and the custom option I can have which is a huge plus compared to the iphone, but there are some drawbacks I have found. One is the overall life of the battery, with heavy usage it can drain pretty quick and even without much use it can still seem to drain quickly, as compared to what I imagined the life of the new battery would but this is easily overcame with the fast charger where in just 15 minutes you can get an ample charge to last you hours which in my mind balances that out. The second is the phone can be a bit glitchy or slow at times which is suprising seeing that the phone is just a few weeks old, but this might be worked out as updates come. The final complaint I have was the amount of bloat wear or pre loading apps that were on the phone. I had to spend most of my evening deleting or disabling ( apps that can not be deleted) and there was quite a few. But with a bit of persistance I got the phone situated to my liking and have loved the phone since the day I got it.

I am not going to write about the S6 but the fact that is the international unlocked version SM-G920F. If you were to buy this from AT&T in the states it would be $685. So for almost $200 less the unlocked version is a value. It is important to note that not all bands are available, so please research if your carrier will support this phone. Also there is some debate on whether AT&T in NYC provides LTE to this phone. My phone only says 4G, but some have said that the phone doesn't read LTE because this phone is for the English market and they don't refer to LTE. I tend to agree with this since when I look in the phone which bands my phone is using it says 17, which is considered LTE in the states. But what confuses me is the speed I am getting in NYC (midtown) only 10/7, which for me isn't slow but more HSPA+ speeds. Since this version was intended for the English market the charger has a UK plug and Samsung or the shipper included an adapter. Overall a great phone but just double check on the cellular capability. OH BTW by not going through a carrier you don't have the crazy amount of bloatware on the phone only Samsung's and Microsoft's which is more than enough already.

The phone is very nice -- not too many bloatware, lightning fast, sleek, except, as reported in many places, the battery is not long lasting. On the other hand, the charging speed is superior -- less than 80 mins from 0% to 100% with the adaptive fast charger. The one start I'm not giving is for the phone not straight from factor. Claimed by the seller in the reply to my inquiry email as "factory sealed straight from the manufacturer", and in another email where I complained not true after getting it "verified that there was not usage on this unit prior to it arriving to you". But I still believe this is not true. Before opening the box, I saw a smaller factory seal (broken) covered by a larger one. After opening it, I immediately noticed a fingerprint on the phone protecting wrapper. I didn't return it because this was the 2nd time (returned once to another seller) and no longer wanted a 2nd long wait -- certainly, I checked the CPU/memory/SoC etc. to be the same as S6 specs before making the decision. In sum, this is an almost ideal phone. Buy it from stores if possible.

I purchased this phone about three months ago through AT&T and I honestly love this phone. I love the size and the color I instantly gravitated towards this color of phone because while this phone is Gold it is more on the cool toned side which is a shade of Gold that I prefer to shades more on the warmer side. The phone is run on an android system which I find the easiest to navigate and The programs are fast. I have had little to no technical issues with this phone and the photo quality is amazing. This phone has a setting in the camera that I have not experienced on any other phone; it has the option for a "wide selfie" This is great for group picture as you take the photo and then slowly move the photo to the left and then to the right and makes group photos with multiple people possible without the selfie stick trend ( I also have a selfie stick but I tend to use my selfie stick at events with a lot of people as to allow for the height of people in front of me and for better video angles). If you are in the market for a new phone let me say that I believe that this is the perfect phone.

Textual Messages: The phone is beautiful, however this review is specifically about this unlocked version of the Samsung Galaxy S6. I had the hardest time trying to get a network connection on this phone. I took it to the corporate store of my service provider (Metro PCS) and even they couldn't tell me why I couldn't get a network connection. Luckily the people there could refered me to someone who worked in the vicinity and knew about unlocking cell phones. He told me that because this is an International phone he had to install extra things on it to get it working. I have a 4G connection, not LTE. My guy told me LTE isn't capable on an International phone. So beware the extra steps you will have to take to get this phone working like it's supposed to. Despite that, now that I have a connection I do love it. Besides, there's really no difference between 4G and LTE.

I normally go back and forth between Apple and Android but I started a new job so I bought the Samsung Galaxy s6 as a means of new efficiency. I think its great so far. PRO 1. Great UI. There are many things the user can control to his/her preferences which is a huge plus. Finger print password, managing apps, shortcuts, etc. 2. Great color and clarity of screen. Good use of large screen without feeling bulky. 3. Functionality. Works well with 4G. I've use Apple for most of my professional life and I can't believe how flawless and seamless the Android system functions. It hasn't crashed despite the memory-hogging, data-centric apps I use - unlike my previous iPhone. CON 1. One annoying thing was that my SIM card did not originally fit so I had to go to my local mobile store and get it cut - no charge ofcourse, but they did seem surprised that a new SIM did not come with the package as it seemed the norm. But that was a small inconvenience to bear.

Textual Messages: I'm shocked that Samsung is still producing a phone with a user interface that feels like 2003. This phone is running the latest version of Android, but it feels like the original version. Samsung loads tons of custom apps that are substantially worse than the Android default apps. Compared to base Android, it's incredibly hard to find basic things, such as how to uninstall an app, changing the background picture etc. I hate that apps like Facebook and Instagram cannot be uninstalled. I don't mind them being installed by default but I should be able to remove them. The only good I can say is that the phone is fast - it feels very responsive. The build quality is tolerable but it still feels sub-par for the price. Having now used: Galaxy S4, S5, S6, Nexus 5 & 6, iPhone 4S, 5, 5S & 6 - I would strongly recommend against the Galaxy line. When the day comes that Samsung figures out how to remove its customization to Android it might be worth considering. I really don't want a customized OS that makes my experience worse.

Textual Messages: Im a Walmart Electronics Associate, and was able to get an upclose view and useage of both the S6 and S6 edge, as well was able to have a personal chat with a worker from Samsung about the phone, the first thing i noticed about both was the sleek look of it, with glass on the back and a metal frame, it was a wonderful sight. After that was noticing the edge, a curved screen right at the edges, which made it my personal favorite. Two cons i noticed right off the bat, no replaceable battery, and no microSD slot, i can explain why there is no microSD slot, and its not due to their skills of making the cases. They found that their new style of hard drive which i heard was a form of hybrid ssd/hdd, was faster then any of the latest microSD cards, so instering one into the phone would simply slow it down whenever you wanted to access anything from the SD card. So a legidimate reason to not include a MicroSD card slot, luckly they provided that the smallest memory capacity the phone comes in is 32gb, unlike apple with their 8gb minimum. The battery is simply a special style, and it would have got rid of the beautiful style of the phone to make it replaceable. Now think about the screen itself, its pratically a glass screen protector built into itself, of course dont go dropping it becase i said that. Samsung went to great lengths to create a phone that had far less problems with the screen cracking, but still no system is perfect, although the screen is more durable then most of their competitors. I still, and i always will highly recommend getting a screen protector and case. The phone is very fast, switching instantly from apps, and even picture taking is unbelievable, with rapid photo taking if you hold the button down, and you can even tell it to take a picture like in the previous s5. The screen is beautiful, perfect detail for such a small phone, samsung i believe is the top picture quality producer among phones. But i cannot offer much more on the phone, since i was unable to use it for very long. Overall, i would buy it if i could afford it.

Textual Messages: Samsung TV's are amazing. I have an 8K series smart TV and the thing is out of this world. I have a Samsung blu-ray player and it’s a very good blu-ray player. I have a Samsung Tablet and it is a great tablet. What the heck does this have to do with a Galaxy S6 Smart Phone review? Please keep reading I promise you won’t be sorry. First of all I just wanted to show that I am not a first time Samsung product buyer. I have many Samsung products that work great as well I have bought several of their smart phones all have been great phones. Until now. As I said I had the S4 my wife’s S3 took a dump so I reluctantly gave her my S4 and bought an S6. I had the new S6 phone for almost a week. It has some great new features particularity the ability to keep the phone from locking when connected to anything in the exclusion list. I have to use a password on my phone because its a personal phone I use for work mostly. I work 100% remotely from home I am on it all day every day. So, I need it to lock but love that the new feature will allow you to set an exclusion list of when and where to lock it. Anyway, I quickly realized that most of the new features, why I liked this new phone, worked intermittently at best. I soon noticed I was dropping almost every call I made, the phone just seemed to be cursed. So, I took it back to where I bought it and they gave me a new one, we both were thinking I just got a "bad" phone. I was very skeptical that I had just happened to get a "bad" phone I was convinced it was Samsung laying an egg with new technology. I thought crappy design and even worse mother boards. Man was I was right!!!! This second phone acted and did the same thingas the first. The battery lasts for like 30 minutes (being facetious) not too far off! and the new features continued to act the same way, worked intermittently at best and the phone just seemed to be cursed. NOTE: Man does this thing charge lightning fast and it better cause like I said the battery lasts for like 30 minutes. So, I called Samsung tech support and this is where things get interesting. I worked with tech support and they couldn’t fix it so they asked me to send it in so they could fix it. I sent it in and within a week I had the phone back! Hurray! Ummm, yea right, NOT! I quickly noticed it was not zeroed out to factory settings as they said it would be. They hadnt fixed it at all. I checked the box several times thinking there was some explanation as to what they found and --- NOTHING, ZILCH. There was no follow up call or e-mail or anything in the ticket online to say what they found either. So, I called them and they told me “it has water damage” we can’t fix it!?!?!?!?!?! WTF!?!?!?!? Guys I’m telling you, I have used two of these new phones both brand new out of the box and they both acted the same way - quite simply in short THEY SUCK! I will now come across as a disgruntled customer spewing silly rhetoric but I don’t care. What I am saying is all true and if my phone really had water damage then the serial number sticker I specifically left stuck to the back of the phone would surely have water damage, it does not. I DID NOT CAUSE WATER DAMAGE TO MY PHONE. I pleaded with Samsung to replace my phone and they said they would talk to their supervisor and call me back. Well, you guessed it no call back after a week so far. Quick NOTE: I was involved with the first Pentium PC processors when they first came out, the company I worked for got a bad first batch and the big blue company that made them and installed them had to replace about 150 mother boards in all the new PC's we purchased from that first batch. Point being, bad computer chips, bad mother boards and CPU's etc...does happen. Bottom line - please, please, DO NOT BUY THE S6, you will be sorry, especially if you use the phone for anything other than calls, texting or taking pictures. SAMSUNG LAID AN ABSOLUTE EGG WITH THIS NEW S6!!! And they screwed a regular guy like me by telling me Oh sorry, your

Helpful: 95 of 103 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I just moved from the Galaxy Note 3 to the S6 Edge so my review is colored by that comparison. This wasn't the unqualified success I'd hoped for. The Good: o Cool factor. The edge screen is eye catching and a popular topic of discussion o Size. My Note 3 Phablet was too big. The S6 has a large screen but can be easily one-handed. o Speed. Generally speaking the phone is fast and responsive o Wireless charging. This built-in feature is by far my favorite upgrade. I have a charging pad on my nightstand and I can just lay the phone down to charge. If I need to read it during the night I'm not wrestling with wires. o Screen resolution. Insanely sharp and bright. The increased pixel density isn't necessarily noticable with the naked eye but I am a VR enthusiast and I can see a significant improvement when using Google Cardboard. I'm looking forward to getting the Samsung VR helmet later this year. The Bad: o Battery life - even with moderate use I have to charge once or twice during the day. o Hesitation - I use the same suite of apps as I did on my Note 3 but the S6 will hang up for no discernable reason where the Note 3 didn't. This is especally odd given the S6 processor upgrade. o Hand Feel - the edge feels like a fragile bird in my hand. The power and volume buttons are way to easy to press and the thin edge feels fragile. The cover I bought has considerably improved this situation. o Constantly waking up unbidden like an attention starved toddler. I'm not talking about bumping the power button. I'm talking about spontaneous wake up due to lord knows what - proxity to another phone, the power of my Aura when its in my pocket, a sideways glance. Its very frustrating and probably a big contributor to my battery life issues. I'm still looking for the "shut the heck up until I call for you" setting but so far no luck. I've never owned such a touchy smart phone. o The curved screen has some downsides. It warps the edge of images and some apps are hard to navigate if a control is near the edge.Overall I wish I'd bought the regular S6. Don't mistake me. This is a very good smart phone. But there are some downsides to consider before getting swept up in the cool factor like I did. Probably deserves 4 stars but nobody reads those reviews.

Helpful: 60 of 66 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Wow, what a difference a year makes. While last year's S5 took many steps in the right direction(being somewhat waterproof with better material and craftsmanship), it still wasn't there to make it a mouth-watering phone yet, like what HTC did when they first introduced their One M7, or whenever Apple introduces a new iPhone size. This year, Samsung has finally learned from both of their competitors, and made a phone that has all the good qualities of both, plus some of their own. Finally, this is the Galaxy S that you've always wanted and been dreaming of. * LOOKS/FORM-FACTOR/MATERIALS: The very first thing you notice when you handle the phone, is its new design and form factor - finally Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful. The metal fully wraps around the edges ofthe phone. The back is beautiful, the sides are beautiful - heck, even the buttons are beautiful. It feels great in the hand, and oozes style and sophistication. The S6 Edge is just so unique-looking - it is the most beautiful phone I've seen in a long time. And contrary to what people might say or what you might think, the two sloped edges are not awkward to handle, does not dig into your skin, and is not uncomfortable to grip. * SCREEN: The very next thing you notice, of course, is the screen. I am continually pleasantly surprised at the evolution of Samsung's AMOLED technology - it has now became the best screen in the industry, hands down. I used to defend the LCD technology of the HTC M7, and at that point it was in fact overall superior to the Samsung S4 because the AMOLED then had issues in the sun, and color reproduction(it was too saturated and not natural). But now, they have fixed those issues, and the S6's screen is just quite simply the best. If you don't believe it, just compare an LG/Samsung OLED TV to any LED TVs today. I still think 5.1 inches for a screen of a PHONE is still too big, but overall, for what smartphones represent nowadays, it is acceptable - we have conditioned ourselves to accept the bigger sizes of smartphones(I remember when I first held a 4.2" smartphone when it first came out - the HTC HD2 - and thought, "what the h3ll is this monstrosity??"). * It doesn't hurt that Samsung boosted up the resolution to 1440 x 2560 pixels, which is approximately 577 ppi in pixel density. Although this is quite overkill right now, it's always nice to have the latest and greatest technology - that's the reason why we buy these overpriced phones in the first place, isn't it? It is also very bright, and sunlit legibility is excellent. Color reproduction is quite accurate, and like the S5, you can choose different color modes to suit your liking. *BATTERY LIFE: An important aspect to discuss is the battery life, now more than ever because there is no removable back cover to make replacing the battery easily like before, not to mention there is no microSD slot for you to add memory space to your phone. Comparatively, the S6 Edge is supposed to last a little less than the S6 regular, which I've read is less than last year's S5. But I'm one of those who are always around a charger, and I always carry external battery packs in my backpack when I travel, so that's never a concern. Seriously, who even buys an extra battery anymore - which you can only use for a single specific phone model - when your external battery can charge ANY and ALL phones and tablets?? This scenario only makes sense if your work is so demanding that you don't have extra time to charge the phone, and need to swap batteries IMMEDIATELY. I don't think that scenario is realistic nowadays when external batteries are so small, light, and cheap. My S6 goes from 100% at 10 am to about 20% at 10 pm with moderate use - so no complaints there. I get home, plug it up, and there are no issues. * What's better this year, is the wireless charging standards are already built into th

Textual Messages: I don't know what some of these negative comments are talking about. No this isn't a scam, I received the g925F not the I (the F for international, the I for the India version. Although both have the EXACT same specs.) and the box doesn't have extra letters.... I must say, being a die hard iOS girl, that this is a nice phone. The screen is beautiful, it's android so you have to know it's not as simple (they have a toggle for a simpler version which I have yet to try), it's very presonisable. I was able to easily connect to my iPhone and transfer everything over, and when I say everything I mean everything! They matched my apps and if they didn't have the exact one they found one that was similer, freaking great option. Now for the people complain about battery life? WELCOME to the smart phone world, you wanted a mini TV screen that can multitask and be able to power a s*** ton of apps and keep up with what everyone is doing on facebook, twitter, myspace, tumbr and IG then yes the battery's suck. When you first get this phone you are going to sit there and program it to death, tweak everything to your liking. So the first week yeah your battery life is going to suck even more than normal. So androids I don't care which one has a s*** ton of apps that stay on in the back ground. So the apps with the screen saps your battery. So now you have two ways to fix this: a. Figure out to how to toggle all the apps from running in the background yourself which means you have to check up on them, or b. Download a app that does that exact thing for you such as juice defender or such like (no it doesn't turn off your fb no worries your gossip will come to you). Now with that being said the battery life and the way the phone is built has nothing to do with this seller. Why are you rating someone a horrible rate when it wasn't them who built the phone in their backyard? What you need to know when buying from this seller: * Crazy fast delivery, man got here super quick. * the phone was in it's box sealed and came with an American adapter for the charger. * the product works and works well. I bought it for cricket and works great. No damage. * Would I suggest you buy this phone coming from an iPhone? Yes! I like it, I definitely don't regret switching. * Would I suggest you buy it from this seller? Yes I gave the seller 5 stars. Awesome and would buy a phone again from them in the future.

Textual Messages: Great looking phone with solid built construction and premium materials but Samsung still needs to go back to the drawing table! The design of this phone is great looking (especially the gold platinum). The camera on it is the second best I've used on a phone. Only the LG G4 has a better camera IMO. This phone however does lack in other areas, and no its not the non-replaceable battery or lack of micro-sd support. According to Samsung "Touchwiz" has been toned down but it is still laggy!! Too much bloatware!! NO I don't want to use Samsung Hub, NO I don't want to use Samsung Music, NO I don't want to use Samsung Cloud!! YES I know loud music can damage my hearing (constantly comes up when adjusting vol up)!! Lastly, Why is Samsung not using Google's default AVRPC profile!! This causes a lot of headaches with MANY bluetooth devices including paring problems, missing song/artis info, and inability to use steering wheel controls for playback control!! Sorry Samsung, I had the S3, Note 2, Note 3, Note Edge (returned) and I can honestly say that I am a happy camper with my LG G4 I just received in exchanged for this device (cheaper too).

Helpful: 4 of 4 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: This phone is a beautiful phone inside and out. It looks amazing and the curved edge make it look very cool and unique, i had this phone ever since the day it came out and I enjoyed it very much. I had a screen protector and a heavy duty case to protect it from drops spills scraches anything. However the phone has a few BIG problems which I am going to talk about. 1. The phone is fragile. I had a case and a screen protector and I never dropped it, well until i did from about 3 feet and the bottom on the screen cracked. i couldn't believe that such a light fall would crack it, even though I had a Spigen case on it, and a screen protector. 2. Since it has a curved display, there are no real tempered glass screen protectors. 3. Battery life is average, and no removable battery which meant the phone has an expiration, unless you know or take it to someone who can change it for you. Even though these flaws are BIG to some people (like me) the phone is great, the camera is amazing, the speakers are very good, and the display is stunning, with that being said, after moving to the regular galaxy s6, I realized that its the better out of the two brothers. its more comfortable to use and is about 140$ cheaper too. take my advice if you are stuck between the s6 and the edge, don't go for the edge because the edges are more of a burden than something functional.

Textual Messages: Edit: Now that I'm in the routine of rebooting, it works pretty well. It's an annoying step to have to take, but in fairness I'm much happier than I was when I wrote the review below and I'm adding a star as a result. Earlier: This phone is a total bust. It is often unbearably slow -- so much so that it's essentially unusable until a reboot. Rebooting is easier said than done when it's in super slow mode. Whatever software or memory glitch is to blame (according to the buzz online), it wasn't fixed in the latest update. The screen is also a problem. It doesn't always register touches. Another glitch: Several times the phone has dialed the wrong person. I click on one name, and someone else entirely from my phonebook gets a call from me. That's pretty awkward. I'll stand up for the curved screen, though. Reviewers say it's useless. So are high heels, but they look great. Same thing with this phone. Also, the camera is pretty great. Avoid this like the plague until they fix the slow problem.

One of the better phones I've owned. I recently switched to T-mobile due to the nickel and diming scheme that Verizon pulls. I get great coverage on this phone, which is more than could be said about the IP6 that I originally had chosen (and returned) with T-mobile. This phone is one of the better phones I've owned because it actually allows me the freedom to do what I want to do on a phone. I have never had many personalizing items on any phone as I do on this one. The iPhone STILL doesn't have an IR blaster which is something that I cannot believe, after 7+ years, that phone is still not right. The edge design as well as the color got me interested in this phone. I like to buy unique items, and this phone fits the bill in the color respect and the "edge" respect. There is a display for the time and notifications in grayscale on the corner of the screen, which conserves battery, and also allows you to know exactly what you need to know without waking the phone. You can use the side for alerts and not take up any valuable screen size while playing games, or videos, and actually still be aware of your surroundings (if you get a text that is important, etc), and still be doing what you were initially doing. The battery life, despite hearing from reviews is bad, is actually about the same as the NOTE4 that I used to own. It's rumored it's the same battery, just inside of the phone, but I don't really want to dissect my phone to find out, lol. Navigation with Google is actually much better than Apple maps, it displays the exit sign that you will need to get off at if traveling on a highway, so that way you know exactly where you're going, almost mirrored to the Garmin GPS that I had used previously. I was worried about the coverage initially with the issues that I'd had with my iPhone, but this is a band 12 supported phone (IP6S is as well), allowing for it to work automatically on other carriers when signal isn't as good with T-mobile. That and the cost of the phone + plan is worth much more than what Verizon had to offer. The camera is EXCELLENT on this phone, as is the sound quality. The screen is vibrant and large, bright, and doesn't make the battery deplete substantially. The phone runs hot at times due to it's metal structure, but it's not extremely noticeable, more so if you have location turned on.

The big draw of the curved screen is supposedly to get notification flashes even when the screen is face down. The solution to this "problem" that doesn't require an unnecessary phone just to be a walking marketing ploy for selling new phones to people with perfectly good ones is simple: don't put your darn phone face down. What a concept. You can use the "edge screen" to see extra tidbits of info along the side... what is this, a CNN rolling news bar? Or even better, the existing notifications bar that drops down from the top? What a completely worthless, redundant thing to create. I can't even call it a feature, a feature is something I would have to be able to use practically. You can turn both of these "features" off, and once you do it makes having this phone fundamentally worthless. The Edge is difficult to grip because of the screen curves. The power button is in an inconvenient spot toward the middle of the phone, right where a palm or finger holding it would be, leading to nothing but annoying pushes in the middle of use. The internal lighting isn't enough to overcome the curve of the phone, so there are constant visible shadows (or glare, depending on your lighting) down the length of both sides of the screen. So on either side of photos, videos, and fullscreen activities you don't get true color display, there's a built-in shadow caused by the design of the phone REGARDLESS of what angle you hold the phone at. The screen is curved but the keyboard and display are not, so you have an awkward rounded space to click on a flat display item - especially problematic while using the keyboard with its tiny keys. And in terms of useless starter apps, this Galaxy is the most gut-loaded with junk by far. It even came with instagram, so you can partake in the commodification of culture straight out of the package! Most irritating of all and by far what makes me loathe this phone the most is: this glorified flashlight is literally impossible for me to use. The screen being 3D and not flat gives it a sort of 3D-within-3D appearance like some kind of sci-fi haptic hologram (or, for a different visual, like a backlit layer of spilled koolaid). My eyes don't know what the heck to do with it! So using this phone not only messes with my depth perception (aka ruins it) but gives me motion sickness when I sidescroll. I was pressured into getting this phone by a retail associate at my carrier. Between that and its terrible ill-conceived design, it's clear to me that it only exists for the sake of being a new phone to draw in people who need to have the newest phone at all times. If I could give this review zero stars, I would. I was going to really try and make this phone work, to give myself some time to get used to it, but it's so unusable that it's not even worth it.

My first ever Android device came in the form of Samsung's Galaxy s3. In my opinion the S3 , to this date, is by the far the best phone I have ever owned. I have patiently waited for Samsung to release a phone that can bring me the same joy and wonder as the S3 and even going past my issue with Large form factor I thought the S6 would be it! However, I was sorely wrong. The S6 is a failure in my eyes. I feel that Samsung was pressured to move away from it's plastic to a more premium feel and didn't think about the internals or software. I waited so long to join the android world due to this one thought, " Over powered, under performing". This statement equates to the S6. On paper the S6 should be a powerhouse. Unfortunately that is quite the opposite. The S6, when it works, does blow you away. However, it doesn't work efficiently all the time. Even with using a different launcher and avoiding touchwiz the phone lags beyond belief. The experience is maddening. To top it off the phone will get so hot that the metal will actually burn you. Please note, this is not an exaggeration and also not while phone is on the charger. The phone had a recent update which admittedly helped some of the lag, but it has gone back to its old ways of being close to useless. Random battery drains, lag, and overheating are the name of the game with this phone. The edge screen is aesthetically pleasing but serves no function. Build quality is good. That is about it. Please take your time before investing in this phone. I am currently in the process of trying to sell mine. The phone I can recommend is the Galaxy Alpha- it is discontinued so if you are ok with a device that won't have support or accessories it has a smaller form factor and works correctly.

Helpful: 5 of 8 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Samsung has done a better job with the Galaxy S6 Edge than with the S5. Not only is it beautiful and light, the screen resolution is better than ever. To begin with the body - it is slim and a lightweight all-metal body with a curved glass design that is lightning-fast thanks to the Samsung Exynos® 7420 Octa-core 64-bit processor that delivers the most power and speed I've ever had in a smartphone. Samsung increased the fast charge capability and the Galaxy S6 Edge charges much faster that other smart phones. Samsung has also paid attention to the camera and it is significantly improved. With both a front facing (the all important Selfie feature) and a rear facing camera option that you will love. You will also love that you can quickly launch the camera by double tapping the Home button and use optical image stabilization to eliminate blurry photos and shaky videos. No more blurry selfies taken by your kids to be posted on social media. There is a feature to disable the quick launch of your camera, if you dislike that feature. Samsung has added a larger aperture to the camera for low-light photography and an infrared sensor to improve white balance. Overall the camera takes great pictures and if one of your criteria for a smart phone is taking good pictures, then the Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge is for you. As with any improvement in technology, the cost goes up and without a doubt the Galaxy S6 Edge does have improved processing and a better camera, but it also comes with a higher cost and only you can determine if the additional features are for you.

Helpful: 0 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Aesthetically, this is a great looking phone. The best looking phone currently, better looking than any iPhone. The screen quality is also phenomenal. However, I absolutely hate the software. This is my first Samsung Galaxy phone, and supposedly, the S6 has a less obtrusive touchwhiz software compared to older galaxy phones. I'm coming from various Nexus phones, so I used to the vanilla-ness and snappiness of the Nexus phones. I now understand the touchwhiz hate. This biggest problem with the touchwhiz on S6 edge is lag. The lag is absolutely excruciating, and the initial lag on the lock screen is so awful. I have issues putting in the 4 pins to unlock this phone because the lag is so bad. After the phone unlocks, it takes awhile for the phone to get going. Occasionally, if you open an app to quickly after unlocking the phone, there could be a 30 second freeze. If you have music going while unlocking the phone, lag can potentially go on for eternity. Once the phone is up and running, it does run smooth. As for the Samsung apps themselves, my thoughts are 'meh'. I don't hate them, but I disabled what I could. I sort of like the S health which counts my steps. Cyanogenmod folks have yet to crack this phone because of the proprietary chip exynos. If I can get another OS on this phone, such as vanilla android or cyanogenmod, I would do it in a heartbeat. As for the battery, it's about average. The Nexus phones were about average for battery as well, so no real change. I do think the S6 edge is slightly worse though, but I think lots of the battery issues are due to TouchWhiz. Even with non-use, I can feel the phone getting hot in my pocket, and I'm sure the Samsung apps are just going crazy in the background. I don't take lots of pictures with my phone, but the camera is top notch. Maybe I would love this phone more, if I took more picture. tl;dr Looks and the aesthetics: 5 stars, This phone is currently the best looking phone. Software: 1 star, I absolutely loathe TouchWhiz and the lag. Battery: 3 stars, The battery life is average Camera: 5 stars Overall: A little bit more than 3 stars.

Textual Messages: This is possibly the worst phone I've ever had, relative to the price. While the screen is great and it takes excellent photos, the battery life is awful and the UI is unresponsive and flaky. At best, under typical use (texting, web browsing, a few photos) you'll get about 5 hours of battery before needing recharge. Fast Charging is kind of a joke if you have to do it every few hours. Touch response is awful - it can take several taps to get an app to actually launch, and once launched is similarly frustrating to actually use an app. On the other hand, the response on the edge is overactive, so just by holding the phone you'll find yourself accidentally triggering app launches and buttons presses.

The resolution is better than my eye can see. I use a Galaxy S4 as my regular phone and it has great resolution where you can't see individual pixels. I thought the S4 screen was as good as you can get, but the S6 screen takes it to a whole new level. Even though you can't see pixels on either screen, the higher resolution of the S6 screen makes everything look so sharp that it's nearly impossible to tell you are looking at a screen. It's that incredible. ? The design of the phone just feels more 'expensive'. I mean that in a good way. It feels just higher quality than previous models in the Galaxy S line. The S3 and S4 for example are often critiqued for having a plastic shell. The S6 has a metal band around the outside that just makes it feel 'premium' in your hand. It should also provide more protection for the device as well. ? TouchWiz is HEAVILY scaled back. I hate TouchWiz (Samsung's version of Android) It adds a layer of UI that is neither helpful nor intuitive. And it's a resource hog which slows the phone down for important tasks just so it can make the scrolling smoother, and other such useless tradeoffs. On the S6 TouchWiz was barely noticeable. The UI looks more like the standard Google Android Lollipop interface. It was all just much smoother and simpler and better and wonderful. ? Camera. 16 MP. And the images it takes look stunning on the super HD screen. Those photos on a larger high resolution monitor are simply stunning. ?????THE DOWNSIDES????? ? The battery is not removable or easily replaceable. A cell phone battery has a life of about 500 charge cycles. I tend to keep my phones for 2 years as daily users, then I keep my old phones for a variety of other purposes around the house. (My old HTC Sensation is hooked up to my stereo for use as a nice wifi streaming media player with a touchscreen UI, for example) I eventually have a need to replace batteries because I wear them out. I like being able to go on Amazon, spent $20 on a replacement battery, pop it in and be done. Additionally, even if you don't keep your phones that long, batteries fail sometimes. The stock batteries on the Galaxy S4 had some problems. They were minimal, but for those affected the battery absolutely had to be replaced. On the S4 it took 8 seconds and the problem was solved. On the S6 I'm sure it would be covered by warranty but it'd be a pain to take it somewhere to have it worked on should the issue come up. So no replaceable battery is a deal killer for me. This might not be an issue for you. If not, great! But be aware of the issue before making purchase decisions. ? You can't expand the storage with an SD Card. I don't want to live in the cloud. I hate the cloud. Sometimes I'm not on an LTE network. Sometimes I'm in the middle of nowhere but still want to show someone pictures of my kids. I got my wife the 32GB model. That sounds like a lot, but keep in mind that some of that is dedicated for the operating system and user apps. So you don't get to use all 32GB. The S6 is going to be available in up to 128GB, which ends my problem with not liking the cloud option. Again, you might not care. If not, great! My wife doesn't keep a lot of stuff on her phone. Textual Messages: I've had many types of phones. iPhone, HTC, Motorolla, now this Samsung. It's my first ever Samsung and I love it. I have the white 32gb and the reason I went with this is not only does it look great, it was super easy to figure out to use and the screen is awesome. I use my phone mainly for pictures, and that was a big deciding factor in my choice. I was hoping for the blue only to find out that it's not available in the U.S. The black isn't a true black, the edge was $100 more for features I really could care less about. I didn't need any confusion. I'm not very good at adjusting to different phones, and I just found this to be very smooth and easy to adjust to. I love this phone! The only thing I really don't like is the amount of finger prints you can see. I got the Samsung wireless charger, I love that as well! **** There are some complaints about the phone battery, I was very annoyed at first about it as well. I thought I was going to have to keep recharging. I have not had a problem with the phone not lasting through the day on average days. I do not do any gaming, just surfing, my 2 year old sometimes watches Youtube, I facebook, both my email accounts are on my phone so I get frequent notices. I would still highly recommend this phone, and I still love it.

Helpful: 51 of 54 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: This year, Samsung kept everything much more simple, intuitive, and beautiful. As a result, the Galaxy S6 is the best smartphone any person can currently. My review will focus on 3 key aspects: exterior design and materials, tech specs and hardware performance, and interface and ui. I will also point out outstanding and new features along the way. Exterior Design: Although at first the Galaxy S6 may not look completely different from the Galaxy S5, it is leaps and bounds ahead of its predecessor. The 2 sheets of Gorilla Glass 4 adorning the front and back make the phone feel extremely premium, resolving common complaint about the previous generation. It has a full metal band surrounding it, rather than a faux plastic one. Now, the feel in hand is comparable to the iPhone 6, and the design is elegant while familiar. The Black Sapphire color on the back shimmers beautifully in the light, changing into an almost purple/dark blue shade. Since the phone is so thin at 6.8 mm, the camera module protrudes slightly from the chassis, however it does not affect the phone. There is a sapphire lens to protect the camera, but placing the phone in a case should alleviate the protruding camera issue. Going to the front. there is a typical rectangular home button with a recent apps capacitive key on the left, with a back key on the right. Overall, the Galaxy S6 is the best phone Samsung has ever designed; however, the sealed battery and absence of a micro SD card slot may upset many. I do not replace the batteries in my phone nor add SD cards for storage, but customers from the Galaxy devices before may be unhappy. Tech Specs, Hardware Performance, Notable Features: The Galaxy in real life and on paper is a monster! Screen: It packs an amazing 5.1 Super AMOLED screen with a resolution of 2560x1440. The screen is capable of bright whites and dark blacks, and is the best mobile display currently on the market. Although Super AMOLED screens tend to have overly saturated colors, choosing AMOLED Cinema mode in settings creates natural colors. Fingerprint Scanner: Instead of a swipe based sensor, the new fingerprint scanner embedded in the home button is a capacitive touch based sensor, like the one on the iPhone 6. All you do is place your finger on the home button to unlock the phone. You can set up a total of 4 fingers, and the sensor is extremely reliable and useful. Every person using this phone should have the fingerprint sensor turned on since it provides good security while being intuitive to use. Camera: The camera is a 16 megapixel sensor with OIS. The Galaxy S6 has the best camera out of all Android phones, and easily competes with the iPhone 6 Plus. Because of the higher resolution, images are extremely detailed. The Optical Imaging Stabilization ensures pictures are clear, while videos are buttery smooth. The OIS also helps at night, as the sensor can pull in more light without creating a blurry image. The result is an amazing camera that can produce vibrant and beautiful pictures during the day, and a camera that can create accurate and bright pictures at night. The camera is also capable of 4K video recording, and slow motion video as well. An important new feature the Galaxy S6 incorporates is the double click on home button to activate. When you double click the home button, it opens the camera in less than 1 second! The "just shoot" mentality this camera gives its users is simply amazing and unmatched. For the pro users out there, the camera includes a professional mode that users can use to adjust ISO, white balance, and more settings. The front camera is 5 megapixels, and it is a strong front facing camera. Not much can be said about it, but it produces beautiful selfies and good colors, and is more than adequate for all users. Quick Charging and Wireless Charging: The Galaxy S6 is capable of adaptive quick charging using the charger supplied in the box. This charges the Galaxy S6 extremely fast; you can get about 4 hours of use

Textual Messages: Oh, Another year 2015. Another set of phones from manufacturers! I have been hooked onto get the latest phone every year syndrome and love reviewing specifics. Disclaimer, I love Android and have been using from very early days. Samsung Galaxy S6 tries to be a revolutionary, but it is evolutionary. If you have an older phone more than 2 years old, absolutely get this. So do check local specs. I played around with both S6 and S6 Edge for few days and my opinions are based on this. There are tons of reviews going into lot of details, so I am focused on few other aspects like what’s out there and how to compare specs. First Big Changes: No microSD or removable battery. I know many of you loyal Samsung fans says BUMMER! I was a die hard fan of Samsung till S4, then I went to LG G2/G3. I think this is the best bet for S6 to pull it off after a dismal year for Samsung last year. I was very curious to try out S6 and HTC One M9 as they are most talked about now. Many manufacturers are going away from microSD card slots and this is absolutely a must and is a key differentiator from iPhone. I am really sad Samsung decided to drop microSD card slot as well as no removable battery. Why?! Screen is a beauty on S6 – Just Gorgeous. Just go to a retail store and feel it! The Edge feature is still gimmicky. Unlike Note Edge, this has both sides so less dorky but still I am not sold yet. Unless you have loads of money, I will shy away from it for one more year and get it next year when they polish it up. It is certainly fancy and nice to show off, but I would rather buy an Android wear watch like Motorola 360 or Samsung Gear or LG R series. I like Motorola 360 but waiting for version 2 to appear. I like Round watches. IF YOU HAVE LAST YEAR model of any phone, PLEASE DON’T upgrade. Phones are becoming so standard and power packed it makes no sense to upgrade and waste money every year. I buy and sell so many phones as it is like a hobby for me, but I stick to one phone as primary for couple of years now. My main requirements are a 128 GB microSD, good screen, battery life and performance. I am trying hard to see if I can live without one. S6 and S6 Edge comes in a 128 GB variant and I will wait for prices to stabilize on this model. In my opinion, following are key specs to consider when you buying a phone. Most of others are standard or does not matter at all. First size, weight and resolution are part of look and feel. RAM/CPU part of performance. external Storage is part of expandability. Camera is obvious! SAR (Specific Absorption Rating) is an often ignored, but I feel essential to making a buying choice. Manufacturers don’t advertise or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S6: 5.65 x 2.78 x 0.27 in, 138 gm, 1440 x 2560 pixels, 5.1 in, 577 ppi, 3 GB RAM, NO MICROSD SLOT (bummer), Internal Storage upto 128 GB, Exynos 7420 Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex-A57, Gorilla Glass 4, 16 MP/5MP camera, SAR 1.15 W/kg (head), 1.16 W/kg (body) NANO SIM Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge: Slightly lower dimensions, 0.01 in thicker, 6 gm less weight, Same resolution, Curved Screen, HTC One M9: 5.69 x 2.74 x 0.38 in, 157 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 3 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 20.7 MP (rear), 4 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 810, Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2 GHz Cortex-A57 Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G3: 5.76 x 2.94 x 0.35 in, 149 gm, 2560 x 1440 pixels, 5.5 in, 538 pp
