Textual Messages: I have been using the S6 for about 4 days now. My first impressions: It's beautiful, well made. The screen is excellent. Works great under direct sun light too. It's fast, very responsive. Call quality is excellent Finger print unlock features works very well. Much better than the S5 CONS: It's slippery - my wife dropped her 4 times the first day she got hers. Yikes. But it didn't break! I got her a case now... Battery life is average Example: it's 100% at bed time, by morning it's at 80%. I didn't use the phone that whole time as I was sleeping. I do not have alot of aps on the phone yet. ocation is turned off. I do have 2 emails synching, one is Yahoo and the other for work and it's set to synch every hour. Fully charged in the morning, I am down to 80% by noon. I check emails, FB in the AM then it sits on my desk mostly unused during work, other than a quick check at lunch. I used it some to check FB and and emails later and it was down to about 20% by 8 PM. My wife uses her phone more than me and gets similar numbers. My son today, at noon, was at 52%. He uses it alot as he plays various games. So I am not impressed with battery life ; I absolutely DO NOT recommend the S6 if you are a heavy user.

Helpful: 10 of 10 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Wow, what a difference a year makes. While last year's S5 took many steps in the right direction(being somewhat waterproof with better material and craftsmanship), it still wasn't there to make it a mouth-watering phone yet, like what HTC did when they first introduced their One M7, or whenever Apple introduces a new iPhone size. This year, Samsung has finally learned from both of their competitors, and made a phone that has all the good qualities of both, plus some of their own. Finally, this is the Galaxy S that you've always wanted and been dreaming of. * LOOKS/FORM-FACTOR/MATERIALS: The very first thing you notice when you handle the phone, is its new design and form factor - finally Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful. The metal fully wraps around the edges ofthe phone. The back is beautiful, the sides are beautiful - heck, even the buttons are beautiful. It feels great in the hand, and oozes style and sophistication. * SCREEN: The very next thing you notice, of course, is the screen. I am continually pleasantly surprised at the evolution of Samsung's AMOLED technology - it has now became the best screen in the industry, hands down. I used to defend the LCD technology of the HTC M7, and at that point it was in fact overall superior to the Samsung S4 because the AMOLED then had issues in the sun, and color reproduction(it was too saturated and not natural). But now, they have fixed those issues, and the S6's screen is just quite simply the best. If you don't believe it, just compare an LG/Samsung OLED TV to any LED TVs today. I still think 5.1 inches for a screen of a PHONE is still too big, but overall, for what smartphones represent nowadays, it is acceptable - we have conditioned ourselves to accept the bigger sizes of smartphones(I remember when I first held a 4.2" smartphone when it first came out - the HTC HD2 - and thought, "what the h3ll is this monstrosity??"). * It doesn't hurt that Samsung boosted up the resolution to 1440 x 2560 pixels, which is approximately 577 ppi in pixel density. Although this is quite overkill right now, it's always nice to have the latest and greatest technology - that's the reason why we buy these overpriced phones in the first place, isn't it? It is also very bright, and sunlit legibility is excellent. Color reproduction is quite accurate, and like the S5, you can choose different color modes to suit your liking. *BATTERY LIFE: An important aspect to discuss is the battery life, now more than ever because there is no removable back cover to make replacing the battery easily like before, not to mention there is no microSD slot for you to add memory space to your phone. Comparatively, the S6 Edge is supposed to last a little less than the S6 regular, which I've read is less than last year's S5. But I'm one of those who are always around a charger, and I always carry external battery packs in my backpack when I travel, so that's never a concern. Seriously, who even buys an extra battery anymore - which you can only use for a single specific phone model - when your external battery can charge ANY and ALL phones and tablets?? This scenario only makes sense if your work is so demanding that you don't have extra time to charge the phone, and need to swap batteries IMMEDIATELY. I don't think that scenario is realistic nowadays when external batteries are so small, light, and cheap. My S6 goes from 100% at 10 am to about 20% at 10 pm with moderate use - so no complaints there. I get home, plug it up, and there are no issues. * What's better this year, is the wireless charging standards are already built into the phone, so you can just buy a charging pad for about $50 and feel even more cool. * USER INTERFACE/SOFTWARE: The Samsung user interface called TouchWiz used to be bloated and sluggish. It would slow down(navigating throughout the phone, switching between apps, and using

Helpful: 13 of 14 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: For readers, my opinions on this device (ATT 32Gb version) is based off the experiences I had with this device for the passed few hours as today is launch day (April 10, 2015). I will continue to update this review in the future. This review should be the similar to Galaxy S6 on other carriers such as Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile. Pros: - No more plastics and cheap material. Samsung is finally giving us the hardware that we've long desired. By far, the best designed Galaxy phone to date imo - 5.1 in, QHD Super AMOLED screen. The screen is absolutely gorgeous that it hurts my eyes a bit. I'm still adjusting to it. - 16MP Camera with Smart OIS and 5MP front camera. Very well specs, but even better in performance. In short, the best camera on any android phones. I cannot believe that the picture came out so well in low light environment. You have to try it yourself to believe how great these low light pictures come out. - Gorilla Glass 4 panels for front and back (reminds me of the iPhone 4 and Nexus 4). Gorilla Glass are known to be tough and scratch resistance. - Comes in various colors: White, black, gold, green, blue (US only get the white, black, and gold unfortunately) - Comes in 32, 64, or 128GB of built-in memory. (For the 32gb - 3.7gb is for system partition, 25.2 for data/apps/pictures) - Less of the TouchWiz’s gimmicky features like the eye scroll, eye away from the screen pause. So we will not be experiencing the same slowdown or low storage as we did with earlier versions. If the GS4/5 were all about the features, this phone is all about the design. I do like the camera app and how they add a "close all" into the recent screen. - Rapid charging (need to use this more to confirm their claim of 4hrs of battery in 10 minute charge - UPDATED 5/1/15 i am getting about 1 to 1 1/2 hrs of use after the 10 minute charge, I'm guessing the 4hr claim is idle??) - Wireless charging - So if you have extra money that you want to drop for a wireless charging dock, you will be able to use it with this phone. Cons (Not necessarily apply to everyone): - No removable back panel. - No removable battery. I’m a battery hog, so I’m always draining my battery by 3-4pm. Not being able to just swap out my battery will be a pain, but let’s wait to see if the battery swap will be needed in a month when I fully test this device. - Lower battery capacity - 2550mAh compared to the 2600mAh in GS4 and 2800mAh in GS5. With the new processor, battery usage should be more efficient so it should not be a big deal, but end-users would rather the capacity to increase than decrease (Will update if this make through a day of normal usage, UPDATED 5/1/15 - I'm getting average about 8-9 hrs of normal usage, not ideal but I'll manage) - No waterproofing like the GS5, but I never used a smartphone that was waterproofed before, so not a big issue "to me" - No ability to swap out memory card – Might bother some Galaxy fans, but with the higher memory options, I do not think this is a huge problem. - Still no on-screen navigation button – Might only be a problem for "pure" Android fan. - Rear Camera and Flash sticks out a bit and not flush with the back panel. - Front and back glass is a potential problem as we all experiences with iPhone 4 and Nexus 4. Glass will break if you drop your phone at the right angle regardless how much stronger it is, so "case up". - The 1 speaker at the bottom is louder, however when you turn it on max, you will get some distortions in the audio quality. - There are some apps on there that I prefer downloading myself rather than them pushing it on me. There are some Social apps or Microsoft apps included such as OneDrive, facebook, etc. I personally use these apps, but there are people who don't. - I have been experiencing some weird stutters/lags while messing around the phone. This might because I'm loading a bunch of apps into it right now. I will need a few more days to look into this. Overall, this feels like a this is a solid de

Textual Messages: I have been using the S6 for about 4 days now. My first impressions: It's beautiful, well made. The screen is excellent. Works great under direct sun light too. It's fast, very responsive. Call quality is excellent Finger print unlock features works very well. Much better than the S5 CONS: It's slippery - my wife dropped her 4 times the first day she got hers. Yikes. But it didn't break! I got her a case now... Battery life is average Example: it's 100% at bed time, by morning it's at 80%. I didn't use the phone that whole time as I was sleeping. I do not have alot of aps on the phone yet. ocation is turned off. I do have 2 emails synching, one is Yahoo and the other for work and it's set to synch every hour. Fully charged in the morning, I am down to 80% by noon. I check emails, FB in the AM then it sits on my desk mostly unused during work, other than a quick check at lunch. I used it some to check FB and and emails later and it was down to about 20% by 8 PM. My wife uses her phone more than me and gets similar numbers. My son today, at noon, was at 52%. He uses it alot as he plays various games. So I am not impressed with battery life ; I DO NOT recommend the S6 if you are a heavy user. Update 19th April I've not had the phone for over a week now. The screen is fantastic. My monthly Google calendar shows up on 1 screen, and it's easy to read all the events on it. I can actually use the phone in bright sunlight, something I haven't been able to do well with prior cell phones. There was an Samsung push update which appears to have helped the battery life, and I for that reason have raised the rating from 3 to 4 stars. The battery now lasts me all day, with casual uses. If you are a heavy user, this phone will not last you all day without a re-charge by 2 PM. The good news is that a 10-15 minute recharge will give you a 30-40% or so battery boost and the phone can be >90% in about one hour. I still do not recommend the phone for heavy ap users (gamers). You'll need to consider the Samsung note or the Droid phones as I can't see the S6 lasting past 2 PM for those individuals.

Textual Messages: Oh, Another year 2015. Another set of phones from manufacturers! I have been hooked onto get the latest phone every year syndrome and love reviewing specifics. Disclaimer, I love Android and have been using from very early days. Samsung Galaxy S6 tries to be a revolutionary, but it is evolutionary. If you have an older phone more than 2 years old, absolutely get this. So do check local specs. I played around with both S6 and S6 Edge for few days and my opinions are based on this. There are tons of reviews going into lot of details, so I am focused on few other aspects like what’s out there and how to compare specs. First Big Changes: No microSD or removable battery. I know many of you loyal Samsung fans says BUMMER! I was a die hard fan of Samsung till S4, then I went to LG G2/G3. I think this is the best bet for S6 to pull it off after a dismal year for Samsung last year. I was very curious to try out S6 and HTC One M9 as they are most talked about now. Many manufacturers are going away from microSD card slots and this is absolutely a must and is a key differentiator from iPhone. I am really sad Samsung decided to drop microSD card slot as well as no removable battery. Why?! Screen is a beauty on S6 – Just Gorgeous. Just go to a retail store and feel it! The Edge feature is still gimmicky. Unlike Note Edge, this has both sides so less dorky but still I am not sold yet. Unless you have loads of money, I will shy away from it for one more year and get it next year when they polish it up. It is certainly fancy and nice to show off, but I would rather buy an Android wear watch like Motorola 360 or Samsung Gear or LG R series. I like Motorola 360 but waiting for version 2 to appear. I like Round watches. IF YOU HAVE LAST YEAR model of any phone, PLEASE DON’T upgrade. Phones are becoming so standard and power packed it makes no sense to upgrade and waste money every year. I buy and sell so many phones as it is like a hobby for me, but I stick to one phone as primary for couple of years now. My main requirements are a 128 GB microSD, good screen, battery life and performance. I am trying hard to see if I can live without one. S6 and S6 Edge comes in a 128 GB variant and I will wait for prices to stabilize on this model. In my opinion, following are key specs to consider when you buying a phone. Most of others are standard or does not matter at all. First size, weight and resolution are part of look and feel. RAM/CPU part of performance. external Storage is part of expandability. Camera is obvious! SAR (Specific Absorption Rating) is an often ignored, but I feel essential to making a buying choice. Manufacturers don’t advertise or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S6: 5.65 x 2.78 x 0.27 in, 138 gm, 1440 x 2560 pixels, 5.1 in, 577 ppi, 3 GB RAM, NO MICROSD SLOT (bummer), Internal Storage upto 128 GB, Exynos 7420 Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex-A57, Gorilla Glass 4, 16 MP/5MP camera, SAR 1.15 W/kg (head), 1.16 W/kg (body) NANO SIM Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge: Slightly lower dimensions, 0.01 in thicker, 6 gm less weight, Same resolution, Curved Screen, HTC One M9: 5.69 x 2.74 x 0.38 in, 157 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 3 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 20.7 MP (rear), 4 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 810, Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2 GHz Cortex-A57 Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G3: 5.76 x 2.94 x 0.35 in, 149 gm, 2560 x 1440 pixels, 5.5 in, 538 pp

Textual Messages: Wow, what a difference a year makes. While last year's S5 took many steps in the right direction(being somewhat waterproof with better material and craftsmanship), it still wasn't there to make it a mouth-watering phone yet, like what HTC did when they first introduced their One M7, or whenever Apple introduces a new iPhone size. This year, Samsung has finally learned from both of their competitors, and made a phone that has all the good qualities of both, plus some of their own. Finally, this is the Galaxy S that you've always wanted and been dreaming of. * LOOKS/FORM-FACTOR/MATERIALS: The very first thing you notice when you handle the phone, is its new design and form factor - finally Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful. The metal fully wraps around the edges ofthe phone. The back is beautiful, the sides are beautiful - heck, even the buttons are beautiful. It feels great in the hand, and oozes style and sophistication. * SCREEN: The very next thing you notice, of course, is the screen. I am continually pleasantly surprised at the evolution of Samsung's AMOLED technology - it has now became the best screen in the industry, hands down. I used to defend the LCD technology of the HTC M7, and at that point it was in fact overall superior to the Samsung S4 because the AMOLED then had issues in the sun, and color reproduction(it was too saturated and not natural). But now, they have fixed those issues, and the S6's screen is just quite simply the best. If you don't believe it, just compare an LG/Samsung OLED TV to any LED TVs today. I still think 5.1 inches for a screen of a PHONE is still too big, but overall, for what smartphones represent nowadays, it is acceptable - we have conditioned ourselves to accept the bigger sizes of smartphones(I remember when I first held a 4.2" smartphone when it first came out - the HTC HD2 - and thought, "what the h3ll is this monstrosity??"). * It doesn't hurt that Samsung boosted up the resolution to 1440 x 2560 pixels, which is approximately 577 ppi in pixel density. Although this is quite overkill right now, it's always nice to have the latest and greatest technology - that's the reason why we buy these overpriced phones in the first place, isn't it? It is also very bright, and sunlit legibility is excellent. Color reproduction is quite accurate, and like the S5, you can choose different color modes to suit your liking. *BATTERY LIFE: An important aspect to discuss is the battery life, now more than ever because there is no removable back cover to make replacing the battery easily like before, not to mention there is no microSD slot for you to add memory space to your phone. Comparatively, the S6 Edge is supposed to last a little less than the S6 regular, which I've read is less than last year's S5. But I'm one of those who are always around a charger, and I always carry external battery packs in my backpack when I travel, so that's never a concern. Seriously, who even buys an extra battery anymore - which you can only use for a single specific phone model - when your external battery can charge ANY and ALL phones and tablets?? This scenario only makes sense if your work is so demanding that you don't have extra time to charge the phone, and need to swap batteries IMMEDIATELY. I don't think that scenario is realistic nowadays when external batteries are so small, light, and cheap. My S6 goes from 100% at 10 am to about 20% at 10 pm with moderate use - so no complaints there. I get home, plug it up, and there are no issues. * What's better this year, is the wireless charging standards are already built into the phone, so you can just buy a charging pad for about $50 and feel even more cool. * USER INTERFACE/SOFTWARE: The Samsung user interface called TouchWiz used to be bloated and sluggish. It would slow down(navigating throughout the phone, switching between apps, and using

Textual Messages: This year, Samsung kept everything much more simple, intuitive, and beautiful. As a result, the Galaxy S6 is the best smartphone any person can currently. My review will focus on 3 key aspects: exterior design and materials, tech specs and hardware performance, and interface and ui. I will also point out outstanding and new features along the way. Exterior Design: Although at first the Galaxy S6 may not look completely different from the Galaxy S5, it is leaps and bounds ahead of its predecessor. The 2 sheets of Gorilla Glass 4 adorning the front and back make the phone feel extremely premium, resolving common complaint about the previous generation. It has a full metal band surrounding it, rather than a faux plastic one. Now, the feel in hand is comparable to the iPhone 6, and the design is elegant while familiar. Since the phone is so thin at 6.8 mm, the camera module protrudes slightly from the chassis, however it does not affect the phone. There is a sapphire lens to protect the camera, but placing the phone in a case should alleviate the protruding camera issue. Going to the front. there is a typical rectangular home button with a recent apps capacitive key on the left, with a back key on the right. Overall, the Galaxy S6 is the best phone Samsung has ever designed; however, the sealed battery and absence of a micro SD card slot may upset many. I do not replace the batteries in my phone nor add SD cards for storage, but customers from the Galaxy devices before may be unhappy. Tech Specs, Hardware Performance, Notable Features: The Galaxy in real life and on paper is a monster! Screen: It packs an amazing 5.1 Super AMOLED screen with a resolution of 2560x1440. The screen is capable of bright whites and dark blacks, and is the best mobile display currently on the market. Although Super AMOLED screens tend to have overly saturated colors, choosing AMOLED Cinema mode in settings creates natural colors. Fingerprint Scanner: Instead of a swipe based sensor, the new fingerprint scanner embedded in the home button is a capacitive touch based sensor, like the one on the iPhone 6. All you do is place your finger on the home button to unlock the phone. You can set up a total of 4 fingers, and the sensor is extremely reliable and useful. Every person using this phone should have the fingerprint sensor turned on since it provides good security while being intuitive to use. Camera: The camera is a 16 megapixel sensor with OIS. The Galaxy S6 has the best camera out of all Android phones, and easily competes with the iPhone 6 Plus. Because of the higher resolution, images are extremely detailed. The Optical Imaging Stabilization ensures pictures are clear, while videos are buttery smooth. The OIS also helps at night, as the sensor can pull in more light without creating a blurry image. The result is an amazing camera that can produce vibrant and beautiful pictures during the day, and a camera that can create accurate and bright pictures at night. The camera is also capable of 4K video recording, and slow motion video as well. An important new feature the Galaxy S6 incorporates is the double click on home button to activate. When you double click the home button, it opens the camera in less than 1 second! The "just shoot" mentality this camera gives its users is simply amazing and unmatched. For the pro users out there, the camera includes a professional mode that users can use to adjust ISO, white balance, and more settings. The front camera is 5 megapixels, and it is a strong front facing camera. Not much can be said about it, but it produces beautiful selfies and good colors, and is more than adequate for all users. Quick Charging and Wireless Charging: The Galaxy S6 is capable of adaptive quick charging using the charger supplied in the box. This charges the Galaxy S6 extremely fast; you can get about 4 hours of use only with 10 minutes of charging. The phone also supports other Qualcomm Quick Chargers. The Galaxy S6 also supports the

Textual Messages: The Galaxy s 6 isn't just another iteration of the same old same the Galaxy s 6 is a brand new phone built from the ground up. Everything about it screams that it wants to be the beast of all smart phones! OK let face it most of us who are adults and have maintained a phone plan for years have been using smartphones for the better part of a decade. The joys of gimmicky apps that make you look old or fat or really anything else have faded away, our smart phones have become important tools to us that we use for very adult things like keeping I touch paying bills and checking and sending emails and yes Instagram! Truth is we don't think much about these little unsung hero's living in our pockets or perses these days and just about nothing about them gets us too excited any more. Truth be told me and my wife only upgraded our phones because she dropped hers from half way up an 120ft ride at an amusement park. Needless to say her iPhone was destroyed so we knew it was new phone time. My wife has owned just about every iPhone and I have owned the Galaxy s 1,2,4 and now 6. The Galaxy s line were easily the best smartphones of the market where the 1,5 2 even three came out but the 4 and 5 were honestly nothing special. To be honest the s4 was going to be my last galaxy phone I was sure I was going to switch. It's not a big deal that they were mostly plastic I mean most electronics are, and the external part of the hardware was actually quite sturdy I've dropped all mine more the a few times through the years. There have been dings and dents but never ever a cracked screens and trust me there have been doozies! The problems with the Galaxy line were all internal, it was always a hardware issue that couldn't be fixed with an update that involved. Shipping it back to Samsung. Dude these are phones that basically cost a grand there brand new and I have to send them back to Samsung I mean come on?! My galaxy s1 would shut it's self off in your pocket, trust me it's annoying. My s2 got returned to the store for a bad screen. (in the s2 defence it was the greatest galaxy phone until the s6 in my opinion). My s4 oh my s4 this was the most annoying of all, it had a problem where it would eject my Sim at random causing me to loose phone and I internet signal, by the end I was ready to part from its company. Listen I'm not what you would call a phone activist if you like Apple great if you like android great. Personally I like them both android for my phone and apple for its iPad line witch is great for getting business done. Like I said I prefer android on my phone personally I think it's openness makes it better for a phone compared to apples "walled garden". So I was hopefull some day android would get apples beautiful sturdy superior hardware while running on Android that day has come! While I know Samsung wasn't the first in the Android world I think they have done it the best. Every thing about is quality, gone is all that plastic it's replaced by a glass front and back panel and a metal rim very apple like gone are the old creeks and clicks of the old gs phones. The fake silver paint that used to adorn the edges of so many gs phones is gone replaced by real metal. Trust me this phone is beautiful in my opinion the most beautiful android phone to date. The screen The screen on this little guy is amazing. Images look sharp and crisp, colors are bright and bold. Some people don't like this about Samsung amaloid screens where as I have always loved it. Things just look happier on Samsung amaloid screens, may be it's not as realistic but I don't care about that. Truth be told amaloid screens are one of the main reasons the gs line keeps me coming back, other companies screens no matter how many pixels just don't pop like amaloid displays do! That being the case the gs6 display has gone above and beyond here, look close and you won't see a single pixel. But to all this beauty the downside is a screen that drains your battery and quick. Textual Messages: I have had this phone for 5 days now and I figured I would review my experience with the phone so far. The phone its self is absolutely amazing. Best display on a smartphone to date, best camera on a smartphone, beefy tech specs, attractive design, etc. All of this should warrant a 5 star review right? Wrong. The battery life on this phone is absolutely terrible. I have done my research and went out of my way to remove bloatware, adjust phone settings to conserve power, every little trick I could find online and still the battery life is not good enough for me to say "it is a reliable phone". The sad thing is that I don't think it is Samsung's fault. I think it has more to do with the wireless carrier (in my case Verizon, but I hear same issues exist with AT&T). Basically, I will charge my phone up to 100% (fast charge is great and works as advertised), then I just watch my battery drain even when my phone is inactive laying on my desk top. When I look at the battery statistics, something called "call standby" drains the phone battery even when I am not using it. In fact, it is by far the biggest battery drain on the phone even over a 4k super amoled display with full brightness. What the heck is going on Verizon? I looked into it further and saw many other people having the same issue. I noticed that my phone is always sending and receiving information to the Verizon network even when I am not using the phone. What is being sent? Does this have something to do with the NSA? Seriously. Last night I charged my phone to 100% just before bed, I cleared all apps loaded on the RAM just to see how what the battery percentage would be like in the morning and just sitting there on my night stand my phone drained 43% of the battery. Honestly, if this issue is not fixed, I am going to reactivate my old galaxy s5. I never had this issue on my s5. Hope this issue gets resolved soon or Verizon and Samsung just lost a long time customer.

Textual Messages: Let me preface this with the following: 1. I've only had this phone a few days so I will likely have to edit this later and 2. I had an iPhone previously that I am still quite fond of. My iPhone 5 had started showing its age and experience serious lag issues. So after beating a dead horse with research I'd come down to the iPhone 6 or the Galaxy 6 -and part of me i still weighing the pros/cons - I decided on the Galaxy S6. These were the big decision makers for me: 1. 32GB, minimum memory, is apprx. $23/month using AT&T Next which is less than the 32GB mid tier iPhone 6 2. Samsung and Google have developed a very stable product 3. Camera and pixel density were a huge improvement over either my iPhone 5 or the 6 4. Samsung's Smart Switch App 5. It has two power save modes. I've heard a LOT about the battery life on this device being "eh", and experienced it some, granted I'm in transition mode. So I've switched on one of the power save modes. If memory serves, there isn't a power save mode on any iPhone. 6. MICRO USB -- i have lord know how many of these cords and they've all proven compatible without any issues (unlike a few of my lightning cables). The detractors: BLOATWARE!!! There's so much of it, however, you CAN disable those apps you don't like or want to use and I've done so. Otherwise it has all the same usability and functionality I would expect with an iPhone. So long as it continues to perform well and not give me any real issues. The learning curve between iPhone and the current Galaxy S6 is nominal at best. With that said, even if I ultimately return it at the end of my 14 day return period (which I probably won't...), it still deserves a 4.5-5 star rating because it's a fantastic device. Not too big, fairly easy to adjust too, and it's fun.

Textual Messages: I was skeptical at first, but Samsung did a great job with this phone. Here are my thoughts on the phone *The screen is huge and beautiful. I sometimes forget I'm even looking at a screen. The colors are accurate, deep, and rich. The pixels are so plentiful that you can't even tell it's a screen. It moves so fluidly while watching videos. They did a stellar job. *The phone feels great in your hand. It feels like a quality phone. It is easy to hold. I am a small female and I can easily use the phone one handed. I don't worry about breaking it every second because it feels sturdy and well built. It never feels hot. It's not slippery, yet it slides easily in and out of a pocket or purse. *TouchWiz is definitely toned down. It still doesn't look like true Android OS, but it definitely looks better and runs more smooth. It was a huge improvement and TouchWiz now has more positives than negatives. *While there is still bloatware on the phone that you cannot get rid of without rooting your phone, it is way toned down from previous Samsung phones. Even the bloatware you're stuck with can be hidden - you can disable the app and/or completely hide it from view anywhere on the phone. So while it still takes up space, you can easily pretend it isn't there. *Battery life is great AFTER you make adjustments. Turn on Power Saving Mode at all times. You won't notice a difference in the functionality of your phone, but it will add to battery life. Also disable background data on apps that you don't need notifications from - I disabled it on apps like the Play Store. Finally, make sure you set the Play Store to only update apps on WiFi so you don't use massive amounts of data. *Ultra Power Save Mode is neat when you must use it. Your phone will look like a basic grayscale screen with only access to basic things like phone calls and texting. Everything else is shut down. It's great for emergencies when you need your phone to still work, can't charge it, and the battery is super low. It will last for days! *The themes are a lot of fun. If you don't like or get bored with the look of the UI, you can change it with themes. They have a ton of them available for free now and you can switch amongst them in just a few seconds. It's a lot of fun! *I like that you can change the size of the screens to fit more icons if needed. It's a very handy feature for people who want to fit more on one screen! It adds more to your homescreen without making things smaller. *The Google Calendar widget is not the native Google Calendar widget. It only shows you a month view which isn't very helpful. I had to download the real Google Calendar from the Play Store and it allows me to still have the agenda style widget. Annoying, but an easy fix. *I have crappy fingerprints so the fingerprint scanner doesn't work super well for me. However, considering what an awful time most things have reading my fingerprint, this does relatively well. I have tested many other people's fingerprints (including immediate family) and it will never unlock for them. So it has exceeded my expectations. It also reads super fast which just a quick swipe. *Call quality is great. I always receive my calls and other people always sound great and they always sound great to me. I don't ever seen to drop calls or have poor reception. *One small annoyance is the light that blinks to tell you that you have a notification... it's very slow. I have to stare at my phone for a good 7-8 seconds to see it blink each time. I wish the blink speed was faster so it would be easier to tell if I had a notification. *The rapid charging feature is AMAZING!!! It still shocks me how fast the phone really does charge. Even when I use my phone a ton and the battery does drop, a quick 10-15 minute charge gives me about a whole days worth right there! It's such a lifesaver. Just remember that it only works with the included charger or another charger that puts out more power. It won't worth with any standard charger. *I li

Textual Messages: I have both an iPhone 6 (personal) and the Galaxy S6 (work) and here's what I can tell you after using both: The S6 is the first and only android I have tested that feels as smooth and natural as an iPhone. You really have to credit Apple who was able to develop an OS that has been quite fluid through their previous generations of iPhones. Kudos for Samsung for finally bringing this fluidity to Android users (and SHAME on Apple for "bricking" my older iPhones with their updates. I swear they do that on purpose to force you to upgrade.) Both these phones feel almost identical in the hand. I hate the S6 camera protrusion. I am in constant fear of breaking the lens. I know I can use a case but I do not like to use cases under normal circumstances. Putting a case on these stunning phones is tantamount to putting a trench coat on Sofia Vergara. Plus it makes the phone feel larger. I feel way more confident with the iPhone. The iPhone's camera, while technically being inferior, seems to take better photos overall. This has been hit and miss. The iPhone fingerprint reader is superior. The S6 is better than the S5 but still lagging behind. The surface area of the reader is a long oval vs. a perfect circle. I rarely have misreads with the iPhone while the Samsung sometimes doesn't read my print correctly. The Samsung's screen is STUNNING. The iPhone is no slouch but in this case AMOLED beats Retina. The Samsung is fast. I mean fast. Everything it does is fast. Unfortunately the battery drains just as fast. Fortunately, the fast charging option works FAST and a cheap aftermarket wireless charger is just a wonderful option. There is an ultra low power mode which reverts your phone to a circa 1990s Motorola StarTac (black & white screen and all!) but it really stretches out your battery life. I rarely use my charging cable anymore. I really do wish however that I had the option to replace my battery though. The iPhone battery life stinks as well but the S6 is worse. The S6 has more options to compensate. Internet browsing and phone calls are nearly identical. The iPhone speaker is a bit louder and sounds better. I really hate Apple lately but you just can't beat iTunes or the Apple store for apps. Google play and Amazon just feel second rate. Some dual platform apps feel better on the iPhone while others feel better on the Galaxy. Google doesn't have the personality of Siri but I find it is easier and more accurate. Also, the Google app is always listening and doesn't require a key press to activate. This is both convenient and unnerving since I sometimes believe Google is the devil. The GUIs both have their quirks and advantages. I feel that Android, while having more options and customization, has always felt like an OS on top of an OS. Always endless menus to get things done. I guess this is the price that comes with the power to customize. Samsung has made navigation much easier with this last version of their TouchWiz and most of the bloat is gone. I love the "back" key on Android. As an iPhone user you don't miss it until you have a phone that offers it...especially if you like one-handed operation. I still believe iPhone has the advantage here. FaceTime rocks. I don't care what any Android user thinks but connectivity to all things Apple is just so cool. FaceTime is just one facet of this. Android diehards probably won't understand this. I miss an SD slot. Whether it was Blackberry, Android, etc., I have carried my photos, videos, documents, etc. from all my previous non-iPhone devices to newer models in a seamless fashion. Continuation... I just compared video taken with both phones (same locations) on my 60" LED TV. The S6 looks like it was taken with a dedicated camcorder. My guests could not believe the quality. I don't have a 4K TV but the difference between the two was noticeable on the big screen. Maybe its the lens? Maybe the pre/post processing? Maybe a combination of several factors. The iPhone however did seem to balance

Textual Messages: I got a chance to test a Galaxy S6 out and immediately bought one for my wife. I'm a complete phone nerd (XDA Developers Recognized Contributor, if that means anything to you) so I massively over analyze these things. It's a VERY nice phone but it's got some things that I consider drawbacks. For my wife, all the drawbacks listed below were non issues. She didn't care about these issues. So understand that my 'drawbacks' are completely subjective to your personal needs. But they are things that you should be aware of and consider if they mean anything to you before purchasing. ?????THE UPSIDES????? ? The screen is incredible. Like really incredible. The resolution is better than my eye can see. I use a Galaxy S4 as my regular phone and it has great resolution where you can't see individual pixels. I thought the S4 screen was as good as you can get, but the S6 screen takes it to a whole new level. Even though you can't see pixels on either screen, the higher resolution of the S6 screen makes everything look so sharp that it's nearly impossible to tell you are looking at a screen. It's that incredible. ? The design of the phone just feels more 'expensive'. I mean that in a good way. It feels just higher quality than previous models in the Galaxy S line. The S3 and S4 for example are often critiqued for having a plastic shell. The S6 has a metal band around the outside that just makes it feel 'premium' in your hand. It should also provide more protection for the device as well. ? TouchWiz is HEAVILY scaled back. I hate TouchWiz (Samsung's version of Android) It adds a layer of UI that is neither helpful nor intuitive. And it's a resource hog which slows the phone down for important tasks just so it can make the scrolling smoother, and other such useless tradeoffs. On the S6 TouchWiz was barely noticeable. The UI looks more like the standard Google Android Lollipop interface. It was all just much smoother and simpler and better and wonderful. ? Camera. 16 MP. And the images it takes look stunning on the super HD screen. Those photos on a larger high resolution monitor are simply stunning. ?????THE DOWNSIDES????? ? The battery is not removable or easily replaceable. A cell phone battery has a life of about 500 charge cycles. I tend to keep my phones for 2 years as daily users, then I keep my old phones for a variety of other purposes around the house. (My old HTC Sensation is hooked up to my stereo for use as a nice wifi streaming media player with a touchscreen UI, for example) I eventually have a need to replace batteries because I wear them out. I like being able to go on Amazon, spent $20 on a replacement battery, pop it in and be done. Additionally, even if you don't keep your phones that long, batteries fail sometimes. The stock batteries on the Galaxy S4 had some problems. They were minimal, but for those affected the battery absolutely had to be replaced. On the S4 it took 8 seconds and the problem was solved. On the S6 I'm sure it would be covered by warranty but it'd be a pain to take it somewhere to have it worked on should the issue come up. So no replaceable battery is a deal killer for me. This might not be an issue for you. If not, great! But be aware of the issue before making purchase decisions. ? You can't expand the storage with an SD Card. I don't want to live in the cloud. I hate the cloud. Sometimes I'm not on an LTE network. Sometimes I'm in the middle of nowhere but still want to show someone pictures of my kids. I got my wife the 32GB model. That sounds like a lot, but keep in mind that some of that is dedicated for the operating system and user apps. So you don't get to use all 32GB. The S6 is going to be available in up to 128GB, which ends my problem with not liking the cloud option. Again, you might not care. If not, great! My wife doesn't keep a lot of stuff on her phone. She moves all her pictures to her computer and never loaded video to watch on her phone, so the storage thing wasn't a big deal to he

I know many of you loyal Samsung fans says BUMMER! I was a die hard fan of Samsung till S4, then I went to LG G2/G3. I think this is the best bet for S6 to pull it off after a dismal year for Samsung last year. I was very curious to try out S6 and HTC One M9 as they are most talked about now. Many manufacturers are going away from microSD card slots and this is absolutely a must and is a key differentiator from iPhone. I am really sad Samsung decided to drop microSD card slot as well as no removable battery. Why?! Screen is a beauty on S6 – Just Gorgeous. Just go to a retail store and feel it! The Edge feature is still gimmicky. Unlike Note Edge, this has both sides so less dorky but still I am not sold yet. Unless you have loads of money, I will shy away from it for one more year and get it next year when they polish it up. It is certainly fancy and nice to show off, but I would rather buy an Android wear watch like Motorola 360 or Samsung Gear or LG R series. I like Motorola 360 but waiting for version 2 to appear. I like Round watches. IF YOU HAVE LAST YEAR model of any phone, PLEASE DON’T upgrade. Phones are becoming so standard and power packed it makes no sense to upgrade and waste money every year. I buy and sell so many phones as it is like a hobby for me, but I stick to one phone as primary for couple of years now. My main requirements are a 128 GB microSD, good screen, battery life and performance. I am trying hard to see if I can live without one. S6 and S6 Edge comes in a 128 GB variant and I will wait for prices to stabilize on this model. In my opinion, following are key specs to consider when you buying a phone. Most of others are standard or does not matter at all. First size, weight and resolution are part of look and feel. RAM/CPU part of performance. external Storage is part of expandability. Camera is obvious! SAR (Specific Absorption Rating) is an often ignored, but I feel essential to making a buying choice. Manufacturers don’t advertise or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S6: 5.65 x 2.78 x 0.27 in, 138 gm, 1440 x 2560 pixels, 5.1 in, 577 ppi, 3 GB RAM, NO MICROSD SLOT (bummer), Internal Storage upto 128 GB, Exynos 7420 Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex-A57, Gorilla Glass 4, 16 MP/5MP camera, SAR 1.15 W/kg (head), 1.16 W/kg (body) NANO SIM Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge: Slightly lower dimensions, 0.01 in thicker, 6 gm less weight, Same resolution, Curved Screen, HTC One M9: 5.69 x 2.74 x 0.38 in, 157 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 3 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 20.7 MP (rear), 4 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 810, Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2 GHz Cortex-A57 Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G3: 5.76 x 2.94 x 0.35 in, 149 gm, 2560 x 1440 pixels, 5.5 in, 538 pp

Textual Messages: This is detailed, it’s long, it’s my personal experience, hopefully I can prove to the readers what real world use of the phone feels like. I owned a Samsung Galaxy S4 (T-Mobile) before acquiring my GS6 more than two weeks ago. I was unhappy with my GS4 but I stuck with it for 2 years, then came the GS6. It provides a lot of what I felt the GS4 was missing or not properly executing. I dislike riding the hype train and “upgrading” phones every year they are released so I passed on the Galaxy S5, even though it offers up some very important features I value, such as a waterproof body and expandable memory, which Samsung got rid of and is leaving some of those features for their “Samsung GS6 Active” phone released later this year no doubt.. »DESIGN« This phone completely resembles what would happen if and iphone and an Android had a baby, plenty of side by side photo comparisons to support my claim. I’ve never really cared about the metal vs. plastic, it’s all beef created from Apple vs. Android fans for the most part, but the aluminum + glass feels really good. Every single phone I have ever owned goes straight into a case from the moment I remove it from it’s original packaging. It’s it smart phone, and it’s a smart idea to protect it, with a phone case. I never really considered buying the Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge, because like the Galaxy S4, the GS6 Edge variant is one giant gimmick. The curved screen is the only reason someone would immediately know it’s an S6 vs a S5/S4. It’s also more expensive, for little to no good reason. »THE GUTS« Since I like to buy my phones every two years, I feel compelled to purchase the best my money can buy, so I go straight for the Flagships. This flagship phone comes with it’s own Samsung Exynos 7420 Octa-core Processor instead of a Snapdragon 810 (Battery Hog!) or a Snapdragon 808 (a 810 but with 2 processors turned off) like the LG G4 is featuring or maybe more phones releasing later this year. Not sure about you guys, but I don’t see the point in paying for last year’s technology. 5.1” QHD 2560x1440p Screen (any bigger and it gets harder to use with 1 hand) Lets talk about the camera for a moment. This is the best camera-phone I’ve had a chance to use, my brother who has had the Iphone 6 plus since the beginning of the year seems to agree with me, this coming from a heavy selfie/social media user. These cameras paired up with powerful software on newer phones are no laughing matter anymore. »16 MP Rear Camera »5 MP Front Camera (Wide) »F1.9 Aperture size, I dumped my Sony Cybershot 10.1 for this camera! »Camera features: AF Assist Beam, Optical image stabilization, Manual focus, Face detection, Smile detection, Digital zoom, Voice activation, Self-timer, Back-illuminated sensor (BSI), Autofocus, Touch to focus, Geo tagging, HDR and then some! seriously... »Camcorder features: 3840x2160 (4K) (30 fps), 1920x1080 (1080p HD) (60 fps), 1280x720 (720p HD) (120 fps) also…. Optical image stabilization, High Dynamic Range mode (HDR), Continuous autofocus, Picture-taking during video recording, Video light, Video calling -My experience with the camera has been a very positive user experience, it exceeds my expectations. Double tapping the home button immediately launches the camera app, no matter what your doing on the phone. You don’t know how useful this is until you actually use it. Pictures turn out great, no crazy autofocus wait times like my older phones and cameras would do. -The Camcorder isn’t quite the same. Once you select to record video in anything Higher then 1080p (30FPS) such as 4K Ultra High Definition, all of those really nice features disappear. The result is a much, much better crisp clear video, that turns off HDR, Video effects, Video stabilization (this one is really important), taking pictures while recording, and tracking autofocus. Also! You made only record for exactly 5 minutes while recording video in Ultra HD! The phone is firing on all engines when doing this so it heats

Textual Messages: Decided to upgrade from my Galaxy S4 after 2 years and I am so glad that I did. This thing is so smooth and powerful that its hard to believe phone internals and tech have come along this far even in two years. I was a little upset that they got rid of the removable battery and the expandable memory, but then kind of thought about how little i really accessed those two thing on my S4. Say goodbye to the plastic casing. Not that this really bothered me because I always put my phones in a case, but the finish on this thing is incredible. Previously I didn't think much about wireless charging. Now... LOVE IT. Being able to just plunk this thing down on a pad and walk away is great. I have yet to have an issue with it connecting on first placement onto the CHOE Stadium Qi Wireless Charger. Even with a Spigen Neo Hybrid case wrapped around it. Camera... So smooth and quick on boot up. Double click the home button even with the phone is idle and BAM the camera is up and running and ready to shoot. Just remember to remove the little protective cover around the lens that they place there for shipping. The screen is beautiful and colors are very vivid. Brightness can range from almost nonexistent to nice and visible in the noon sun. One tip I will share is go ahead and sign up for the advanced calling (aka HD Voice) with Verizon. With out doing that you will not have data and calling at the same time. From what I have read it has to do with they removed an antenna in the phone to either slim the phone down or to free up space for other things, and that everyone is moving to the new Voice over LTE system anyway. No extra cost. Google "advanced calling 1.0" and you can get the details.

Textual Messages: I got a chance to test a Galaxy S6 out and immediately bought one for my wife. I'm a complete phone nerd (XDA Developers Recognized Contributor, if that means anything to you) so I massively over analyze these things. It's a VERY nice phone but it's got some things that I consider drawbacks. For my wife, all the drawbacks listed below were non issues. She didn't care about these issues. So understand that my 'drawbacks' are completely subjective to your personal needs. But they are things that you should be aware of and consider if they mean anything to you before purchasing. ?????THE UPSIDES????? ? The screen is incredible. Like really incredible. The resolution is better than my eye can see. I use a Galaxy S4 as my regular phone and it has great resolution where you can't see individual pixels. I thought the S4 screen was as good as you can get, but the S6 screen takes it to a whole new level. Even though you can't see pixels on either screen, the higher resolution of the S6 screen makes everything look so sharp that it's nearly impossible to tell you are looking at a screen. It's that incredible. ? The design of the phone just feels more 'expensive'. I mean that in a good way. It feels just higher quality than previous models in the Galaxy S line. The S3 and S4 for example are often critiqued for having a plastic shell. The S6 has a metal band around the outside that just makes it feel 'premium' in your hand. It should also provide more protection for the device as well. ? TouchWiz is HEAVILY scaled back. I hate TouchWiz (Samsung's version of Android) It adds a layer of UI that is neither helpful nor intuitive. And it's a resource hog which slows the phone down for important tasks just so it can make the scrolling smoother, and other such useless tradeoffs. On the S6 TouchWiz was barely noticeable. The UI looks more like the standard Google Android Lollipop interface. It was all just much smoother and simpler and better and wonderful. ? Camera. 16 MP. And the images it takes look stunning on the super HD screen. Those photos on a larger high resolution monitor are simply stunning. ?????THE DOWNSIDES????? ? The battery is not removable or easily replaceable. A cell phone battery has a life of about 500 charge cycles. I tend to keep my phones for 2 years as daily users, then I keep my old phones for a variety of other purposes around the house. (My old HTC Sensation is hooked up to my stereo for use as a nice wifi streaming media player with a touchscreen UI, for example) I eventually have a need to replace batteries because I wear them out. I like being able to go on Amazon, spent $20 on a replacement battery, pop it in and be done. Additionally, even if you don't keep your phones that long, batteries fail sometimes. The stock batteries on the Galaxy S4 had some problems. They were minimal, but for those affected the battery absolutely had to be replaced. On the S4 it took 8 seconds and the problem was solved. On the S6 I'm sure it would be covered by warranty but it'd be a pain to take it somewhere to have it worked on should the issue come up. So no replaceable battery is a deal killer for me. This might not be an issue for you. If not, great! But be aware of the issue before making purchase decisions. ? You can't expand the storage with an SD Card. I don't want to live in the cloud. I hate the cloud. Sometimes I'm not on an LTE network. Sometimes I'm in the middle of nowhere but still want to show someone pictures of my kids. I got my wife the 32GB model. That sounds like a lot, but keep in mind that some of that is dedicated for the operating system and user apps. So you don't get to use all 32GB. The S6 is going to be available in up to 128GB, which ends my problem with not liking the cloud option. Again, you might not care. If not, great! My wife doesn't keep a lot of stuff on her phone. She moves all her pictures to her computer and never loaded video to watch on her phone, so the storage thing wasn't a big deal to he

Textual Messages: I bought the S6 edge 32gb the day it came out, April 10th, from Best Buy so I could get the free wireless charger. After a day with the phone, I decided the $100 extra wasn't worth it, and decided to exchange for the S6 64GB. There were some other factors besides money. The edge screen was too weird to get used to while playing certain games that require touching the top of the screen. Since I wasn't in love with the screen, it didn't make sense for me to keep it and opted for the 64GB "regular" S6 for the extra storage if I need it. As a disclaimer, I have used a lot of different Android phones. Nexus 5, HTC One m7&m8, Xperia z3, Note 2,3,4, and a bunch of other phones I don't know off the top of my head. The phone I had prior to this phone was the LG G3 and I had the G2 some time ago. The phone is great when it comes to build quality. It's light and feels premium, however the untrained eye won't notice the difference between an s4,s5 and s6, so don't think you're going to get compliments on the phone from "regular" phone users that only know iPhone and non-iPhone. There's nothing really to different than a s4,s5,s6, especially if you have a case on it. The good things I liked about the phone. I have had it for 2 days, and will be taking it back to Best Buy today to go back to my G3, however the good things about the phone are that it has a great camera. Very fast when it comes to taking pictures, the slow motion mode is fun to play with and every video and picture I took were very sharp. I don't usually care for cell phone cameras since we have a DSLR, but if you need to take footage of something right away, this doesn't disappoint. Double tap the home button and you can take a picture in about 1-1.5 seconds when the screen is off. The speaker is loud. Much louder than the G3. It gets distorted at max level, but you can still make out a song or spoken words. It seems about as loud as the Amazon Fire Phone, maybe louder, and that phone's speaker was pretty loud. The display is very nice. Better than the 9 month old G3, and one of the reasons I wanted to buy a Samsung again is that I missed their displays. I would say it's the best display on the market. Now for the bad. I'm going to make this quick because I have stuff to do, but here are my thoughts on the phone after using it almost nonstop for the past 2 days -The Exynos chip is fast, and octacore seems like a great idea, but I still like snapdragon processors. A few of the games I normally play on my g3, and have been playing since the snapdragon 600 processor on the HTC One M7, lag on the S6. It's quite noticeable. I play popular games that update frequently and there's still stutter and lag. I also noticed a lot of lag on certain websites, especially in "desktop mode". Unacceptable to have a brand new chip with 3gb RAM and there's lag on websites. I don't have any issues with my G3 in that sense, which is one of the reasons I'm going back. Other processes like camera opening, gallery opening, and opening most system apps are lightning fast. In my personal use of the product, games and web browsing is lacking. -I don't know if it's a bad device, but there's a couple of games I play and there's a hissing throughout playing. It's only on the game. When I exit either game, the hissing stops. I don't know why, and frankly don't care. A brand new flagship need not have this issue. -The battery. This is a big one. A small, non-replaceable battery that doesn't last a long time in my opinion. I used the wireless charger to charge the phone overnight. In about 5 hours it got up to 99%. Never hit 100% until I plugged it into the wall. That's weird to me. Maybe it's the technology that I don't know about, but it should charge to 100%. I charged it in the car on my way to work. I took it off the charger, and in about 15 minutes of not even using the phone, 1% drained. Right now I have 1 hour and 27 mins of screen on time and my battery is at 53%. That's a little over 3 hours of scre

Helpful: 3 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Have owned an S3, S4, Note 4, and now S6. Samsung makes an excellent product. The S6 was for my son who is at college studying to be an engineer. He LOVES this phone. The phone is fast, sleek, logical, intuitive and highly functional. We are amazed at each successive generation for the improvements and innovation that bring the Samsung product along. One benefit not often though of is that Samsung seems to develop and support software updates more frequently. They roll out the updates to many other older generations of their lines too which means your phone stays much more functional and safe for the time you own it. Some brands do not seem to roll out updates as Samsung does-it is not that there are issues but that they constantly innovate. This fact along is reason enough to purchase a S6 but paired with the excellent aesthetics and quality build-you can't go wrong. **Please note-I do not recommend trading in your old cell phone through Amazon. The phone that this new S6 replaced was sent in it's original box, in perfect working order with excellent battery & original equipment cables having been protected by cases & screen protectors throughout it's 2 yrs of usage. It very clearly met the criteria listed for being in the top tier yet it was downgraded to a lower value. After it a long shipping voyage there, now they shipped it back (not yet received!) taking many weeks! Amazon evidently uses vendors to evaluate trade ins-had I know it was a third party then I would never have bothered! This is a money making venture but not for you the consumer. Don't make the mistake of factoring in a trade in for your purchase of a new phone. If you do decide to flip the coin and try it-take photos of the phone, photos of serial numbers and photos of every single thing. I do not recommend that you use Amazon trade in for your old phone. This one was in perfect condition and only 2 years old top quality-premium phone still sold today! Better to keep it as a spare of donate it & write it off your taxes. Very frustrated and extremely dis-satisfied by the trade in experience-especially as it was through Amazon. I honestly expect more and this will influence whether I purchase another phone through Amazon or if I go to my carrier who had an offer of $100 for trade in value on this phone. Lesson learned-it pays to shop around and factor in your trade in value with the purchase but I choose to be loyal to Amazon rather than my carrier. Some things we don't like are NO SD card! Though you can readily use cloud services of many kinds to safeguard your info, many of us still prefer to have that SD card. I also am not a huge fan of not being able to remove the battery myself. This model moves towards the Apple method of doing things where any little thing you want done has to be done at a store, shipped in or can't be done! Screen: The Gorilla glass is excellent and top quality. The clarity and resolution of the screen is outstanding-just when I thought my Note 4 was the greatest, they go and improve within the few months between the time that it came out and the new S6. Conclusion: I highly recommend this phone. We have two tablets, and have had five Samsung phones and been very happy with them all. They work well together and the quality is outstanding.

Textual Messages: This year, Samsung kept everything much more simple, intuitive, and beautiful. As a result, the Galaxy S6 is the best smartphone any person can currently. My review will focus on 3 key aspects: exterior design and materials, tech specs and hardware performance, and interface and ui. I will also point out outstanding and new features along the way. Exterior Design: Although at first the Galaxy S6 may not look completely different from the Galaxy S5, it is leaps and bounds ahead of its predecessor. The 2 sheets of Gorilla Glass 4 adorning the front and back make the phone feel extremely premium, resolving common complaint about the previous generation. It has a full metal band surrounding it, rather than a faux plastic one. Now, the feel in hand is comparable to the iPhone 6, and the design is elegant while familiar. Since the phone is so thin at 6.8 mm, the camera module protrudes slightly from the chassis, however it does not affect the phone. There is a sapphire lens to protect the camera, but placing the phone in a case should alleviate the protruding camera issue. Going to the front. there is a typical rectangular home button with a recent apps capacitive key on the left, with a back key on the right. Overall, the Galaxy S6 is the best phone Samsung has ever designed; however, the sealed battery and absence of a micro SD card slot may upset many. I do not replace the batteries in my phone nor add SD cards for storage, but customers from the Galaxy devices before may be unhappy. Tech Specs, Hardware Performance, Notable Features: The Galaxy in real life and on paper is a monster! Screen: It packs an amazing 5.1 Super AMOLED screen with a resolution of 2560x1440. The screen is capable of bright whites and dark blacks, and is the best mobile display currently on the market. Although Super AMOLED screens tend to have overly saturated colors, choosing AMOLED Cinema mode in settings creates natural colors. Fingerprint Scanner: Instead of a swipe based sensor, the new fingerprint scanner embedded in the home button is a capacitive touch based sensor, like the one on the iPhone 6. All you do is place your finger on the home button to unlock the phone. You can set up a total of 4 fingers, and the sensor is extremely reliable and useful. Every person using this phone should have the fingerprint sensor turned on since it provides good security while being intuitive to use. Camera: The camera is a 16 megapixel sensor with OIS. The Galaxy S6 has the best camera out of all Android phones, and easily competes with the iPhone 6 Plus. Because of the higher resolution, images are extremely detailed. The Optical Imaging Stabilization ensures pictures are clear, while videos are buttery smooth. The OIS also helps at night, as the sensor can pull in more light without creating a blurry image. The result is an amazing camera that can produce vibrant and beautiful pictures during the day, and a camera that can create accurate and bright pictures at night. The camera is also capable of 4K video recording, and slow motion video as well. An important new feature the Galaxy S6 incorporates is the double click on home button to activate. When you double click the home button, it opens the camera in less than 1 second! The "just shoot" mentality this camera gives its users is simply amazing and unmatched. For the pro users out there, the camera includes a professional mode that users can use to adjust ISO, white balance, and more settings. The front camera is 5 megapixels, and it is a strong front facing camera. Not much can be said about it, but it produces beautiful selfies and good colors, and is more than adequate for all users. Quick Charging and Wireless Charging: The Galaxy S6 is capable of adaptive quick charging using the charger supplied in the box. This charges the Galaxy S6 extremely fast; you can get about 4 hours of use only with 10 minutes of charging. The phone also supports other Qualcomm Quick Chargers. The Galaxy S6 also supports the

Textual Messages: Wow, what a difference a year makes. While last year's S5 took many steps in the right direction(being somewhat waterproof with better material and craftsmanship), it still wasn't there to make it a mouth-watering phone yet, like what HTC did when they first introduced their One M7, or whenever Apple introduces a new iPhone size. This year, Samsung has finally learned from both of their competitors, and made a phone that has all the good qualities of both, plus some of their own. Finally, this is the Galaxy S that you've always wanted and been dreaming of. * LOOKS/FORM-FACTOR/MATERIALS: The very first thing you notice when you handle the phone, is its new design and form factor - finally Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful. The metal fully wraps around the edges ofthe phone. The back is beautiful, the sides are beautiful - heck, even the buttons are beautiful. It feels great in the hand, and oozes style and sophistication. * SCREEN: The very next thing you notice, of course, is the screen. I am continually pleasantly surprised at the evolution of Samsung's AMOLED technology - it has now became the best screen in the industry, hands down. I used to defend the LCD technology of the HTC M7, and at that point it was in fact overall superior to the Samsung S4 because the AMOLED then had issues in the sun, and color reproduction(it was too saturated and not natural). But now, they have fixed those issues, and the S6's screen is just quite simply the best. If you don't believe it, just compare an LG/Samsung OLED TV to any LED TVs today. I still think 5.1 inches for a screen of a PHONE is still too big, but overall, for what smartphones represent nowadays, it is acceptable - we have conditioned ourselves to accept the bigger sizes of smartphones(I remember when I first held a 4.2" smartphone when it first came out - the HTC HD2 - and thought, "what the h3ll is this monstrosity??"). * It doesn't hurt that Samsung boosted up the resolution to 1440 x 2560 pixels, which is approximately 577 ppi in pixel density. Although this is quite overkill right now, it's always nice to have the latest and greatest technology - that's the reason why we buy these overpriced phones in the first place, isn't it? It is also very bright, and sunlit legibility is excellent. Color reproduction is quite accurate, and like the S5, you can choose different color modes to suit your liking. *BATTERY LIFE: An important aspect to discuss is the battery life, now more than ever because there is no removable back cover to make replacing the battery easily like before, not to mention there is no microSD slot for you to add memory space to your phone. Comparatively, the S6 Edge is supposed to last a little less than the S6 regular, which I've read is less than last year's S5. But I'm one of those who are always around a charger, and I always carry external battery packs in my backpack when I travel, so that's never a concern. Seriously, who even buys an extra battery anymore - which you can only use for a single specific phone model - when your external battery can charge ANY and ALL phones and tablets?? This scenario only makes sense if your work is so demanding that you don't have extra time to charge the phone, and need to swap batteries IMMEDIATELY. I don't think that scenario is realistic nowadays when external batteries are so small, light, and cheap. My S6 goes from 100% at 10 am to about 20% at 10 pm with moderate use - so no complaints there. I get home, plug it up, and there are no issues. * What's better this year, is the wireless charging standards are already built into the phone, so you can just buy a charging pad for about $50 and feel even more cool. * USER INTERFACE/SOFTWARE: The Samsung user interface called TouchWiz used to be bloated and sluggish. It would slow down(navigating throughout the phone, switching between apps, and using

Textual Messages: Buying the Samsung S6 was personally the worst technology purchase/mistake I have ever made. I purchased it new with the full insurance plan. The phone just went dark and stopped working. No problem I THOUGHT...I went store and they said file the insurance claim. I got back a REFURBISHED phone. So paid for a new phone, it died within 30 days. Since then, 2 refurbished phones batteries have "swelled" and phone stopped working. So $700 for 1st phone, $200 for each replacement. I'm 3 phones down, $1100 later and I have another burned out phone with cracked backing. The back is glass and cracks easily, so when the battery swelled, it cracked the glass...and then the insurance says I had physical damage... I have since just bought a new S5, downgraded myself. Will get the piece of junk S6 repaired and then sell it. Samsun should be ashamed! DONE with S6..horrible, horrible, horrible durability/reliability.

Textual Messages: I finally broke from my long-term relationship with BlackBerry. The first few days were difficult but glad I did it. The Galaxy S6 and apps are great, and since I bought a Samsung tablet several months ago, both the Samsung and Android functions were fairly familiar to me. Within a few hours, I removed some of the apps I don't care about and easily downloaded others, using either Google Play or just doing a voice recognition Google search "OK Google, get me the ABC app." Several things were driving me crazy, however, and the sales people gave no satisfactory answers. But I found solutions so let me share them here. The biggest problem was how to sync my contacts and calendar between the S6 and Outlook on my PC. No one seemed to have a decent answer. Sales guy said: Buy Microsoft 365, download it onto both your PC and the S6 and sync that way. Seemed reasonable, especially since a personal license is now $65 (first year) for three devices (PC, tablet and mobile). Unfortunately, Microsoft 365 wouldn't download correctly, Microsoft customer service never called me back even though the web said I'd hear from them within six minutes, and several YouTube videos say the Microsoft instructions actually don't work and then try to show how to do it. Wow, you'd think by now they'd have this down. Plus, I already have all the Office functions on my PC and you can now get mobile versions of Word, Excel and PowerPoint for free at Google Apps so this seemed stupid in retrospect, especially since it didn’t work. I looked at various apps that supposedly do the sync and even posed a question on an Amazon forum. No solutions. Then an engineer friend told me to try Sync 2, which gave me free use for several weeks and I can then buy a one-time license for around $39.95. Went to their web site, downloaded their software, found the instructions amazingly understandable, and watched as their system then moved my contacts, calendar and tasks to my existing Google account even though I’ve never shared contacts or calendar with Google in the past and even though I don’t use Google for my email and still don’t. Sure enough, everything got transferred into my Google account, and when I went to my S6 to see how I could then sync my contacts and calendar on the S6 with my Google contacts and calendar, it turns out the S6 had already synced since it already had my Google account name and password. I find the S6 is now regularly staying in sync, in slightly different format from Outlook but something I can easily get used to. I also find that when I now send any emails, as is the case with Outlook on my PC, the S6 email system draws upon my contacts and when I do hands free calling, including from my car, I get the same great interlinks. In other words, Sync 2 keeps my PC contacts and calendar in sync at Google (even though I largely don’t use Google) and my S6 in turn uses that Google account to do its sync. A great solution. You'd think the techies would realize that the millions of us who actually use our mobile devices for work would need something like this. Second, unlike my old BlackBerry (which always gave me a choice) or my Samsung tablet, whenever I deleted email on the S6, it was deleting the emails on the servers, which I didn't want since I archive important emails on my PC. Sales people said: don't delete your emails then, and it's a problem with your Internet service provider anyway. Wrong. If you explore the settings on the S6, about three levels down (from email accounts, not general settings -- it's definitely NOT intuitive), there's a place where you can set the handling of incoming email on each email account you have linked to your S6 – “always delete” or “never delete.” I switched each account to “never delete” and the problem is solved. And finally, my signature lines were looking awful, and many web forums said there was no way to fix this. But I found one forum that had an amazing solution: Send yourself an email with the signature bl
