I will continue to update this review in the future. This review should be the similar to Galaxy S6 on other carriers such as Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile. Pros: - No more plastics and cheap material. Samsung is finally giving us the hardware that we've long desired. By far, the best designed Galaxy phone to date imo - 5.1 in, QHD Super AMOLED screen. The screen is absolutely gorgeous that it hurts my eyes a bit. I'm still adjusting to it. - 16MP Camera with Smart OIS and 5MP front camera. Very well specs, but even better in performance. In short, the best camera on any android phones. I cannot believe that the picture came out so well in low light environment. You have to try it yourself to believe how great these low light pictures come out. - Gorilla Glass 4 panels for front and back (reminds me of the iPhone 4 and Nexus 4). Gorilla Glass are known to be tough and scratch resistance. - Comes in various colors: White, black, gold, green, blue (US only get the white, black, and gold unfortunately) - Comes in 32, 64, or 128GB of built-in memory. (For the 32gb - 3.7gb is for system partition, 25.2 for data/apps/pictures) - Less of the TouchWiz’s gimmicky features like the eye scroll, eye away from the screen pause. So we will not be experiencing the same slowdown or low storage as we did with earlier versions. If the GS4/5 were all about the features, this phone is all about the design. I do like the camera app and how they add a "close all" into the recent screen. - Rapid charging (need to use this more to confirm their claim of 4hrs of battery in 10 minute charge - UPDATED 5/1/15 i am getting about 1 to 1 1/2 hrs of use after the 10 minute charge, I'm guessing the 4hr claim is idle??) - Wireless charging - So if you have extra money that you want to drop for a wireless charging dock, you will be able to use it with this phone. Cons (Not necessarily apply to everyone): - No removable back panel. - No removable battery. I’m a battery hog, so I’m always draining my battery by 3-4pm. Not being able to just swap out my battery will be a pain, but let’s wait to see if the battery swap will be needed in a month when I fully test this device. - Lower battery capacity - 2550mAh compared to the 2600mAh in GS4 and 2800mAh in GS5. With the new processor, battery usage should be more efficient so it should not be a big deal, but end-users would rather the capacity to increase than decrease (Will update if this make through a day of normal usage, UPDATED 5/1/15 - I'm getting average about 8-9 hrs of normal usage, not ideal but I'll manage) - No waterproofing like the GS5, but I never used a smartphone that was waterproofed before, so not a big issue "to me" - No ability to swap out memory card – Might bother some Galaxy fans, but with the higher memory options, I do not think this is a huge problem. - Still no on-screen navigation button – Might only be a problem for "pure" Android fan. - Rear Camera and Flash sticks out a bit and not flush with the back panel. - Front and back glass is a potential problem as we all experiences with iPhone 4 and Nexus 4. Glass will break if you drop your phone at the right angle regardless how much stronger it is, so "case up". - The 1 speaker at the bottom is louder, however when you turn it on max, you will get some distortions in the audio quality. - There are some apps on there that I prefer downloading myself rather than them pushing it on me. Textual Messages: Where to start. I upgraded from a Samsung s3....yeah hahaha. I was happy with that phone, up until just recently it started to have some glitches. Went ahead , and got the S6. This device is no doubt faster, and has a great display. If you use applications a lot, you'll love it. The actual phone is marginal at best. Low volume, (I had to do an exchange on my first purchase as peoples voices were crackly). The speakerphone is fine, but I use the actual phone. Im seriously disappointed in that, the S3 is easily 10 times better. I could make it as loud as necessary when needed. With the 6 its low with a marginal volume boost. In my opinion this is a great droid, and disappointing actual phone. Better like charging too as its battery life is ridiculously low, and nope you cant replace/swap the battery. Samsung decided they want you to buy a new phone when your battery starts to fail. I would have went with a different unit, but ATT charges to exchange for a different model, and there customer service is the worst Ive dealt with. Id recommend you explore the newest LG, or IPhone if you're going to get a new phone, this S6 is nothing special.

Textual Messages: Love the phone but there are MAJOR issues with the phone on the Sprint network! Check the Sprint forum to see the discussion. Users from areas throughout the country cannot use the phone on the 4G LTE or Spark settings, there is rarely any reception and if there is, calls drop. Putting the phone on CDMA allows it to be used but at 3G. Both my husband and I saw this personally with our phones. Previously we had the S4 and had great reception, the only thing that changed was the phone. Other people posting have tested their phones along with friends with the S6 but on other carriers, and those phones did not have this problem. It appears that it is an issue with how Sprint/Samsung configured the phones being sold by Sprint. Sprint will not acknowledge or reply to the forum discussion, nor do their technicians appear to be informed of the problem. The phone itself is wonderful.

Textual Messages: Why I chose the Samsung Galaxy S6 over the Apple iPhone 6 First, let me make it clear that these were the only two phones I performed a detailed comparison of. There are many other credible phones that would make worthy competitors -- however I narrowed it down to these two at the time I made my purchase (June 2015). Additionally, these are my findings based on my use case. Obviously your use case may be different. Given the difficultly of performing an objective and scientific A/B test for all the categories that were important to me, I've also provided links to objective technical analysis performed by credible engineering labs and other sources throughout my review below. You may have to copy/paste the links into the url of your browser. While I double checked the technical specs, don’t hesitate to make me aware of any technical spec errors if you see any. SCREEN TO BODY RATIO – Samsung Wins: I intentionally chose to start with this characteristic of the two phones given that I rarely see it mentioned in the many reviews I've read (users, technical journalist, etc.) -- and this really bothered me about the Apple device. Apple's iPhone 6 struck me as being stuck in the ancient past (in relative Smartphone years) with huge bezels (top, bottom and side) as compared to the svelte futuristic look and feel of the Samsung Galaxy S6. Samsung's exterior design really showcased it's outstanding screen by minimizing the size of the bezels -- it looks much more futuristic and modern than Apple's phones. Considering the Samsung Galaxy S6 packs a larger battery, along with other much more impressive hardware specs, this is an amazing accomplishment. BATTERY ENDURANCE – Samsung Wins: Almost all Smartphone users complain about the duration of their battery. It's certainly a valid concern - and one not to take lightly when choosing your phone. You've heard the saying regarding which camera is the best -- it's the one you're carrying. Well, for batteries it seems to be the opposite -- from a user's perspective the worst battery seems to always be the one in the Smartphone you're carrying. The link below provides an excellent analysis for battery comparison that supports my observation that Samsung’s Galaxy S6 battery holds up longer than the Apple iPhone 6 battery (there are many others with the same or similar conclusion). You may need to add the two phones using PhoneArena’s drop down box as they are adding new phones all the time. http://www.phonearena.com/news/Galaxy-S6-edge-battery-life-benchmark-results-show-better-performance-than-the-Note5_id72736 Samsung’s Galaxy S6 includes a 2550 mAh battery, while Apple’s iPhone 6 includes an 1810 mAh battery. While neither of these batteries will set any endurance records, PhoneArena rates the Apple iPhone 6 battery as ‘Poor’ – while rating the Samsung Galaxy S6 battery as ‘Good’. The categories, best to worse, are ‘Excellent’, ‘Good’, ‘Average’, ‘Poor’. To be sure, some legacy Samsung users have complained about Samsung's decision to exclude a user replaceable battery in the Galaxy S6. However, my review isn't a comparison of the Galaxy S6 to previous Samsung flagship Smartphones. Instead, I'm directly comparing it to the Apple iPhone6. BATTERY CHARGING – Samsung Wins: Reference the same link above for an objective and detailed comparison of battery charging performance. Based on PhoneArena’s analysis, even with the larger battery, the Samsung Galaxy S6 charges almost twice as fast as the Apple iPhone 6. Samsung's Galaxy S6 supports quick charge - and, with built-in wireless charging, the S6 supports the two top wireless charging standards. In my use case, given that I work in an assigned office, wireless charging is very convenient. I use the TechMatte Qi wireless charging pad (purchased on Amazon) and find it to be very reliable and consistent with the E.C.L. USA Crystal Clear Ultra Slim case (also purchased on Amazon). When I'm not using my Galaxy S6, I simple place it on the charging pad as

Helpful: 2 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: 7:28 0:00 This video is not intended for all audiences. What date were you born?  Submit Adobe Flash Player is required to watch this video. Install Flash Player I bought the Samsung Galaxy S6 directly through Verizon. Myself and my family tend to be Samsung users - smartphones, tablets, camcorders, Blueray players... so yes, I do have Samsung loyalty, yet I have to say the non-expandable internal memory is a bit of a bleah. I purposely got the 32GB as a) I am not one to fill up memory (never have been) and b) the extra hundred bucks for a 64GB seems ludicrous. Initial available memory is at approximately 22GB after all the updates... and the updates just keep coming, day in, day out. Some you can remove completely (if its listed under the APP windows, you can), rest you can disable, yet at times I have noticed there are ones that will suddenly re-activated and download the updates again. I have had this issue with my Samsung Tab 3 10.1", too. When you plug the S6 into a PC (mine is Win 8.1 64Bit), you should be prompted to download and install a handler program for PC/S6 data transfers. I did get a very odd error though with some Amazon music tracks I transferred this way - standard MP3 format, but for some reason an error popped up as corrupted files. These were from two specific album collections (Instrumental Beats), yet the other album collections play fine. I can only assume it had something to do with the Samsung transfer software since I have the same tracks on multiple other Android devices, and never seen that error before. This can get quite warm with prolonged use. It gets a bit uncomfortable to the hand if no case is on. I currently use a UAG military-drop case, so it's no longer an issue. Strong, quick Bluetooth connections. Has NFC pairing - something I only discovered today while exploring the settings. Cool! The camera is great, of course, and the included photo editor is as robust as many Android Photo Editor I have evaluated. Fantastic display - fairs very well even in direct, bright sunshine. No problems with phone audio. I have to scratch my head in perplexity over other reviews say terrible reception. I can only guess it's a carrier-to-carrier issue? As for the "bending" complaint, that one also puzzles me. Yet I do have mine in a case, so perhaps that is the needful thing. Contact list includes Auto-Reject (something I had really wanted on my last phone) 4G support of credit card transactions. Has made my laptop home-visit repairs a better, more assured experience. ;) The aspect I personally love the most is the wireless charging - that is a pretty big plus in my book. The batter can dwindle relatively quickly, but by surrounding my self with wireless QI charging options (home, car travel, even a wireless charging power bank), it really is a moot thing. Standby time is strong; Samsung does shine in that respect. I hadn't known about the non-replaceable battery until after purchase... not sure how I feel about that. All in all, it's the slight doubt about only going with 32GB that bothers me, and I will burn the non-replaceable battery aspect bridge when I come to it down the line. Aside from that, I am quite pleased with this.

Textual Messages: Oh, Another year 2015. Another set of phones from manufacturers! I have been hooked onto get the latest phone every year syndrome and love reviewing specifics. Disclaimer, I love Android and have been using from very early days. Samsung Galaxy S6 tries to be a revolutionary, but it is evolutionary. If you have an older phone more than 2 years old, absolutely get this. So do check local specs. I played around with both S6 and S6 Edge for few days and my opinions are based on this. There are tons of reviews going into lot of details, so I am focused on few other aspects like what’s out there and how to compare specs. First Big Changes: No microSD or removable battery. I know many of you loyal Samsung fans says BUMMER! I was a die hard fan of Samsung till S4, then I went to LG G2/G3. I think this is the best bet for S6 to pull it off after a dismal year for Samsung last year. I was very curious to try out S6 and HTC One M9 as they are most talked about now. Many manufacturers are going away from microSD card slots and this is absolutely a must and is a key differentiator from iPhone. I am really sad Samsung decided to drop microSD card slot as well as no removable battery. Why?! Screen is a beauty on S6 – Just Gorgeous. Just go to a retail store and feel it! The Edge feature is still gimmicky. Unlike Note Edge, this has both sides so less dorky but still I am not sold yet. Unless you have loads of money, I will shy away from it for one more year and get it next year when they polish it up. It is certainly fancy and nice to show off, but I would rather buy an Android wear watch like Motorola 360 or Samsung Gear or LG R series. I like Motorola 360 but waiting for version 2 to appear. I like Round watches. IF YOU HAVE LAST YEAR model of any phone, PLEASE DON’T upgrade. Phones are becoming so standard and power packed it makes no sense to upgrade and waste money every year. I buy and sell so many phones as it is like a hobby for me, but I stick to one phone as primary for couple of years now. My main requirements are a 128 GB microSD, good screen, battery life and performance. I am trying hard to see if I can live without one. S6 and S6 Edge comes in a 128 GB variant and I will wait for prices to stabilize on this model. In my opinion, following are key specs to consider when you buying a phone. Most of others are standard or does not matter at all. First size, weight and resolution are part of look and feel. RAM/CPU part of performance. external Storage is part of expandability. Camera is obvious! SAR (Specific Absorption Rating) is an often ignored, but I feel essential to making a buying choice. Manufacturers don’t advertise or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S6: 5.65 x 2.78 x 0.27 in, 138 gm, 1440 x 2560 pixels, 5.1 in, 577 ppi, 3 GB RAM, NO MICROSD SLOT (bummer), Internal Storage upto 128 GB, Exynos 7420 Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex-A57, Gorilla Glass 4, 16 MP/5MP camera, SAR 1.15 W/kg (head), 1.16 W/kg (body) NANO SIM Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge: Slightly lower dimensions, 0.01 in thicker, 6 gm less weight, Same resolution, Curved Screen, HTC One M9: 5.69 x 2.74 x 0.38 in, 157 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 3 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 20.7 MP (rear), 4 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 810, Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2 GHz Cortex-A57 Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G3: 5.76 x 2.94 x 0.35 in, 149 gm, 2560 x 1440 pixels, 5.5 in, 538 pp

Textual Messages: My Verdict: My experience with this device was at first a positive one with a greatly-improved camera, a pretty snappy performance and lovely screen. It didn't take long for things to go downhill, and then, nuclear. The most important thing I can say after spending quite a lot of time with Samsung support via phone and chat is: are you in the mood to gather up several hundreds of dollars and burn them in front of yourself just for the hell of it? So, here's the best I can come up with about the new Galaxy phones: there are, or were, a number of unknowns due to the complete design and build changes, and Samsung is ready to blame customers with failed, failing and constantly-overheating phones (there seem to be a lot of those). And the carriers are more than happy to charge the customers for a new phone, and then play the blame game with Samsung and vice-versa ("Well, it's clearly a device issue" vs. "Speak to your carrier about how they're handling and shipping our devices") in an endless loop of refurbished and flawed nightmares until your year's warranty (from time of the phone's manufacture, not the date of purchase!) is up. AT&T and Samsung both verbally smacked my palms for not having insurance, since then they would happily replace my 4-month old phone for just a few more hundred dollars! When a device is built like this so that air cannot escape as the processor rages on (and frankly, not much at all can be known about Samsung's chip given that it's not purchased by any other phone manufacturer and is new to this generation of Galaxies), any air trapped inside (and this would happen if not properly evacuated during the build sequence) causes the moisture in that air to condense and will discolor or corrode anything sealed inside the phone. Now, this explains the damage done, but certainly not how I could have caused it or could have prevented it. My Experience: After 4 months of owning the S6, what I now have is a "water damaged/irreparable" slab. Oh, it's important to note that I have received 3 of these phones as the first failed out of the box, received another that worked smoothly for about 6 wks, and then a replacement which, again, failed out of the box. I put a lot of confidence into the fact that my 3-year-old galaxy was still working, and that issues with the new design would be caught within year 1 (and that Samsung would be receptive to these potential issues). I was wrong, and please don't make the mistake of thinking that if you take incredibly good and gentle care of your phone and have had basically good experiences with Samsung in the past, that you can count on this device. Also, once Samsung has voided your warranty, your carrier probably will do absolutely nothing except offer to sell you another phone. At about 5-6 wks, the phone locked up during a podcast when I opened the camera, and sat there for about 20 minutes like a record skipping (screen unresponsive) while I looked into how to shut it down as nothing would work and I wasn't yet familiar with the soft reset for this device. Things went downhill from this point, and the phone gradually became buggier and more difficult, often shutting itself down and restarting 20 times in a day for no discernible reason, though any AT&T updates absolutely brought it to its knees. Most recently, a major AT&T update was the beginning of my device's end. It quite literally just broke down, shutting itself off, only able to remain on for about 45 seconds when I forced it to turn on again or after a soft reset. Any task I could open within that tiny window would prompt it to freeze and/or shut down. It never worked again. Fast forward through AT&T's lack of interest or response to the issues, even refusing to troubleshoot or actually to answer any simple questions I asked; instead, I was told that a warranty replacement needed to be ordered as the phone was clearly beyond help. I eventually said "yes" to this and the "certified, like-new phone" I received as a rep

Helpful: 4 of 5 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Included with the phone (comes with the Android 5 installed) are the instructions, a micro USB charging cable (approximately 3 feet 7 inches in length), wall adaptor, and a set of wired headphones with microphone. I don’t know about anyone else but every time I have to get a new cell phone, I feel it is almost as bad as going to buy a car. My S4 recently died and I was forced to get a new phone. I really wasn’t looking forward to it as I had an unlimited contract that as soon as I got a new phone, I would lose that plan since Verizon no longer lets you keep your plan. Since Verizon no longer sells the S4, I decided to go with the new S6 64 gig version and bought it directly from Verizon wireless. The phone itself looks similar in design to the S4 but a bit thinner overall and a bit longer with a slightly bigger screen. One of the trends for phone makers these days is to go with a solid body design with the battery not removable. I didn’t like the cheap plastic back on the S4 that chipped up over time but since I tend to keep a phone longer than two years, I don’t like a phone that I can’t open the back and change the battery if I need. In addition to that you can’t add any addition memory as there is no external SD card slot which wasn’t main reason I went with the 64 gig version as I don’t think the 100 cost difference is worth it. Locally the 32 gig was sold out and since I needed a phone, I decided to go with the 64 gig version. Some people may not mind these issues though, especially if you trade phones every couple years and don’t worry about changing batteries or adding more space for your apps. I am not sure why though that they didn’t make this waterproof like the S5 since it does have a one body design. To me, the phone really only has a few differences in how it operates, since both my S4 (recently updated) and this S6 uses Android 5. The main thing I do like with this phone is the ability to use your fingerprint instead of a password to unlock my phone. It is a great time saver and works pretty flawlessly. The phone screen is sharp and the phone is quick with my apps. This has a pretty good camera with a 16 MP camera which takes nice quality pictures and video, although I am not a big phone picture taker. The battery life for this is ok and since you are stuck with the battery or a case/power bank that you use to supplement it, it is what it is. I like the style of the phone it definitely feels less cheap than the plastic back design of the S4, but I do wish it had the flexibility of opening the back for changing batteries and for additional memory. It you like the style and design of the S4 and S5 and don’t mind the battery and storage issues, then this is just as nice and you will most likely like this phone. 4 stars.

Cons (Not necessarily apply to everyone): - No removable back panel. - No removable battery. I’m a battery hog, so I’m always draining my battery by 3-4pm. Not being able to just swap out my battery will be a pain, but let’s wait to see if the battery swap will be needed in a month when I fully test this device. - Lower battery capacity - 2550mAh compared to the 2600mAh in GS4 and 2800mAh in GS5. With the new processor, battery usage should be more efficient so it should not be a big deal, but end-users would rather the capacity to increase than decrease (Will update if this make through a day of normal usage, UPDATED 5/1/15 - I'm getting average about 8-9 hrs of normal usage, not ideal but I'll manage) - No waterproofing like the GS5, but I never used a smartphone that was waterproofed before, so not a big issue "to me" - No ability to swap out memory card – Might bother some Galaxy fans, but with the higher memory options, I do not think this is a huge problem. - Still no on-screen navigation button – Might only be a problem for "pure" Android fan. - Rear Camera and Flash sticks out a bit and not flush with the back panel. - Front and back glass is a potential problem as we all experiences with iPhone 4 and Nexus 4. Glass will break if you drop your phone at the right angle regardless how much stronger it is, so "case up". - The 1 speaker at the bottom is louder, however when you turn it on max, you will get some distortions in the audio quality. - There are some apps on there that I prefer downloading myself rather than them pushing it on me. There are some Social apps or Microsoft apps included such as OneDrive, facebook, etc. I personally use these apps, but there are people who don't. - I have been experiencing some weird stutters/lags while messing around the phone. This might because I'm loading a bunch of apps into it right now. I will need a few more days to look into this. Overall, this feels like a this is a solid de

Textual Messages: Wow, what a difference a year makes. While last year's S5 took many steps in the right direction(being somewhat waterproof with better material and craftsmanship), it still wasn't there to make it a mouth-watering phone yet, like what HTC did when they first introduced their One M7, or whenever Apple introduces a new iPhone size. This year, Samsung has finally learned from both of their competitors, and made a phone that has all the good qualities of both, plus some of their own. Finally, this is the Galaxy S that you've always wanted and been dreaming of. * LOOKS/FORM-FACTOR/MATERIALS: The very first thing you notice when you handle the phone, is its new design and form factor - finally Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful. The metal fully wraps around the edges ofthe phone. The back is beautiful, the sides are beautiful - heck, even the buttons are beautiful. It feels great in the hand, and oozes style and sophistication. * SCREEN: The very next thing you notice, of course, is the screen. I am continually pleasantly surprised at the evolution of Samsung's AMOLED technology - it has now became the best screen in the industry, hands down. I used to defend the LCD technology of the HTC M7, and at that point it was in fact overall superior to the Samsung S4 because the AMOLED then had issues in the sun, and color reproduction(it was too saturated and not natural). But now, they have fixed those issues, and the S6's screen is just quite simply the best. If you don't believe it, just compare an LG/Samsung OLED TV to any LED TVs today. I still think 5.1 inches for a screen of a PHONE is still too big, but overall, for what smartphones represent nowadays, it is acceptable - we have conditioned ourselves to accept the bigger sizes of smartphones(I remember when I first held a 4.2" smartphone when it first came out - the HTC HD2 - and thought, "what the h3ll is this monstrosity??"). * It doesn't hurt that Samsung boosted up the resolution to 1440 x 2560 pixels, which is approximately 577 ppi in pixel density. Although this is quite overkill right now, it's always nice to have the latest and greatest technology - that's the reason why we buy these overpriced phones in the first place, isn't it? It is also very bright, and sunlit legibility is excellent. Color reproduction is quite accurate, and like the S5, you can choose different color modes to suit your liking. *BATTERY LIFE: An important aspect to discuss is the battery life, now more than ever because there is no removable back cover to make replacing the battery easily like before, not to mention there is no microSD slot for you to add memory space to your phone. Comparatively, the S6 Edge is supposed to last a little less than the S6 regular, which I've read is less than last year's S5. But I'm one of those who are always around a charger, and I always carry external battery packs in my backpack when I travel, so that's never a concern. Seriously, who even buys an extra battery anymore - which you can only use for a single specific phone model - when your external battery can charge ANY and ALL phones and tablets?? This scenario only makes sense if your work is so demanding that you don't have extra time to charge the phone, and need to swap batteries IMMEDIATELY. I don't think that scenario is realistic nowadays when external batteries are so small, light, and cheap. My S6 goes from 100% at 10 am to about 20% at 10 pm with moderate use - so no complaints there. I get home, plug it up, and there are no issues. * What's better this year, is the wireless charging standards are already built into the phone, so you can just buy a charging pad for about $50 and feel even more cool. * USER INTERFACE/SOFTWARE: The Samsung user interface called TouchWiz used to be bloated and sluggish. It would slow down(navigating throughout the phone, switching between apps, and using

Helpful: 13 of 18 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Oh, Another year 2015. Another set of phones from manufacturers! I have been hooked onto get the latest phone every year syndrome and love reviewing specifics. Disclaimer, I love Android and have been using from very early days. Samsung Galaxy S6 tries to be a revolutionary, but it is evolutionary. If you have an older phone more than 2 years old, absolutely get this. So do check local specs. I played around with both S6 and S6 Edge for few days and my opinions are based on this. There are tons of reviews going into lot of details, so I am focused on few other aspects like what’s out there and how to compare specs. First Big Changes: No microSD or removable battery. I know many of you loyal Samsung fans says BUMMER! I was a die hard fan of Samsung till S4, then I went to LG G2/G3. I think this is the best bet for S6 to pull it off after a dismal year for Samsung last year. I was very curious to try out S6 and HTC One M9 as they are most talked about now. Many manufacturers are going away from microSD card slots and this is absolutely a must and is a key differentiator from iPhone. I am really sad Samsung decided to drop microSD card slot as well as no removable battery. Why?! Screen is a beauty on S6 – Just Gorgeous. Just go to a retail store and feel it! The Edge feature is still gimmicky. Unlike Note Edge, this has both sides so less dorky but still I am not sold yet. Unless you have loads of money, I will shy away from it for one more year and get it next year when they polish it up. It is certainly fancy and nice to show off, but I would rather buy an Android wear watch like Motorola 360 or Samsung Gear or LG R series. I like Motorola 360 but waiting for version 2 to appear. I like Round watches. IF YOU HAVE LAST YEAR model of any phone, PLEASE DON’T upgrade. Phones are becoming so standard and power packed it makes no sense to upgrade and waste money every year. I buy and sell so many phones as it is like a hobby for me, but I stick to one phone as primary for couple of years now. My main requirements are a 128 GB microSD, good screen, battery life and performance. I am trying hard to see if I can live without one. S6 and S6 Edge comes in a 128 GB variant and I will wait for prices to stabilize on this model. In my opinion, following are key specs to consider when you buying a phone. Most of others are standard or does not matter at all. First size, weight and resolution are part of look and feel. RAM/CPU part of performance. external Storage is part of expandability. Camera is obvious! SAR (Specific Absorption Rating) is an often ignored, but I feel essential to making a buying choice. Manufacturers don’t advertise or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S6: 5.65 x 2.78 x 0.27 in, 138 gm, 1440 x 2560 pixels, 5.1 in, 577 ppi, 3 GB RAM, NO MICROSD SLOT (bummer), Internal Storage upto 128 GB, Exynos 7420 Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex-A57, Gorilla Glass 4, 16 MP/5MP camera, SAR 1.15 W/kg (head), 1.16 W/kg (body) NANO SIM Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge: Slightly lower dimensions, 0.01 in thicker, 6 gm less weight, Same resolution, Curved Screen, HTC One M9: 5.69 x 2.74 x 0.38 in, 157 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 3 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 20.7 MP (rear), 4 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 810, Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2 GHz Cortex-A57 Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G3: 5.76 x 2.94 x 0.35 in, 149 gm, 2560 x 1440 pixels, 5.5 in, 538 pp

Helpful: 2 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I really wanted to keep this phone. It excels in almost all areas except one, calls. It gets horrible reception! I live in NY, not the boonies. It will work fine if you are outdoors, but inside my home, or in any building and I would constantly get complaints from callers saying they can't hear me, I'm breaking up. Never had this problem with any other Samsung phone, so I must assume all the metal and glass on the S6 is somehow interfering with the signal. My wife has a Samsung Mega, same network, and her reception is stellar. I started checking forums and found that there any MANY other S6 users that have the same problem. Spent $650 on this, so I expect it to at least be able to make calls, I mean it is a phone. Very disappointed.

Helpful: 2 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: The two main things that I don't like about my S6 is the inaccessibility to the battery and the lack of a micro SD card slot. The third thing I don't like is that the Maps application, when in use, quickly drains the battery. I have to keep my S6 plugged into a car charger while navigating on trips as short as 40 miles. I understand that Samsung is hoping that the S6 and S6 Edge will turn around their losses in the Smartphone market. Personally, I think Samsung will be forced to return to the drawing board. I'd also suggest that Samsung give up on the fingerprint reader. Mine didn't work most of the time on the S5 and it is even more troublesome on my S6. My S6 is outstanding in all other areas.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: The Galaxy S6 is an outstanding smartphone. Not to be confused with its sibling, the S6 Edge, it makes up for the lack of a touch screen that extends to the sides of the phone with its lower price. Otherwise the phones are identical in features and capabilities which are long and impressive. The screen, with is slightly larger than the S5, is bright and, to date, has the highest resolution of any smartphone and is extremely responsive with virtually no noticeable lag when touched. Although it does not have the Snapdragon processor, which is the fastest in the industry, it does have two slower quad-core processors working in tandem which gives the phone phenomenal speed and multitasking capabilities. The improvements added since the S5 are built-in wireless charging capabilities that meet the Q1 standard, Gorilla Glass 4, the latest shock resistant touch glass from Corning. The already impressive camera is improved with an increased aperture enabling a greater sensitivity to ambient light and much wider pictures to accompany a superb auto focusing system. And addressing the complaints of the S5's plastic case, the S6 has a thinner and lighter aluminum body. The thinner body also makes the S6 ideal for use with a protective case or shell. Lastly, the latest version of Android seems perfectly suited for each feature of the phone, especially the S6 Edge, making it more than a match for Apple's iPhone 6 in both speed and ease of use while exceeding it in capabilities and functionality. However, the S6 does have its drawbacks but they are few. Like the S4 and S5, the battery life is pretty much just below average, most likely due to supporting the twin processors and that bright, hi-res screen. But unlike the S4 and S5, the battery in the S6 is not removable so you can't upgrade it with an increased capacity aftermarket version. This is most like due to the wireless charging capability. Samsung claims to combat this issue with built-in power management software that can extend battery life, enable rapid charging and improve battery performance as it learns the characteristics of the battery in conjunction with your usage patterns. I can attest that the S6 does charge fairly quickly although slightly slower using wireless charging. And Q1 wireless charging can be a quirky since the power adapter must match the amperage and voltage of the Samsung S6 adapter precisely for it to work reliably. If you're intent on using wireless charging, I recommend using a Q1 charger with an extra Samsung S6 adapter. It also only has a single, although highly capable, speaker which is surprisingly loud considering its small size. Like the S5, the S6 delivers much better high fidelity stereo sound when using the speaker jack or a bluetooth speaker/headphone connection. Another drawback is that the S6 has no MicroSD card slot so you are limited to built-in memory. However, Samsung does offer three memory options (32, 64 and 128 GB) as opposed to the usual two (16 / 32 or 32 / 64 GB) which entail additional costs with each increase in memory (another reason to opt for an S6 with increased memory as opposed to an S6 Edge for the same price). Overall, the S6 is an excellent response from Samsung after the unimpressive sales performance of the S5. While the S6 Edge is definitely the best looking smartphone on the market, you may not find its side areas worth the added expense when compared to the normal S6. The regular S6, though, has the edge (no pun intended) over its more glamorous sibling simply because the additional money required to purchased an Edge can be used to increase the built-in memory which, in my opinion, will do more to extend the functional life of the phone giving you more room for applications and other software. I definitely consider this phone to be the best on the market to date and have no problem recommending it for anyone looking for a phone packed with features and capabilities.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: ?° ?? ?° I got a chance to test a Galaxy S6 out and immediately bought one for my wife. I'm a complete phone nerd (XDA Developers Recognized Contributor, if that means anything to you) so I massively over analyze these things. It's a VERY nice phone but it's got some things that I consider drawbacks. For my wife, all the drawbacks listed below were non issues. She didn't care about these issues. So understand that my 'drawbacks' are completely subjective to your personal needs. But they are things that you should be aware of and consider if they mean anything to you before purchasing. ?????THE UPSIDES????? ? The screen is incredible. Like really incredible. The resolution is better than my eye can see. I use a Galaxy S4 as my regular phone and it has great resolution where you can't see individual pixels. I thought the S4 screen was as good as you can get, but the S6 screen takes it to a whole new level. Even though you can't see pixels on either screen, the higher resolution of the S6 screen makes everything look so sharp that it's nearly impossible to tell you are looking at a screen. It's that incredible. ? The design of the phone just feels more 'expensive'. I mean that in a good way. It feels just higher quality than previous models in the Galaxy S line. The S3 and S4 for example are often critiqued for having a plastic shell. The S6 has a metal band around the outside that just makes it feel 'premium' in your hand. It should also provide more protection for the device as well. ? TouchWiz is HEAVILY scaled back. I hate TouchWiz (Samsung's version of Android) It adds a layer of UI that is neither helpful nor intuitive. And it's a resource hog which slows the phone down for important tasks just so it can make the scrolling smoother, and other such useless tradeoffs. On the S6 TouchWiz was barely noticeable. The UI looks more like the standard Google Android Lollipop interface. It was all just much smoother and simpler and better and wonderful. ? Camera. 16 MP. And the images it takes look stunning on the super HD screen. Those photos on a larger high resolution monitor are simply stunning. ?????THE DOWNSIDES????? ? The battery is not removable or easily replaceable. A cell phone battery has a life of about 500 charge cycles. I tend to keep my phones for 2 years as daily users, then I keep my old phones for a variety of other purposes around the house. (My old HTC Sensation is hooked up to my stereo for use as a nice wifi streaming media player with a touchscreen UI, for example) I eventually have a need to replace batteries because I wear them out. I like being able to go on Amazon, spent $20 on a replacement battery, pop it in and be done. Additionally, even if you don't keep your phones that long, batteries fail sometimes. The stock batteries on the Galaxy S4 had some problems. They were minimal, but for those affected the battery absolutely had to be replaced. On the S4 it took 8 seconds and the problem was solved. On the S6 I'm sure it would be covered by warranty but it'd be a pain to take it somewhere to have it worked on should the issue come up. So no replaceable battery is a deal killer for me. This might not be an issue for you. If not, great! But be aware of the issue before making purchase decisions. ? You can't expand the storage with an SD Card. I don't want to live in the cloud. I hate the cloud. Sometimes I'm not on an LTE network. Sometimes I'm in the middle of nowhere but still want to show someone pictures of my kids. I got my wife the 32GB model. That sounds like a lot, but keep in mind that some of that is dedicated for the operating system and user apps. So you don't get to use all 32GB. This model is a 128GB model, which greatly limits my problem with not liking the cloud option. But it's still worth noting. Again, you might not care. If not, great! My wife doesn't keep a lot of stuff on her phone. She moves all her pictures to her computer and never loaded video to watch on her phone, so the storage

Textual Messages: For readers, my opinions on this device (ATT 32Gb version) is based off the experiences I had with this device for the passed few hours as today is launch day (April 10, 2015). I will continue to update this review in the future. This review should be the similar to Galaxy S6 on other carriers such as Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile. Pros: - No more plastics and cheap material. Samsung is finally giving us the hardware that we've long desired. By far, the best designed Galaxy phone to date imo - 5.1 in, QHD Super AMOLED screen. The screen is absolutely gorgeous that it hurts my eyes a bit. I'm still adjusting to it. - 16MP Camera with Smart OIS and 5MP front camera. Very well specs, but even better in performance. In short, the best camera on any android phones. I cannot believe that the picture came out so well in low light environment. You have to try it yourself to believe how great these low light pictures come out. - Gorilla Glass 4 panels for front and back (reminds me of the iPhone 4 and Nexus 4). Gorilla Glass are known to be tough and scratch resistance. - Comes in various colors: White, black, gold, green, blue (US only get the white, black, and gold unfortunately) - Comes in 32, 64, or 128GB of built-in memory. (For the 32gb - 3.7gb is for system partition, 25.2 for data/apps/pictures) - Less of the TouchWiz’s gimmicky features like the eye scroll, eye away from the screen pause. So we will not be experiencing the same slowdown or low storage as we did with earlier versions. If the GS4/5 were all about the features, this phone is all about the design. I do like the camera app and how they add a "close all" into the recent screen. - Rapid charging (need to use this more to confirm their claim of 4hrs of battery in 10 minute charge - UPDATED 5/1/15 i am getting about 1 to 1 1/2 hrs of use after the 10 minute charge, I'm guessing the 4hr claim is idle??) - Wireless charging - So if you have extra money that you want to drop for a wireless charging dock, you will be able to use it with this phone. Cons (Not necessarily apply to everyone): - No removable back panel. - No removable battery. I’m a battery hog, so I’m always draining my battery by 3-4pm. Not being able to just swap out my battery will be a pain, but let’s wait to see if the battery swap will be needed in a month when I fully test this device. - Lower battery capacity - 2550mAh compared to the 2600mAh in GS4 and 2800mAh in GS5. With the new processor, battery usage should be more efficient so it should not be a big deal, but end-users would rather the capacity to increase than decrease (Will update if this make through a day of normal usage, UPDATED 5/1/15 - I'm getting average about 8-9 hrs of normal usage, not ideal but I'll manage) - No waterproofing like the GS5, but I never used a smartphone that was waterproofed before, so not a big issue "to me" - No ability to swap out memory card – Might bother some Galaxy fans, but with the higher memory options, I do not think this is a huge problem. - Still no on-screen navigation button – Might only be a problem for "pure" Android fan. - Rear Camera and Flash sticks out a bit and not flush with the back panel. - Front and back glass is a potential problem as we all experiences with iPhone 4 and Nexus 4. Glass will break if you drop your phone at the right angle regardless how much stronger it is, so "case up". - The 1 speaker at the bottom is louder, however when you turn it on max, you will get some distortions in the audio quality. - There are some apps on there that I prefer downloading myself rather than them pushing it on me. There are some Social apps or Microsoft apps included such as OneDrive, facebook, etc. I personally use these apps, but there are people who don't. - I have been experiencing some weird stutters/lags while messing around the phone. This might because I'm loading a bunch of apps into it right now. I will need a few more days to look into this. Overall, this feels like a this is a solid de

Manufacturers don’t advertise or mention SAR prominently. phone parameters: {size, weight, resolution, ppi, RAM, ext Storage, camera, CPU, USA SAR rating} Samsung Galaxy S6: 5.65 x 2.78 x 0.27 in, 138 gm, 1440 x 2560 pixels, 5.1 in, 577 ppi, 3 GB RAM, NO MICROSD SLOT (bummer), Internal Storage upto 128 GB, Exynos 7420 Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex-A57, Gorilla Glass 4, 16 MP/5MP camera, SAR 1.15 W/kg (head), 1.16 W/kg (body) NANO SIM Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge: Slightly lower dimensions, 0.01 in thicker, 6 gm less weight, Same resolution, Curved Screen, HTC One M9: 5.69 x 2.74 x 0.38 in, 157 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 3 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 20.7 MP (rear), 4 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 810, Quad-core 1.5 GHz Cortex-A53 & Quad-core 2 GHz Cortex-A57 Samsung Galaxy S5: 5.59 x 2.85 x 0.32 in, 145 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5.1 in, 432 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, MSM8974-AC Processor: Quad core, 2500 MHz, Krait 400, 0.63 W/kg (head), 0.82 W/kg (body) HTC One M8: 5.76 x 2.78 x 0.37 in, 160 gm, 1080 x 1920 pixels, 5 in, 441 ppi, 2 GB RAM, microSD upto 128 GB!, 4 MP (rear), 5 MP(front for selfies), Qualcomm Snapdragon 801, Quad core, 2300 MHz, Krait 400, 0.94 W/kg (head), 0.83 W/kg (body) LG G3: 5.76 x 2.94 x 0.35 in, 149 gm, 2560 x 1440 pixels, 5.5 in, 538 pp

Textual Messages: *Just a quick disclaimer: I just got this phone today at BestBuy and Ive been playing with it for a lot of time nonstop. So far the experience is great and nearly perfect. I encountered no stutters, no lag, no glitches, nothing. I downloaded a couple graphically intensive games and it ran all of them very well. And all in all navigating through the Touchwiz UI was surprisingly smooth, something that I wish I could've complimented in the past Samsung phones. Right now the battery is at 31 percent for me.* Oh god this phone is a masterpiece. Let me just start out by saying that I've had the S5 for about 6 months now. I've mostly liked the phone. I liked it's dependable battery life, it's water and dust resistance, it's gorgeous display, etc. But I felt like some things about it were just a deal breaker. The Touchwiz UI was no better than looking in a trash can. It was slow to respond and had these peculiar bleeps and bloop sounds that were rather annoying than adding something convenient. The air gestures were dope to use first but it quickly got useless. The settings were a total mess and it left a sour taste to a myriad of users including me. I'm most defenitely not the person who will hate any phone because it is made out of plastic and love the other because it has metal, but I did like a well built phone. It's not like I would hate a plastic phone but the S5 did have a better design than the S4, but it still wasn't good. It was an improvement but not one that I loved holding instantly when I picked it up unlike HTC phones. All in all, the S5 wasn't for everyone. Then I saw this phone at MWC 2015. I didn't go the the event but I did watch some videos of this phone at the event. I saw that the S6 had better design, it was made out of glass, it had no expandable storage or battery replacement option, the Touchwiz UI was less "Touchweezy" and much cleaner and faster, it had much better specs inside, and there was an S6 edge version. I knew that the S6 was a phone that I've wanted from Samsung long time but I had to experience it firsthand to believe it. So I brought this phone Day 1 from Best Buy, and I have to say, this phone is almost everything that I've wished for. Pros: -Very premium to hold. There is actual metal around the edges, not just shiny plastic and the back is made out of glass, just like the Nexus 4. -The display is the best out of any phone in the market at the moment (4/10/15). Samsung upgraded the display from 1080p to 1440p. This makes it sharper and clearer, but you won't notice the difference that much side by side unless you look close. Also, in traditional Samsung fashion, the phone has great colors, excellent contrast ratio, etc. -Touchwiz UI is cleaner and better than ever. The whole UI seems fast and fluid, especially since it's running on Android 5.0 Lollipop. Some of the features like Air Gesture are no longer there in the settings. It looks flatter. -Great performance. Samsung ditched Qualcomm for their processors in their phone now and they decided to put their well known Exynos processor inside this phone. They also put 3 GB of DDR4 Ram now. The result is a beastly phone that does almost anything you throw at it. Graphically intensive games run very well even at high settings and everyday tasking is smooth. Runs like a beast. -Very fast to charge. I had the battery at 21% and charged it for 30 minutes and it instantly went up to 93%. -Camera has less noise on low light pictures and there is OIS now. Cons: -Not IP67, meaning its not dust proof or water resistant. It would've been nice if they still kept that extra protection from the S5 to this phone, but I haven't dropped a phone in the water for nearly a decade, so this isn't a huge problem for me. -Battery is not replacable. Its quite a sad thing for Samsung to cut down, since most of their old phones had this feature. If your battery is dead, then too bad, you have to either go to an Electronics support store and get it fixed or buy a new phon

Textual Messages: I'm neither Pro-Apple or Pro-Android, I'm simply pro-what works best for me. I had the S6 for one day, and that was long enough for me to figure out I wouldn't be happy with it for two years. My first tablet was a Samsung Galaxy Tab 2. I'd heard Samsung's Touchwiz had been improved upon since then, but as far as I'm concerned they didn't improve upon it enough. The device still comes pre-loaded with tons of useless apps.. some of which you can uninstall (and I did), but a great deal you're stuck with. I spent quite a few hours disabling apps and attempting to optimize the user experience to fit my needs. I was running an extremely basic (non-power user) setup, and I still had between 60-85% of my RAM being used up by all the processes running in the background. It doesn't matter if you don't use "S Health" or disable their weather app because you'd rather use another.. there's always going to be a bunch of unnecessary junk hogging your phone's resources, unless you void the warranty and root the device. What's the point of having 3GB of RAM if you can't make the most of it? I got over 5 hours of screen time and 10-11 hours total use before charging again--with 19% remaining--so the battery performed well on day one. It doesn't seem to do very good with standby time, though. My iPhone 5C and iPad Air 2 are capable of going for days on standby, and I can tell that wouldn't be the case with the S6. I wanted this phone for its camera. I've seen many fantastic photos shot with the S6 on Flickr and elsewhere. The results I got from the few test photos I took didn't impress me as much I thought they would, but this is a solid smartphone cam and one of the best you can find on the market right now. The display is also fantastic and one of the brightest I've seen. I had the brightness set at about 15-20% last night and it was still plenty bright. The music I was streaming via Rhapsody and bluetooth in the car was occasionally cutting out last night. This has never happened on my iPhone, so it's not a good sign to be experiencing playback issues with the S6 on the first day. Scrolling through websites and white in the Play Store seemed a bit jittery at times. And as far as the Android app selection is concerned, I guess how good the selection is all comes down to what your needs are. If you're someone like me who's into creative fields like design, photography and music, the iOS App Store is still miles ahead of the competition. So I'm sticking with my 16GB 5C for now. I've had it for almost two years and could probably count on two hands how many times I've dealt with app crashes and system restarts. It still gives me good battery life, charges in about an hour, and new iPhones are just around the corner, so I guess I'll see what Apple has to offer in September. Bottom line: Samsung still doesn't know how to make the most of an Android OS.

Textual Messages: This year, Samsung kept everything much more simple, intuitive, and beautiful. As a result, the Galaxy S6 is the best smartphone any person can currently. My review will focus on 3 key aspects: exterior design and materials, tech specs and hardware performance, and interface and ui. I will also point out outstanding and new features along the way. Exterior Design: Although at first the Galaxy S6 may not look completely different from the Galaxy S5, it is leaps and bounds ahead of its predecessor. The 2 sheets of Gorilla Glass 4 adorning the front and back make the phone feel extremely premium, resolving common complaint about the previous generation. It has a full metal band surrounding it, rather than a faux plastic one. Now, the feel in hand is comparable to the iPhone 6, and the design is elegant while familiar. Since the phone is so thin at 6.8 mm, the camera module protrudes slightly from the chassis, however it does not affect the phone. There is a sapphire lens to protect the camera, but placing the phone in a case should alleviate the protruding camera issue. Going to the front. there is a typical rectangular home button with a recent apps capacitive key on the left, with a back key on the right. Overall, the Galaxy S6 is the best phone Samsung has ever designed; however, the sealed battery and absence of a micro SD card slot may upset many. I do not replace the batteries in my phone nor add SD cards for storage, but customers from the Galaxy devices before may be unhappy. Tech Specs, Hardware Performance, Notable Features: The Galaxy in real life and on paper is a monster! Screen: It packs an amazing 5.1 Super AMOLED screen with a resolution of 2560x1440. The screen is capable of bright whites and dark blacks, and is the best mobile display currently on the market. Although Super AMOLED screens tend to have overly saturated colors, choosing AMOLED Cinema mode in settings creates natural colors. Fingerprint Scanner: Instead of a swipe based sensor, the new fingerprint scanner embedded in the home button is a capacitive touch based sensor, like the one on the iPhone 6. All you do is place your finger on the home button to unlock the phone. You can set up a total of 4 fingers, and the sensor is extremely reliable and useful. Every person using this phone should have the fingerprint sensor turned on since it provides good security while being intuitive to use. Camera: The camera is a 16 megapixel sensor with OIS. The Galaxy S6 has the best camera out of all Android phones, and easily competes with the iPhone 6 Plus. Because of the higher resolution, images are extremely detailed. The Optical Imaging Stabilization ensures pictures are clear, while videos are buttery smooth. The OIS also helps at night, as the sensor can pull in more light without creating a blurry image. The result is an amazing camera that can produce vibrant and beautiful pictures during the day, and a camera that can create accurate and bright pictures at night. The camera is also capable of 4K video recording, and slow motion video as well. An important new feature the Galaxy S6 incorporates is the double click on home button to activate. When you double click the home button, it opens the camera in less than 1 second! The "just shoot" mentality this camera gives its users is simply amazing and unmatched. For the pro users out there, the camera includes a professional mode that users can use to adjust ISO, white balance, and more settings. The front camera is 5 megapixels, and it is a strong front facing camera. Not much can be said about it, but it produces beautiful selfies and good colors, and is more than adequate for all users. Quick Charging and Wireless Charging: The Galaxy S6 is capable of adaptive quick charging using the charger supplied in the box. This charges the Galaxy S6 extremely fast; you can get about 4 hours of use only with 10 minutes of charging. The phone also supports other Qualcomm Quick Chargers. The Galaxy S6 also supports the

Helpful: 3 of 4 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I am skeptical by nature when new phones come out. The cellphone makers overpromise and underdeliver. Usually when a new phone gets released, I will wait a few months to see what everyone else says. Let the developers work out the kinks. By the time they do, months have gone by and they are already talking about the next model. I think about it, and I begrudgingly decide to hold out for that one. And the process repeats. Boy am I glad I did not do that to myself this time. What can I say about the Galaxy S6? The physical design is thought out and well balanced in the hand. At first glance it doesn't look like anything groundbreaking. And in my opinion, it's really not. But that's not a bad thing Samsung didn't break any new ground. What they did do was polish everything up. If my Galaxy S4 were a car and I took it to a detailer to get cleaned and waxed, the Galaxy S6 would drive out the other end. That's basically what this is all about. It's the greatest hits of the Galaxy and the iPhone in one device. Screen - Sharp crisp display, gives the iPhone6 a run for it's money. My eyes aren't good enough to even begin to appreciate this screen Battery - I'm one of those people who disables every app to get the last few percentage points out of my battery, no need to with this. I can get 7-8 hours easy - As a bonus, this charges very fast. Expect about 50% charge in 30 minutes Camera - Probably one of the biggest improvements. Autofocus makes taking nice clear pictures a breeze. - Some cool new features such as "slow mo" video and Virtual shot camera modes Fingerprint reader - Very responsive and not clunky like I was expecting Software - Some different menus but no major changes. Less bloatware and gimmicky apps that usually get included. Everything is streamlined - Very minimal drain on battery from background apps. Not sure if that is because of Samsung or Lollipop Speed - Run as many apps as you want. The processing power is incredible. - Transitions are smooth and there's a nice flow to the user experience Overall, this is a great phone and I am happy with my purchase. Samsung has finally taken the greatest hits of every other phone and put it all into one device. If you're one of those people who hang around on the fence like me waiting for the next model, take a chance on the S6. You won't regret it

Textual Messages: Coming from a Galaxy S5 phone, I am deeply disappointing in the battery life, the battery life is less than 60% of what I experienced on my previous S5. Saving this phone from 1 star, is the wireless charging. At an added expense I have a plantronics ledgend (bluetooth earpiece) and three wireless chargers where I can leave my phone (at my bedside, kitchen, and in my office) that makes the whole battery challenge a non issue except when I am traveling. I spend less than 1 hour on the phone, and 1 hour accessing applications and then I am ok for the day, but anything more than that and I need to charge at or before dinner. No GPS or Wi-Fi usage, thats just phone and apps. Looking at the battery information to see where it is going, the percentages don't' add up to 100% (often not even 70%), if there is an offending application I can't see where the battery power is going, if there is not then the hardware or android is using it. Don't know which.

Textual Messages: I got the opportunity to test this phone out before the official launch. I am a phone phonetic and always switch to latest and greatest phone and other gadgets. My last three phones that I personally used are S4, S5 and IPhone 6 Plus all on Verizon network. And I want to share my thoughts on the all new Samsung Galaxy S6. » First I will list some detail Specs with some the main ones that everyone wants to know about: Platform OS Android OS, v5.0.2 (Lollipop) Memory Card slot No Internal 32/64/128 GB, 3 GB RAM available Camera 16 MP, 2988 x 5312 pixels, optical image stabilization, autofocus, LED flash Video 2160p@30fps, 1080p@60fps, 720p@120fps, HDR, dual-video rec., check quality Secondary 5 MP, 1440p@30fps, dual video call, Auto HDR Battery Non-removable Li-Ion 2550 mAh battery Colors White Pearl, Black Sapphire, Gold Platinum, Blue Topaz Price group [About 700 Dollars without a contract] Battery life Endurance rating 73h » Here are some Pros and Cons that I actually agree with: Pros: * Gorgeous screen * Smart new camera tech * Excellent performance * Improved fingerprint scanner * Supports both wireless charging standards Cons: * Smudge-loving surfaces * No longer waterproof * Gets noticeably hot when pushed * Non-expandable storage * Average battery life » Key features I like about this phone: Faster Specs: Samsung Galaxy S line launched in 2010. But now, Samsung has finally caught up to Apple with the Galaxy S6 and the Galaxy S6 Edge, which has a curved display on both sides. Actually, make that surpass Apple, because these two glass-and-metal phones seriously bring it out. Want to switch from IPhone. That's not the only reason to potentially drop your iPhone -- or upgrade your aging Android. the Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge both sport faster, brighter and smarter cameras (16 MP on the back, 5 MP up front); a speedy octa-core Exynos processor (at least for the international version); and a 5.1-inch quad HD display. Plus, there's wireless charging built in as stated in Spec above. Color Choices for the family: the Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge actually look different based on how they reflect light. Samsung added a reflective structure to the Gorilla Glass 4.0 back to bring out more color. Depending on how you hold it. I like this feature CGalaxy S6 in include a bold Topaz Blue, White Pearl and Gold Platinum. The curved S6 Edge has a sleek Emerald Green option in addition to black, white and gold. Between the metal frame and Gorilla Glass front and back, the Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge feel solid but not slippery. The bottom edge looks a little too much like the iPhone 6 for my taste, as the headphone jack, charging port and speaker grilles are all in the same position, but it still looks good phone to get. Mobile Payments: Just like Apple try to do their thing. The Galaxy S6 will support Samsung Pay during the second half of the year, which will be compatible with both magnetic secure transmission (MST) and NFC for mobile payments. This means you should be able to use the S6 and S6 Edge at a wide range of retailers -- certainly more than Apple Pay with the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus apparently. Samsung says payments will be secured via Samsung Knox, fingerprint scanning and advanced tokenization. Lets see how this will work. » Key Feature I don't like about this phone: No removal battery/ MicroSD slot - I always admire Phones that have removal batteries. Just like apple try to eat consumer money. Samsung is becoming smarter and decided to drop it on us. It's important to note that the S6 and S6 Edge lack both a microSD Card slot for expansion and removable back panel and battery. Little good news is that the S6 starts with 32GB of memory. Yea, they had to do that to keep up with Apple. No more water proof model: Galaxy S6 will not be water resistant, At least you won't have to worry about the S5's annoying microUSB power flap. A lot of owners wound up tearing it off like myself. »»» Bottom line: »»» Will I recommend this Phone: Yes I only had it for

Textual Messages: For readers, my opinions on this device (ATT 32Gb version) is based off the experiences I had with this device for the passed few hours as today is launch day (April 10, 2015). I will continue to update this review in the future. This review should be the similar to Galaxy S6 on other carriers such as Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile. Pros: - No more plastics and cheap material. Samsung is finally giving us the hardware that we've long desired. By far, the best designed Galaxy phone to date imo - 5.1 in, QHD Super AMOLED screen. The screen is absolutely gorgeous that it hurts my eyes a bit. I'm still adjusting to it. - 16MP Camera with Smart OIS and 5MP front camera. Very well specs, but even better in performance. In short, the best camera on any android phones. I cannot believe that the picture came out so well in low light environment. You have to try it yourself to believe how great these low light pictures come out. - Gorilla Glass 4 panels for front and back (reminds me of the iPhone 4 and Nexus 4). Gorilla Glass are known to be tough and scratch resistance. - Comes in various colors: White, black, gold, green, blue (US only get the white, black, and gold unfortunately) - Comes in 32, 64, or 128GB of built-in memory. (For the 32gb - 3.7gb is for system partition, 25.2 for data/apps/pictures) - Less of the TouchWiz’s gimmicky features like the eye scroll, eye away from the screen pause. So we will not be experiencing the same slowdown or low storage as we did with earlier versions. If the GS4/5 were all about the features, this phone is all about the design. I do like the camera app and how they add a "close all" into the recent screen. - Rapid charging (need to use this more to confirm their claim of 4hrs of battery in 10 minute charge - UPDATED 5/1/15 i am getting about 1 to 1 1/2 hrs of use after the 10 minute charge, I'm guessing the 4hr claim is idle??) - Wireless charging - So if you have extra money that you want to drop for a wireless charging dock, you will be able to use it with this phone. Cons (Not necessarily apply to everyone): - No removable back panel. - No removable battery. I’m a battery hog, so I’m always draining my battery by 3-4pm. Not being able to just swap out my battery will be a pain, but let’s wait to see if the battery swap will be needed in a month when I fully test this device. - Lower battery capacity - 2550mAh compared to the 2600mAh in GS4 and 2800mAh in GS5. With the new processor, battery usage should be more efficient so it should not be a big deal, but end-users would rather the capacity to increase than decrease (Will update if this make through a day of normal usage, UPDATED 5/1/15 - I'm getting average about 8-9 hrs of normal usage, not ideal but I'll manage) - No waterproofing like the GS5, but I never used a smartphone that was waterproofed before, so not a big issue "to me" - No ability to swap out memory card – Might bother some Galaxy fans, but with the higher memory options, I do not think this is a huge problem. - Still no on-screen navigation button – Might only be a problem for "pure" Android fan. - Rear Camera and Flash sticks out a bit and not flush with the back panel. - Front and back glass is a potential problem as we all experiences with iPhone 4 and Nexus 4. Glass will break if you drop your phone at the right angle regardless how much stronger it is, so "case up". - The 1 speaker at the bottom is louder, however when you turn it on max, you will get some distortions in the audio quality. - There are some apps on there that I prefer downloading myself rather than them pushing it on me. There are some Social apps or Microsoft apps included such as OneDrive, facebook, etc. I personally use these apps, but there are people who don't. - I have been experiencing some weird stutters/lags while messing around the phone. This might because I'm loading a bunch of apps into it right now. I will need a few more days to look into this. Overall, this feels like a this is a solid de

Textual Messages: Samsung TV's are amazing. I have an 8K series smart TV and the thing is out of this world. I have a Samsung blu-ray player and it’s a very good blu-ray player. I have a Samsung Tablet and it is a great tablet. What the heck does this have to do with a Galaxy S6 Smart Phone review? Please keep reading I promise you won’t be sorry. First of all I just wanted to show that I am not a first time smart phone buyer nor first time galaxy buyer. As I said I had the S4 my wife’s S3 took a dump so I reluctantly gave her my S4 and bought an S6. I had the new S6 phone for almost a week. It has some great new features particularity the ability to keep the phone from locking when connected to anything in the exclusion list. Why is this important to me, it’s because I use my phone for work 99% - I work 100% remotely from home I am on it all day every day. Anyway, I quickly realized that most of the new features, why I liked this new phone, worked intermittently at best. I soon noticed I was dropping almost every call I made, the phone just seemed to be cursed. So, I took it back to where I bought it and they gave me a new one thinking I just got a bad phone. I was very skeptical and thought it was the new designed phone, crappy design and even worse mother boards. That Samsung had laid an egg with this new phone. Well, I was right!!!! This second phone acted and did the same thing. The battery lasts for like 30 minutes (being facetious) not too far off! The new features continued to act the same way, worked intermittently at best and the phone just seemed to be cursed. So, I called Samsung and this is where things get interesting. I worked with tech support and they couldn’t fix it they said send it in so we can fix it. I sent it in and within a week I had the phone back but I quickly noticed it was not zeroed out to factory settings as they said it would be. And there was no follow up call or e-mail or anything in the ticket online to say what they found. So, I called them and they told me “it has water damage” we can’t fix it!?!?!?!?!?! WTF!?!?!?!? Guys I’m telling you, I have used two of the phones now both brand new out of the box and they quite simply in short SUCK! I will now come across as a disgruntled customer spewing silly rhetoric but I don’t care. What I am saying is all true and if my phone really had water damage then the serial number sticker I specifically left stuck to the back of the phone would surely have water damage, it does not. I DID NOT CAUSE WATER DAMAGE TO MY PHONE. I pleaded with Samsung to replace my phone and they said they would talk to their supervisor and call me back. Well, you guessed it no call back after a week so far. I was involved with the first Pentium PC processors when they first came out, the company I worked for got a bad first batch and the big blue company that made them and installed them had to replace about 150 mother boards from that first batch. IT does happen. DO NOT BUY THE S6, you will be sorry, especially if you use the phone for anything other than calls, texting or taking pictures. SAMSUNG LAID AN ABSOLUTE EGG WITH THIS NEW S6!!!
