Textual Messages: I have been using the S6 for about 4 days now. My first impressions: It's beautiful, well made. The screen is excellent. Excellent clarity. It works great under direct sun light too. It's fast, very responsive. No lag. Call quality is excellent Finger print unlock features works very well. Much better than the S5 CONS: It's slippery - my wife dropped her 4 times the first day she got hers. Yikes. But it didn't break! I got her a case now... Battery life is not that great - and when you think about it, that's the most important aspect of a phone. Without power, it's useless. Example: it's 100% at bed time, by morning it's at 80%. I didn't use the phone that whole time as I was sleeping. I do not have alot of aps on the phone yet. ocation is turned off. I do have 2 emails synching, one is Yahoo and the other for work and it's set to synch every hour. Fully charged in the morning, I am down to 80% by noon. I check emails, FB in the AM then it sits on my desk mostly unused during work, other than a quick check at lunch. I used it some to check FB and and emails later and it was down to about 20% by 8 PM. My wife uses her phone more than me and gets similar numbers. My son today, at noon, was at 52%. He uses it alot as he plays various games. So in summary, it's a very nice phone in just about all aspects, except battery life. I took 2 stars off for this because that's the most important feature of a phone (call quality comes next); I DO NOT recommend the S6 if you are a heavy user.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I ordered the Samsung Galaxy S6 - Black - 64GB from AT&T with high hopes. The hardware felt excellent, but after two years on pure Android with a Nexus 5, I just couldn't downgrade to the TouchWiz interface. I returned the phone and ended up with a Moto G 3rd Gen Black - 16GB instead. The hardware is certainly less-powered than the S6, but I find the overall experience so much better with the near-pure Android software. If this phone was offered with stock android (no Samsung or AT&T "enhancements") I'd be right back to the phone in a heartbeat. Sadly no option exists, so I took my business back to Motorola.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I am coming from an S5. I bought the 64 gb and have 800 songs, including some apps, i have a total of 40 gigs left over; the phone is bloated with both companies apps. The camera sticks out, therefore if you want to have it naked (no case) than you are going to have to set it face down so as not to scratch the lens. The headphone jack is at the bottom, very annoying to say the least. Battery life is better than my S5, but charging the takes longer than the S5. Aesthetically speaking it is beautiful. Not a lot of hiccups with Touch Wiz and the sound coming from the speaker has GREATLY improved.

Helpful: 5 of 7 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I love this phone! I have had galaxy phones for a while, switched to an lg, I couldn't wait to go back when this one came out. The camera is the best I have seen on a cell phone and for what I do on a phone the 32gig will be more than sufficient so it doesn't matter that there is no card slot. I've only had the phone a couple of days but the battery life seems decent. The only thing I don't like about it is that the phone is ridiculously slick. It randomly slides off of any thing cloth so I am holding my breath (and the phone, tightly) until my case comes in tomorrow because I have 3 little people living in my house. So please, for your own sanity, order a case at the same time as the phone.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: The screen rotation doesn't work at all. We made sure it was on in the settings and also in the gallery settings as it doesn't work in the photos either. After Googling the issue, it appears that it's a common problem that Samsung has acknowledged. I'm not happy! They aren't saying what exactly is causing the issue. Praying that they have an update soon to take care of the issue. It will probably be the last time I purchase a Samsung product though.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I have been very happy with my S6. I especially like the wireless charging and biometric reader. I was too lazy to use the password or pattern on my last phone so now my phone is more secure. It is really annoying that there is no Micro-SD card anymore. I really miss that. That was much easier for moving files between devices, but it is what it is. I am still happy I upgraded from my old S3.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: This phone has been really great, but don't expect a huge difference from lesser models. There have been a fewhile buggy issues that usually resolve with a reset. Still, it is fluid and sleek, and the video is clean looking. The battery is good to average if you use it more than a few hours on WiFi each day. I would recommend this phone, at least for now.

Helpful: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: my only disappointment is the the rear facing camera lens has already cracked but it was no due to a fall or anything of that nature. The good news is that it has not impacted the pictures however it is disappointing that my new phone of a month is already not at a 100%.

Helpful: 3 of 4 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: MY FIRST SMARTPHONE AND I AM EXCITED WITH IT. I CAN FIND ANY BIT OF INFORMATION I WANT , ANYWHERE IN THE WORLD, ON ANY SUBJECT OR MEMBER OF SOCIETY. IT IS QUICK AND EASY TO USE AND I LEARN MORE MEANS EVERY DAY. MY SON WHO USES ANOTHER MAKE WANTS ONE FOR HIS WORK.

I upgraded from my s3 (which i loved) to this phone a few months ago. I was pleased at first but quickly had some minor things and then larger issues. (Yes some of these are very minor preference issues. But never had so many with a new phone.) 1. no flashlight app 2. no direct dial widget (it always asks which number cant select one number to use) 3. screens do not circle through must go back and forth (really annoying if you have like 5 screens) 4. does not mute sounds when headphones plugged in (notifications, ring tones,etc..library anyone) 5. does not stay logged on to wifi reliably even with strong wifi signal 6.eats through my data plan like crazy 6. already running out of memory and ram (phones memory has a fair percent used up you cant touch like 8gb out of 32) 7. battery life has gotten worse and worse (like from fulll charge to 30% sitting in my purse for 3 hours and yes checked no third party apps doing this) 8. phone has started overheating 9. random issues with calls (like not going through of freezing) 10.face hits keypad when talking on phone (I have friends with this phone who have another list of issues I could add to this) To try and solve these issues I have had to install the following programs 1.flash light widget app 2. direct dial widget app (speeddial) 3. alternate launcher (nova launcher) 4. sound controller (sound about) 5. wifi connect app (wifi keep alive) 6.cleaner/speed up app (360 security) 7.batter saver (du battery saver) 8. data saver app (opera max) I have tried rebooting phone, wiping phone, cleaning cash, using it with and with out above apps, trying different ones, trying different combinations of apps listed, etc...reading numerous articles and message boards, watching a lot of youtube tips and tricks and so on. If I could I would return this phone don't know what else is better but honestly something has to be better than this!

This is a 5 star 3G phone but only a 3 star 4G LTE phone. It’s an excellent phone in many ways except for the strength of the 4G LTE connection on the Sprint Network. Most of the time I can only get 1 bar signal strength on a 4G LTE connection. I set my phone on 3G CDMA to be able to use it effectively. The issue with the strength of the 4G LTE connection has been known since the phone was release on April 2015. You can Google this topic to read more about it. I think one other phone carrier may also have this issue. I’ve had 4G LTE strength connectivity issues since I purchased this phone on April 2015. There were rumors on the Sprint forum that a forthcoming software upgrade would fix the problem. I waited patient for 3 months and just upgraded the system software for the 2nd time to Android 5.1.1 and the connectivity issue still have not be fixed as of late July 2015. There has been an additional carrier update, not operating system update, and the problem still have not be resolved. This problem must be very difficult to solve, otherwise it would have been fixed by now. When I’m on the interstate highway, I only get strong 4G LTE reception when I’m passing by a cellular tower. As soon as I’m a quarter mile away, the signal weakens significantly to 1 bar. My previous phone was an iphone5 and on that same stretch of highway, I would get strong 4G LTE connection for miles. At various locations around town I now get very weak 4G signal whereas I had relatively strong signal on the iphone5. I visited several Sprint stores to see if their display models get strong signals. The display models in all of the stores that I visited did get strong 4G LTE signal, but my phone also got strong signal in the store. I speculate that either the stores are located near cell phone towers or they have some type of signal booster device in the store. My work place has a cellular signal booster so I know that cellular signal strength can be increased by such a device. As soon as I traveled about a quarter mile from the store, the 4G LTE signal strength dropped off dramatically. Another issue that I have with the phone is the battery life. Initially, after setting up the phone, my battery was draining about 5% per hour. After much research, I found that I can extend the battery life significantly if I turn off Wi-Fi, location, and mobile data when not needed. Turning off mobile data really extends the battery life but it is an inconvenience to constantly turn it on and off as needed. My old iphone5 never required such battery management strategy. I amaze me how a premium flagship product can be released with such a major flaw. UPDATED REVIEW 08 26 2015 I just updated the system software and it solves the issue of the weak 4G LTE connection. My 4G LTE connection is now acceptable. The new system software update also appears to extend the battery life. I no longer have the turn off Mobile Data to extend the battery life.

?° ?? ?° I got a chance to test a Galaxy S6 out and immediately bought one for my wife. I'm a complete phone nerd (XDA Developers Recognized Contributor, if that means anything to you) so I massively over analyze these things. It's a VERY nice phone but it's got some things that I consider drawbacks. For my wife, all the drawbacks listed below were non issues. She didn't care about these issues. So understand that my 'drawbacks' are completely subjective to your personal needs. But they are things that you should be aware of and consider if they mean anything to you before purchasing. ?????THE UPSIDES????? ? The screen is incredible. Like really incredible. The resolution is better than my eye can see. I use a Galaxy S4 as my regular phone and it has great resolution where you can't see individual pixels. I thought the S4 screen was as good as you can get, but the S6 screen takes it to a whole new level. Even though you can't see pixels on either screen, the higher resolution of the S6 screen makes everything look so sharp that it's nearly impossible to tell you are looking at a screen. It's that incredible. ? The design of the phone just feels more 'expensive'. I mean that in a good way. It feels just higher quality than previous models in the Galaxy S line. The S3 and S4 for example are often critiqued for having a plastic shell. The S6 has a metal band around the outside that just makes it feel 'premium' in your hand. It should also provide more protection for the device as well. ? TouchWiz is HEAVILY scaled back. I hate TouchWiz (Samsung's version of Android) It adds a layer of UI that is neither helpful nor intuitive. And it's a resource hog which slows the phone down for important tasks just so it can make the scrolling smoother, and other such useless tradeoffs. On the S6 TouchWiz was barely noticeable. The UI looks more like the standard Google Android Lollipop interface. It was all just much smoother and simpler and better and wonderful. ? Camera. 16 MP. And the images it takes look stunning on the super HD screen. Those photos on a larger high resolution monitor are simply stunning. ?????THE DOWNSIDES????? ? The battery is not removable or easily replaceable. A cell phone battery has a life of about 500 charge cycles. I tend to keep my phones for 2 years as daily users, then I keep my old phones for a variety of other purposes around the house. (My old HTC Sensation is hooked up to my stereo for use as a nice wifi streaming media player with a touchscreen UI, for example) I eventually have a need to replace batteries because I wear them out. I like being able to go on Amazon, spent $20 on a replacement battery, pop it in and be done. Additionally, even if you don't keep your phones that long, batteries fail sometimes. The stock batteries on the Galaxy S4 had some problems. They were minimal, but for those affected the battery absolutely had to be replaced. On the S4 it took 8 seconds and the problem was solved. On the S6 I'm sure it would be covered by warranty but it'd be a pain to take it somewhere to have it worked on should the issue come up. So no replaceable battery is a deal killer for me. This might not be an issue for you. If not, great! But be aware of the issue before making purchase decisions. ? You can't expand the storage with an SD Card. I don't want to live in the cloud. I hate the cloud. Sometimes I'm not on an LTE network. Sometimes I'm in the middle of nowhere but still want to show someone pictures of my kids. I got my wife the 32GB model. That sounds like a lot, but keep in mind that some of that is dedicated for the operating system and user apps. So you don't get to use all 32GB. This model is a 128GB model, which greatly limits my problem with not liking the cloud option. But it's still worth noting. Again, you might not care. If not, great! My wife doesn't keep a lot of stuff on her phone. She moves all her pictures to her computer and never loaded video to watch on her phone, so the storage

I'm own a Galaxy S5 and I too was skeptical when the Galaxy S6 was announced due to the sealed in battery and non expandable memory. Then I realized that while I owned the Galaxy S5 for a full year, I never even once replaced its battery. I also realized that I was only using 30 GB out of the 64 GB micro SD card I have had on my S5 for a year. Those two facts made the non replaceable battery and non expandable memory non issues for me. Now let's talk about the Galaxy S6. I was never bothered by the use of plastic on the previous models, but the new design lines are beautiful. The phone is a work of art. It feels lighter and thinner than the S5. The screen is the most beautiful on a smartphone. The new fingerprint sensor is a lot better and makes unlocking your phone much much faster and accurate. The speaker is louder than the GS5 and I like the fact that it's placed on the bottom right. I also like how the power button is now lower on the right side and that the volume rockers are two separate buttons. I haven't taken that many pictures with the rear camera, but it's a lot snappier and pictures are better than on the GS5. I love how much faster the camera starts and love that I can double tap the home button to launch the camera. . The front facing camera is amazing. No more bad selfies. I also like the fact that you can take a picture by touching the heart rate sensor. The whole phone is a lot faster and data transfer rates are also faster. Touchwiz is lighter and cleaner and Lollipop is a beautiful, fluid OS. Another great feature is fast charging. I was able to go from 0 to 100% battery in just a little over an hour. Who needs removable battery when you can recharge that quickly? The screen is so sharp, WOW! Anyway, this phone is a beast. I highly recommend it.

I bought my 64gb White Sprint S6 on launch day, and having upgraded from an S3, I am thrilled with its performance. That said, it is not without its drawbacks. My least favorite thing about this phone is that in a dark room the LED's on the capacitive touch buttons are not linked to the screen brightness, and are absolutely blinding. I exchanged the white for the black sapphire and I find that the touch lights are much less noticeable, and the screen looks better with a darker bezel. This would not be a problem on the white model if you could simply turn down or turn off these backlights as you could on the S3, S4, and S5, but apparently in its effort to "De-bloat" the touchwiz interface, Samsung removed this option (and many other useful options) from the preferences menu. Hopefully this option will be restored in future updates (still hasn't been as of 5.1.1), as it is unlikely to be resolved through apps without first gaining root access. The stock alarm clock is even stripped in options; where you used to control the number and duration of "snooze" operations allowed, now you have only the option of 3x5 minutes. Most of the gimmicks of previous generations have been removed (ie S-beam, air-gestures, etc.), which for the most part is an improvement, and the majority of stock bloat apps can at least be disabled, if not removed. I went with the 64gb simply because the 32gb has only 23gb of usable space, which should be plenty for most people. but I prefer not to get near the limits. The wireless charging works great, even through a thick case (the water resistant Supcase). The other "gimmicks" of this generation are much more useful than in the past, the fingerprint reader works as it should, very fast and reliable, the heartrate monitor works great on the bare phone, but can be more difficult to use with a case on the white S6, works fine with the black phone since the light used to read your fingerprint doesn't reflect off of the phone as badly. Also, the ergonomics are flipped from my S3, which aligned the buttons with your fingers when holding the phone in the right hand, whereas the S6 has the buttons placed for holding the phone in the left hand, with your thumb on the volume rocker and your middle finger on the power button. Overall, after 3 months this is one of the most stable mobile devices I have ever used, the performance is extraordinary and its features continue to be useful and impressive.

Wow, what a difference a year makes. While last year's S5 took many steps in the right direction(being somewhat waterproof with better material and craftsmanship), it still wasn't there to make it a mouth-watering phone yet, like what HTC did when they first introduced their One M7, or whenever Apple introduces a new iPhone size. This year, Samsung has finally learned from both of their competitors, and made a phone that has all the good qualities of both, plus some of their own. Finally, this is the Galaxy S that you've always wanted and been dreaming of. * LOOKS/FORM-FACTOR/MATERIALS: The very first thing you notice when you handle the phone, is its new design and form factor - finally Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful. The metal fully wraps around the edges ofthe phone. The back is beautiful, the sides are beautiful - heck, even the buttons are beautiful. It feels great in the hand, and oozes style and sophistication. * SCREEN: The very next thing you notice, of course, is the screen. I am continually pleasantly surprised at the evolution of Samsung's AMOLED technology - it has now became the best screen in the industry, hands down. I used to defend the LCD technology of the HTC M7, and at that point it was in fact overall superior to the Samsung S4 because the AMOLED then had issues in the sun, and color reproduction(it was too saturated and not natural). But now, they have fixed those issues, and the S6's screen is just quite simply the best. If you don't believe it, just compare an LG/Samsung OLED TV to any LED TVs today. I still think 5.1 inches for a screen of a PHONE is still too big, but overall, for what smartphones represent nowadays, it is acceptable - we have conditioned ourselves to accept the bigger sizes of smartphones(I remember when I first held a 4.2" smartphone when it first came out - the HTC HD2 - and thought, "what the h3ll is this monstrosity??"). * It doesn't hurt that Samsung boosted up the resolution to 1440 x 2560 pixels, which is approximately 577 ppi in pixel density. Although this is quite overkill right now, it's always nice to have the latest and greatest technology - that's the reason why we buy these overpriced phones in the first place, isn't it? It is also very bright, and sunlit legibility is excellent. Color reproduction is quite accurate, and like the S5, you can choose different color modes to suit your liking. *BATTERY LIFE: An important aspect to discuss is the battery life, now more than ever because there is no removable back cover to make replacing the battery easily like before, not to mention there is no microSD slot for you to add memory space to your phone. Comparatively, the S6 Edge is supposed to last a little less than the S6 regular, which I've read is less than last year's S5. But I'm one of those who are always around a charger, and I always carry external battery packs in my backpack when I travel, so that's never a concern. Seriously, who even buys an extra battery anymore - which you can only use for a single specific phone model - when your external battery can charge ANY and ALL phones and tablets?? This scenario only makes sense if your work is so demanding that you don't have extra time to charge the phone, and need to swap batteries IMMEDIATELY. I don't think that scenario is realistic nowadays when external batteries are so small, light, and cheap. My S6 goes from 100% at 10 am to about 20% at 10 pm with moderate use - so no complaints there. I get home, plug it up, and there are no issues. * What's better this year, is the wireless charging standards are already built into the phone, so you can just buy a charging pad for about $50 and feel even more cool. * USER INTERFACE/SOFTWARE: The Samsung user interface called TouchWiz used to be bloated and sluggish. It would slow down(navigating throughout the phone, switching between apps, and using

Helpful: 2 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: For readers, my opinions on this device (ATT 32Gb version) is based off the experiences I had with this device for the passed few hours as today is launch day (April 10, 2015). I will continue to update this review in the future. This review should be the similar to Galaxy S6 on other carriers such as Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile. Pros: - No more plastics and cheap material. Samsung is finally giving us the hardware that we've long desired. By far, the best designed Galaxy phone to date imo - 5.1 in, QHD Super AMOLED screen. The screen is absolutely gorgeous that it hurts my eyes a bit. I'm still adjusting to it. - 16MP Camera with Smart OIS and 5MP front camera. Very well specs, but even better in performance. In short, the best camera on any android phones. I cannot believe that the picture came out so well in low light environment. You have to try it yourself to believe how great these low light pictures come out. - Gorilla Glass 4 panels for front and back (reminds me of the iPhone 4 and Nexus 4). Gorilla Glass are known to be tough and scratch resistance. - Comes in various colors: White, black, gold, green, blue (US only get the white, black, and gold unfortunately) - Comes in 32, 64, or 128GB of built-in memory. (For the 32gb - 3.7gb is for system partition, 25.2 for data/apps/pictures) - Less of the TouchWiz’s gimmicky features like the eye scroll, eye away from the screen pause. So we will not be experiencing the same slowdown or low storage as we did with earlier versions. If the GS4/5 were all about the features, this phone is all about the design. I do like the camera app and how they add a "close all" into the recent screen. - Rapid charging (need to use this more to confirm their claim of 4hrs of battery in 10 minute charge - UPDATED 5/1/15 i am getting about 1 to 1 1/2 hrs of use after the 10 minute charge, I'm guessing the 4hr claim is idle??) - Wireless charging - So if you have extra money that you want to drop for a wireless charging dock, you will be able to use it with this phone. Cons (Not necessarily apply to everyone): - No removable back panel. - No removable battery. I’m a battery hog, so I’m always draining my battery by 3-4pm. Not being able to just swap out my battery will be a pain, but let’s wait to see if the battery swap will be needed in a month when I fully test this device. - Lower battery capacity - 2550mAh compared to the 2600mAh in GS4 and 2800mAh in GS5. With the new processor, battery usage should be more efficient so it should not be a big deal, but end-users would rather the capacity to increase than decrease (Will update if this make through a day of normal usage, UPDATED 5/1/15 - I'm getting average about 8-9 hrs of normal usage, not ideal but I'll manage) - No waterproofing like the GS5, but I never used a smartphone that was waterproofed before, so not a big issue "to me" - No ability to swap out memory card – Might bother some Galaxy fans, but with the higher memory options, I do not think this is a huge problem. - Still no on-screen navigation button – Might only be a problem for "pure" Android fan. - Rear Camera and Flash sticks out a bit and not flush with the back panel. - Front and back glass is a potential problem as we all experiences with iPhone 4 and Nexus 4. Glass will break if you drop your phone at the right angle regardless how much stronger it is, so "case up". - The 1 speaker at the bottom is louder, however when you turn it on max, you will get some distortions in the audio quality. - There are some apps on there that I prefer downloading myself rather than them pushing it on me. There are some Social apps or Microsoft apps included such as OneDrive, facebook, etc. I personally use these apps, but there are people who don't. - I have been experiencing some weird stutters/lags while messing around the phone. This might because I'm loading a bunch of apps into it right now. I will need a few more days to look into this. Overall, this feels like a this is a solid de

Textual Messages: This review is from the perspective of someone coming from the iPhone line to the Samsung S line. I'll be updating this review as time goes on to share what I notice. THE POSITIVE... "The first things that I noticed about this phone were the beautiful display(still set as adaptive in settings) and the camera." SCREEN: The display is visibly superior to the iPhone at first glance. This phone feels like the perfect bridge between the iPhone 6 and the 6+ in a way that improves visibility but maintains an appropriate size. I came from the iPhone5, so the jump in size was odd at first, but I quickly became accustomed to it. I decided to get a thin glass screen guard to preserve its integrity through my adventures. I have not done enough yet to comment any more on the screen quality, I'll be viewing more photographs and videos in the following weeks so that I have more to say. CAMERA: A lot of my friends who are into photography and the few photography professionals I know tend to rave about the quality of the camera on the iPhone, but as a person who has dabbled in the art for some time now I can honestly say I prefer shooting with the S6. The settings available in the native camera app are a good step towards professional shooting options. so far I have played around with most of the photo and video settings and am most impressed by the UHD film setting. The resolution is breathtaking on the 5.2in screen in a way that my computer monitor can't even approach(and I have a decent quality monitor). In terms of editing photos, I'm using Autodesk Pixlr, fantastic and quick... I'll be playing around with the camera a lot more moving forward. Not a perfect representation of the resolution quality, but I'll be posting some of the shots to https://instagram.com/das_luk/ All shots after April 16th will be taken with the S6 unless I include #DSLR. Check them out if you are curious. INTERFACE AND EASE OF USE: "I should preface this with the fact that I'm a tech savvy individual, so there may be some bias, but I love Android so far." The interface was clean, nothing in your face and it didn't feel like there was a lot of bloatware or unnecessary apps. The first thing I did was remove the Amazon widget and the Galaxy Essentials. Just hold and drag to delete and it's looking good. I'm currently using the "Forest Theme", free on the theme store, but I'll be designing my own theme in the near future. I'll add more on that later. Most of the apps I needed or wanted were already on the phone. I suppose some could consider this bloatware, but they were all widely used applications like Uber, Facebook, and various Google apps. Organizing apps and adjusting the interface is easy and intuitive. Within an hour the phone felt like it was mine. This could feel like a lot for an iPhone user, but there are a lot of features that go above and beyond IOS that are found natively on Android(widgets, sizing, themes, ect). Automatic brightness is on point. The phone never feels too bright or dim, I've used it in a wide variety of lighting One negative that I found is that there are not settings for the capacitive key lights. They don't adjust with the phones screen brightness, so they can feel bright and invasive in low lighting situations. They light up every time you touch the screen so it gets frustrating. I looked it up online to see if I was looking in the wrong place, but apparently Samsung removed the settings from the S6 after having it on the previous generations. There is a workaround with root modding that I will be trying, more on that later. The ability to customize the interface and basic functionality of Android is what convinced me to make the switch in the first place, as I play around with it more I'll provide updates. I have yet to play any graphic intensive games yet, but so far, moving between apps, playing with photo and video, and multitasking, I have noticed the pho

Textual Messages: Wow, what a difference a year makes. While last year's S5 took many steps in the right direction(being somewhat waterproof with better material and craftsmanship), it still wasn't there to make it a mouth-watering phone yet, like what HTC did when they first introduced their One M7, or whenever Apple introduces a new iPhone size. This year, Samsung has finally learned from both of their competitors, and made a phone that has all the good qualities of both, plus some of their own. Finally, this is the Galaxy S that you've always wanted and been dreaming of. * LOOKS/FORM-FACTOR/MATERIALS: The very first thing you notice when you handle the phone, is its new design and form factor - finally Samsung has completed their transformation of getting rid of all that ugly plastic parts. Now it is just all glass and metal, and now it is truly beautiful. The metal fully wraps around the edges ofthe phone. The back is beautiful, the sides are beautiful - heck, even the buttons are beautiful. It feels great in the hand, and oozes style and sophistication. The S6 Edge is just so unique-looking - it is the most beautiful phone I've seen in a long time. And contrary to what people might say or what you might think, the two sloped edges are not awkward to handle, does not dig into your skin, and is not uncomfortable to grip. * SCREEN: The very next thing you notice, of course, is the screen. I am continually pleasantly surprised at the evolution of Samsung's AMOLED technology - it has now became the best screen in the industry, hands down. I used to defend the LCD technology of the HTC M7, and at that point it was in fact overall superior to the Samsung S4 because the AMOLED then had issues in the sun, and color reproduction(it was too saturated and not natural). But now, they have fixed those issues, and the S6's screen is just quite simply the best. If you don't believe it, just compare an LG/Samsung OLED TV to any LED TVs today. I still think 5.1 inches for a screen of a PHONE is still too big, but overall, for what smartphones represent nowadays, it is acceptable - we have conditioned ourselves to accept the bigger sizes of smartphones(I remember when I first held a 4.2" smartphone when it first came out - the HTC HD2 - and thought, "what the h3ll is this monstrosity??"). * It doesn't hurt that Samsung boosted up the resolution to 1440 x 2560 pixels, which is approximately 577 ppi in pixel density. Although this is quite overkill right now, it's always nice to have the latest and greatest technology - that's the reason why we buy these overpriced phones in the first place, isn't it? It is also very bright, and sunlit legibility is excellent. Color reproduction is quite accurate, and like the S5, you can choose different color modes to suit your liking. *BATTERY LIFE: An important aspect to discuss is the battery life, now more than ever because there is no removable back cover to make replacing the battery easily like before, not to mention there is no microSD slot for you to add memory space to your phone. Comparatively, the S6 Edge is supposed to last a little less than the S6 regular, which I've read is less than last year's S5. But I'm one of those who are always around a charger, and I always carry external battery packs in my backpack when I travel, so that's never a concern. Seriously, who even buys an extra battery anymore - which you can only use for a single specific phone model - when your external battery can charge ANY and ALL phones and tablets?? This scenario only makes sense if your work is so demanding that you don't have extra time to charge the phone, and need to swap batteries IMMEDIATELY. I don't think that scenario is realistic nowadays when external batteries are so small, light, and cheap. My S6 goes from 100% at 10 am to about 20% at 10 pm with moderate use - so no complaints there. I get home, plug it up, and there are no issues. * What's better this year, is the wireless charging standards are already built into th

Helpful: 4 of 6 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: This year, Samsung kept everything much more simple, intuitive, and beautiful. As a result, the Galaxy S6 is the best smartphone any person can currently. My review will focus on 3 key aspects: exterior design and materials, tech specs and hardware performance, and interface and ui. I will also point out outstanding and new features along the way. Exterior Design: Although at first the Galaxy S6 may not look completely different from the Galaxy S5, it is leaps and bounds ahead of its predecessor. The 2 sheets of Gorilla Glass 4 adorning the front and back make the phone feel extremely premium, resolving common complaint about the previous generation. It has a full metal band surrounding it, rather than a faux plastic one. Now, the feel in hand is comparable to the iPhone 6, and the design is elegant while familiar. Since the phone is so thin at 6.8 mm, the camera module protrudes slightly from the chassis, however it does not affect the phone. There is a sapphire lens to protect the camera, but placing the phone in a case should alleviate the protruding camera issue. Going to the front. there is a typical rectangular home button with a recent apps capacitive key on the left, with a back key on the right. Overall, the Galaxy S6 is the best phone Samsung has ever designed; however, the sealed battery and absence of a micro SD card slot may upset many. I do not replace the batteries in my phone nor add SD cards for storage, but customers from the Galaxy devices before may be unhappy. Tech Specs, Hardware Performance, Notable Features: The Galaxy in real life and on paper is a monster! Screen: It packs an amazing 5.1 Super AMOLED screen with a resolution of 2560x1440. The screen is capable of bright whites and dark blacks, and is the best mobile display currently on the market. Although Super AMOLED screens tend to have overly saturated colors, choosing AMOLED Cinema mode in settings creates natural colors. Fingerprint Scanner: Instead of a swipe based sensor, the new fingerprint scanner embedded in the home button is a capacitive touch based sensor, like the one on the iPhone 6. All you do is place your finger on the home button to unlock the phone. You can set up a total of 4 fingers, and the sensor is extremely reliable and useful. Every person using this phone should have the fingerprint sensor turned on since it provides good security while being intuitive to use. Camera: The camera is a 16 megapixel sensor with OIS. The Galaxy S6 has the best camera out of all Android phones, and easily competes with the iPhone 6 Plus. Because of the higher resolution, images are extremely detailed. The Optical Imaging Stabilization ensures pictures are clear, while videos are buttery smooth. The OIS also helps at night, as the sensor can pull in more light without creating a blurry image. The result is an amazing camera that can produce vibrant and beautiful pictures during the day, and a camera that can create accurate and bright pictures at night. The camera is also capable of 4K video recording, and slow motion video as well. An important new feature the Galaxy S6 incorporates is the double click on home button to activate. When you double click the home button, it opens the camera in less than 1 second! The "just shoot" mentality this camera gives its users is simply amazing and unmatched. For the pro users out there, the camera includes a professional mode that users can use to adjust ISO, white balance, and more settings. The front camera is 5 megapixels, and it is a strong front facing camera. Not much can be said about it, but it produces beautiful selfies and good colors, and is more than adequate for all users. Quick Charging and Wireless Charging: The Galaxy S6 is capable of adaptive quick charging using the charger supplied in the box. This charges the Galaxy S6 extremely fast; you can get about 4 hours of use only with 10 minutes of charging. The phone also supports other Qualcomm Quick Chargers. The Galaxy S6 also supports the

Helpful: 2 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I absolutely love this phone! In the past I've had Motorola and Apple. I was trying to decide whether to get the new iPhone 6 or the Samsung Galaxy S6. I'm immensely happy that I went with Samsung. I can safely say that I will not be going back to Apple any time soon. The most common complaint I've read and heard is that the battery life is awful. I'm rarely down to 10% with even heavy usage. I was skeptical of the fast charging technology, but it definitely works. Pros: I was worried that the screen would be too big, but it's the perfect size. Amazingly clear screen Good battery life Not much bloatware Amazing camera! It's supposed to set a new standard for phones Rapid charging is nice Wireless charging is a nice feature Very thin The phone doesn't have any cheap looking material Eh... I honestly don't care about the removable battery. My past two phones haven't had it and I have had no battery issues, so I'm not missing it. I was originally horrified at the lack of and SD card, but 32GB is plenty for me. I've added all of my apps, tons of pictures, and 1,000 high quality songs and I still have 10GB left. Cons The back camera sticks out quite a bit. The phone lags a bit I think this is me more getting used to the phone, but when I text I must hit a button because it unfocuses and I have to touch the screen again No waterproofing like the Samsung S5 The material is far better, but I fear that all the glass will just make it easier to break I would 100% recommend this phone. I will most likely never get another iPhone and I will definitely not get another Motorola.

Helpful: 2 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I actually have the S6 edge. I absolutely have this phone. I bought the 64g so I would not have to worry about storage. It by far and away is the best phone I have ever used. The fact that you cannot change out the battery does not bother me. In all the years I have had smart phones I have never had to change a battery. Of course I only keep a phone for about 3 years and then move on due to tech advancements. It was easy to set up and I had very little to do to get all my apps up and running. I rarely if ever take photos with my phone but if I have to this after testing is amazing. Being a photographer I am kind of picky and I may use this one more than in the past. I have been a galaxy fan ever since they came out. There will always be detractors if they are an apple devotee but I stick with Samsung. The Iphone also does not have an sd card and I am grateful not to be tied to the their app store. I think all the hype about loss of the card slot and removable battery is ridiculous since I know most are out to get the latest and the best. I have a tablet to do major work on...my phone is for convenience. You cannot expect a phone to take the place of your tablet or laptop. They never will. I never download every app available and I think this is the problem with most complaints. Load what you use ...even a computer gets slow if you have too many apps loaded and open. I insure this phone on my homeowners policy under scheduled property. If anything happens to it it will get replaced and so I am not worried just enjoying it.

Textual Messages: Truly an outstanding flagship device - a rethinking of the Galaxy series and beautiful new flagship for Samsung. Don't get me wrong, functionally I prefer my personal cell, the Nexus 6, but when I got the S6 as my office device I was a happy man. You don't see the lags you did with the S5, it has a smoother experience and compliments Android L perfectly. Battery life isn't great; I MUCH prefer the Nexus 6 for battery life and would love a removable battery for hot swapping. In its favor, the display on the S6 is amazing (which ironically may be the reason the battery doesn't last) and it just feels the right size. I love my Nexus, but it's a big one, whereas the S6 just seems better fitted. The hardware is great, Samsung's TouchWiz isn't that intrusive, and overall you'll be thrilled with this device. Personally I prefer the Nexus but that may have more to do with the pure android and guaranteed updates that come with any Nexus device.

I upgraded from the Samsung Galaxy S4. These are the things I like better about the S6: Brighter display. Two part volume button makes it easier to adjust the volume. Being able to close apps by touching the icon to the left of the home button instead of having to hold down the home button. Using the flashlight on the quick settings panel rather than needing a separate app. Being able to scroll down the settings panel rather than having to choose from the different types of settings in advance. Even though the screen is slightly bigger the overall size of the phone feels smaller.. I use an Otter Box Defender Series case, as I did with the S4, and it definitely is less bulky than before. I have an armband for the phone. I can put the entire case in the armband with the S6 whereas with the S4 I needed to remove the outer layer of the case. The included fast charger is definitely faster than the S4 charger.

Great phone.Wireless charging is awesome and the phones speed is impressive. Every thing else takes time to get used to. MUSIC GROUPIES: I nearly had panic attack when I realized I was leaving apple perfect music setup. BUT just pay Google play their 10 a month same as apple music. Google music app saves 50000 songs free takes several hours and excellent WiFi just like apples iMatch. THEN buy these apps MUSIC MATE 3.99 and POWER AMP 4.99. Problem solved. Google music app saves all of your music>Music Mate then pulls the media down from the cloud> Power Amp is the best media app on the google market. Music is all that I cared about. But it worked out. Recently left apple because of the general lack of options for what you pay for. The only thing you will miss about apple is apple care. This phone does every thing else. Sans apples many limitations.

Went back to big Red after dealing with Kitty wireless lack of customer service, and these phones work great and Verizon has excellent customer service. Only problem I have noticed is the blue-tooth is poor on my phone, hooks up OK to the GM units in vehicles but blue-tooth headsets sound bad and disconnect even if 3 or 4 feet away. I tried a Dylan new version and Vorager Pro HD and returned them both only to find VXI BT350 and VXI Reveal to work satisfactory. The blue-tooth is the only issue that I have found so far. Battery life is sufficient and we love the wireless charging. Phones do get a bit warm but nothing that I think is worrisome, very little lag time with these.. I upgraded from a S3 and the wife from an S4 and we are both happy with the new S6 from Samsung. Please work on the blue-tooth Samsung because your close to a winner here.

beautiful phone. best hardware i seen, coming from iphone5 and s5. this phone definitely is the best phone i had so far. best camera, however selfie, even with beauty mode dial down to 0, it still has that airbrush filter on. nevertheless this thing rivals my canon dslr. however the software still needs some work.while google maps and other apps that lagged on the s5 worked flawlessly in s6, i still get some random crashes here and there. but the lollipop has been a step in the right direction. maybe just me but gps has some issues. was driving on the jersey freeway to a army base, as i blast down the highway, it still thinks i'm on a local road, so i keep getting random direction voices from google map. this could very well be an isolated incident.

Textual Messages: S6 is alright, I have sprint and the WIFI Calling feature, doesn't work. Phone seems sluggish when browsing websites even with WIFI. I purchased my S6 from Best Buy the are offering free Samsung wireless charging station with every S6 purchase with easy pay or lease. Phone does not charge, super fast, like 2 hour charge in 15 minutes time, thats what I read in a review online, that just is not true for me maybe its the wireless charging station. I am not blown away with this phone, lollipop makes the phone, but even that doesn't wow me. I might return my s6 and just pick up the galaxy edge.

I returned to Android after owning an iphone 4s for a couple of years and I am still getting used to it again. I like the widgets, like being able to see the weather without actually opening the app. This phone has feature upon features (palm swipe for a screenshot? awesome) and the screen is so crystal clear it is quite amazing. I use my phone for just about everything but making calls (although I do that on occasion too). Checking Facebook, texting, streaming music, taking pictures, tracking runs, and so much more. The size has been an adjustment too, I have small hands and it is hard for me to use one-handed when I am trying to reach the outer edges with my thumb white it is in my palm but the pros far outweigh the cons.

Just picked this phone up at best buy, traded my note 4 in because I was tired of such a large phone, I don't regret my decision one bit, this is the perfect size phone for me, fits in my pocket very comfortably! After spending some time with my gs6, here are some thoughts... Battery life is good, not great but it gets me through the day. Love the fast charging! Have yet to have a phone that charged this fast! The build quality is superb! Feels so nice in the hand!!! Camera and finger print unlock are two of my favorite things about this phone! Everything just works so smooth! Amazing device! Don't hesitate to get this phone! I can't keep my eyes off of it since I got it, and you won't be able to either!

I waited 3 month to write this. My biggest concern was the lack of expandable memory. I got the 64gig version and it is more than ample. The speed is great. The only malfunction is the Recents key doesn't work. Seems to try hard at opening my recents but they don't stay open until my 4th or 5th attempt. My only real knock I have is the battery. Horrendous from the start. I'm a fairly heavy user and even with power saving mode on it gets me 8 hours maximum. As an early riser that shuts me down by early afternoon. I love the look and feel along with the prestige of carrying the premium phone but looking forward to my next phone. I'm hearing Blackberry is going Android......

The phone is great when it comes to build quality. It's light and feels premium, but there is no much different from the pervious S series phone, I am still using an Android system with the same Apps I have been using. I had used every phone in the Galaxy S series but this one has the worse battery life, maybe we had a bit less apps to run back in the days, but why won't they upgrade the battery life to a better scale? the battery can only last for about 4 hours then it is done, I had to get battery cases (which I always do for android phones) to keep it alive through out the days. besides the battery, I don't have much complains about this S6

Great phone! I have had it since it came out and have had almost no problems. I have had only one issue and that is that the default keyboard kept going unresponsive on me. I had to download another keyboard from the app store and it fixed the problem. Pros: •Responsive screen display •Fast processor •Appealing design •Clear sound quality •Great size •Feels solid (quality materials) Cons •Battery life could be better (as could all android phones). •Keyboard was better than the S4 but kept going unresponsive. Sprint tech support was not helpful. New keyboard from the app store solved the problem.

Easily the best phone I've had so far - was preceded by an LG Optimus G (mediocre camera, and had a weird problem where the proximity sensor never really worked.. which was a big problem for conference calls where you had to dial the PIN) and an HTC EVO (yes, the original - great phone for its day). Build quality is excellent, camera quality is basically on par with my wife's iPhone 6, phone works well as a phone (that used to be a big problem with Samsung's that I used). I could write a lot of other things that are posted in other positive reviews, but I'll end with this: I'd recommend this phone without reservations to anybody.

1, with all the features of ordinary mobile phones, it is possible for normal calls, texting and other mobile applications. 2, the ability to have wireless access to the Internet, the need to support CDMA 1X or 3G network GPRS or CDMA network under the GSM network under. 3, with PDA features, including PIM (personal information management), calendar notes, task scheduling, multimedia applications, browse the Web. 4, with an open operating system, in this operating system platform, you can install more applications, so that the smart phone features can be unlimited expansion. Haha, very good machine.

Textual Messages: Have had the phone since 4/10 and it is fantastic. Saw a lot of complaints about previous iterations of touchwiz, but this version runs incredibly smooth. Camera takes great pictures and launches really fast. No reboots other than when it loaded features when first booting and activating sim. Under moderate to heavy use I can get a full day. Textual Messages: The Samsung S6 is greatly improved over the S4. It fixes the six or so issues I had with the S4. The only downside is the short battery life. If you have a lifestyle, such as myself, that allows for a 15 minute recharge, you'll be good for the whole day. That said, I'm concerned that if the battery life worsens over time, it will become an increasing pain. Don't forget to lift off the back camera lens film with a piece of Scotch tape. Also, I recommend buying a QI wireless charger. Very handy.

This phone is great! I upgraded from my iPhone 5c and the display on this phone blows apple out of the water. The battery is good, about the same as my iPhone's and all the features are really great. If you are are specifically looking for a phone that is really easy to use then iPhone's are your best bet. While this phone is fairly easy to use it isn't as simple as an iPhone. This however isn't a big deal for me. The best part of this phone is the 2k HD display. Watching full HD videos on this phone is incredible! Love the phone and would highly recommend it.

I have the S6 64GB and I completely love it. First people complain about not being able to increase the memory. I got the 64GB model and have no problem whatsoever - plenty of storage. People complain about the battery. I got the Anker 2nd Gen Astro 6400mAh which fits easily and comfortably into my cargo pants pocket and is completely unnoticeable. With that I could easily charge the phone over 2 times but I've only had to use it once since I've had the phone from the first day it came out. I can't come up with even one negative on this phone.

Great phone so far. Very fast with a great camera. Very easy to use if you are used to an android platform( I came from a droid max, very similar) This is my first Samsung, and so far no regrets. My only concern is battery life. I do not do any social media on my phone. I only use it for talk, text, and a few snapchats. Some days the battery will last for 2 days use while other days it only lasts 1. We live in an area with good reception so it's hard to explain the discrepancies. I would recommend this phone to my friends.

The Samsung S6 is greatly improved over the S4. It fixes the six or so issues I had with the S4. The only downside is the short battery life. Incredible phone. It takes better pictures than my camera. And it's light and I love the redesign. The ONLY con I can think of, it tends to eat up a battery. On my S5 I could go all day and with careful use towards the evening, I could make it to bed time to charge. This is the best phone on the market at this time. I previously had the iPhone 6 64GB Space Gray and I love this way more. Android is just so much better then iOS. This is the fastest phone I have ever had, I take a lot of pictures and the camera is stunning. I've also had the Note 4 and its just to big for daily use. This phone is gorgeous aesthetically, how enough power to zip through pretty much anything X 10 and is compact at the same time.

Textual Messages: For readers, my opinions on this device (ATT 32Gb version) is based off the experiences I had with this device for the passed few hours as today is launch day (April 10, 2015). I will continue to update this review in the future. This review should be the similar to Galaxy S6 on other carriers such as Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile. Pros: - No more plastics and cheap material. Samsung is finally giving us the hardware that we've long desired. By far, the best designed Galaxy phone to date imo - 5.1 in, QHD Super AMOLED screen. The screen is absolutely gorgeous that it hurts my eyes a bit. I'm still adjusting to it. - 16MP Camera with Smart OIS and 5MP front camera. Very well specs, but even better in performance. In short, the best camera on any android phones. I cannot believe that the picture came out so well in low light environment. You have to try it yourself to believe how great these low light pictures come out. - Gorilla Glass 4 panels for front and back (reminds me of the iPhone 4 and Nexus 4). Gorilla Glass are known to be tough and scratch resistance. - Comes in various colors: White, black, gold, green, blue (US only get the white, black, and gold unfortunately) - Comes in 32, 64, or 128GB of built-in memory. (For the 32gb - 3.7gb is for system partition, 25.2 for data/apps/pictures) - Less of the TouchWiz’s gimmicky features like the eye scroll, eye away from the screen pause. So we will not be experiencing the same slowdown or low storage as we did with earlier versions. If the GS4/5 were all about the features, this phone is all about the design. I do like the camera app and how they add a "close all" into the recent screen. - Rapid charging (need to use this more to confirm their claim of 4hrs of battery in 10 minute charge - UPDATED 5/1/15 i am getting about 1 to 1 1/2 hrs of use after the 10 minute charge, I'm guessing the 4hr claim is idle??) - Wireless charging - So if you have extra money that you want to drop for a wireless charging dock, you will be able to use it with this phone. Cons (Not necessarily apply to everyone): - No removable back panel. - No removable battery. I’m a battery hog, so I’m always draining my battery by 3-4pm. Not being able to just swap out my battery will be a pain, but let’s wait to see if the battery swap will be needed in a month when I fully test this device. - Lower battery capacity - 2550mAh compared to the 2600mAh in GS4 and 2800mAh in GS5. With the new processor, battery usage should be more efficient so it should not be a big deal, but end-users would rather the capacity to increase than decrease (Will update if this make through a day of normal usage, UPDATED 5/1/15 - I'm getting average about 8-9 hrs of normal usage, not ideal but I'll manage) - No waterproofing like the GS5, but I never used a smartphone that was waterproofed before, so not a big issue "to me" - No ability to swap out memory card – Might bother some Galaxy fans, but with the higher memory options, I do not think this is a huge problem. - Still no on-screen navigation button – Might only be a problem for "pure" Android fan. - Rear Camera and Flash sticks out a bit and not flush with the back panel. - Front and back glass is a potential problem as we all experiences with iPhone 4 and Nexus 4. Glass will break if you drop your phone at the right angle regardless how much stronger it is, so "case up". - The 1 speaker at the bottom is louder, however when you turn it on max, you will get some distortions in the audio quality. - There are some apps on there that I prefer downloading myself rather than them pushing it on me. There are some Social apps or Microsoft apps included such as OneDrive, facebook, etc. I personally use these apps, but there are people who don't. - I have been experiencing some weird stutters/lags while messing around the phone. This might because I'm loading a bunch of apps into it right now. I will need a few more days to look into this. Overall, this feels like a this is a solid de

Could not be happier. The envy of all my friends - at least those who are not Apple bigots. Picture are amazing! Screen knocks your socks off. Took some getting used to because I've had several generations of Motorola phones. So things are in different places, etc. Really like the ability to set "safe zones" so that when I'm at home or in the truck I don't have to keep unlocking the screen.

I got this phone the day it came out, and have since been very pleased with the software and experience it offers. I am disappointed, however, in the battery life. I would gladly give up some thickness or something to get a bigger and better battery, but I guess it takes a lot to power such a high quality phone. Overall I am enjoying it now that I have it customized to my liking.

I love this phone. It is easy to use and to learn. Wish it didn't come with so much stuff on it that I don't need or want, but otherwise it's great! The battery is ok, considering that I have Facebook and Pintrest which both seem to updating all the time. I imagine that if I took them off the battery would last a good part of the day, depending on what I am doing.

Helpful: 2 of 3 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: Get this SAMSUNG mobile phone yesterday. I ordered it in my local Verzion store, I have to say this is the most beautiful and functional phone I've ever used!!! Powerful processor, much quicker to turn on/off app, I love it! And I guess SAMSUNG may win more market by the powerful S6.

I really liked my Samsung Galaxy S4 but the S6 is better without changing things unnecessarily. I recommend maxing out the memory at 128GB as you can't add more later. I hope the battery holds up since it can't be changed by the user. Voice recognition works much better on the S6 than the S4. The operating system seems much quicker and less buggy as well.
The phones worked well. But the batteries dies quickly and the charger doesn't stay in the slot properly. What can I expect for a little over half priced.

This is without question the best phone I have owned. Smooth, Fast, Screen is unreal. The Touchwiz has been scaled back and the allowable customization of themes is really something that erased the concern of the Touchwiz look. The Camera is better performing that almost any out there. Battery was a concern and can be in the 13-15 hr range for heavy use;however with fast charging (never more than 45 min to full charge in my experience) and built in wireless this has never once caused an issue. Samsung hit a homerun with this phone. GET IT!

I bought this phone for my daughter and she loves it. Good battery life, great screen and camera. There was a deal when I bought it that included a $100 Amazon gift card. It's been a month and I haven't seen the gift card. I knew I should have printed out that page with the whole description. Keeping my fingers crossed that I actually receive it.

Top shelf as usual from Samsung. Great device in every way. Hesitation and deal finding is because of the heafty price tag. Sprint store held me hostage, lease, pricier monthly plan, unwaveable first months insurance... well , I escaped got number ported over 2 days later and I finally I have a s6.

Helpful: 1 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: First let me say I love this phone. I have to admit though, for the first month or so... I wondered what I'd gotten myself into, as I wound up totally obsessed with how much battery life was left, because it went so fast. I purchased an "Anker 2nd Gen Astro E5 16000mAh Portable Charger External Battery Power Bank with PowerIQ Technology 2-Port 3A " to help, so I could at least leave home and not worry quite as much that I'd wind up with a dead phone running errands. Even so, I still continued to find my focus on my dwindling battery life. I am not one of those people who previously had a Samsung Galaxy anything, so it was not due to being disappointed with the non-removable battery like some previous customers have been. I previously had several iPhone versions before making the switch this spring and never had an issue with battery life. I finally solved the problem by setting my phone to the first Power Saving Mode. I'm disappointed it was necessary to do so, and I hope in two years when I may be ready to pick up a new phone again that Samsung will have FIXED this flaw in their phone, so you can use it for at least a day or so before needing to tether it to something. For now, using the Power Saving Mode has made it last a day or so and I'm no longer frantically keeping track of the battery power (in large part because I do have that back up Anker 'brick' I can use if it runs low or out) It does take amazing pictures, the screen clarity is also amazing and I love it. It's slim and light enough that with the Spigen Air Cushion crystal clear case it still fits in my pocket easily. I've read a lot of complaints about the still existent bloatware and that some things that don't come with the phone from Samsun and that you elect to download also can't be gotten rid of once downloaded, which is a detractor as well. I've been afraid to add anything by Samsung for fear I wouldn't be able to delete it, only 'disable' it. I have a 64 g, but had intended to get 128g but none were available in gold, so I settled for the 64. I also have a complaint about these companies like Samsung and Apple who have all this hype over new products coming out and lead you to believe you'll be able to get what they advertise. This is not the case. I waited till the end of April and was told the sapphire case which is what I fell in love with would not be available in the US, though it's available in many other places. And that perhaps it might be available around the HOLIDAYS. Right... so I was supposed to either wait till the end of the year or I guess they think I'll buy another one then. Not likely. Just a very dissatisfied Samsung Sales Tactics customer now. That pretty much felt like a big feck you to me, from the Samsung Corp. So... sure I'd recommend this phone, it's very nice. But, I may not buy another... will have to see how Samsung does in the future. I don't enjoy being made to feel the fool.

Helpful: 1 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I was due for a phone but frankly hadn't found a form factor that I liked as well as my old S3. This phone has a lot going for it. The camera seems to take very good pictures even in mediocre light, the screen is beautiful, and it's the fastest phone I've tested with the processor intensive apps we write. That's the good. The bad unfortunately is outweighing the good however. I had my S3 without a case for three years without a scratch on the screen. Three days after I get the S6 and before my case arrived a small plastic yogurt cup rolled over the screen and scratched it bad as the both sat on my car seat. If I hadn't seen it I wouldn't have believed it was so soft and fragile. My case shows up today but I don't think this screen is going to look good in six months and I'm pretty careful with stuff. Second is the non-replaceable battery. I thought it was idiocy for Apple to put a built in battery in the Iphones and Samsung went and did the same thing. Absolutely braindead because batteries deteriorate so fast in my experience and just so they could shave a mm or two on thickness. Since a human being has to actually hold this thing I don't get it. Bragging rights doesn't make the ergonomics good. Last issue isn't a dealbreaker but a general observation. This fascination with metal on phones representing quality is idiotic. It's heavier, gets hotter or colder to the touch, and just doesn't feel as good. Following Apple stupidly into their design is not a sign of a leader and the Apple fans are always going to have some reason to justify their reasoning. You aren't going to change their minds as they will make something else up. This could have been a great phone but I don't think it will last long at this point.

Helpful: 1 of 2 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: I spent a lot of time going back and forth between the HTC One M9 and the Samsung Galaxy S6 prior to settling on this phone. My previous phone was the HTC One M7, which I absolutely loved. My wife has a Samsung Galaxy S4. Between the M7 and the S4, I thought the clear winner was the M7 due to its superior UI, audio quality, display, look and feel. Two years later, I am surprised to say that the Galaxy S6 is the clear winner. The S6 has improved upon the S4 in nearly every area. A lot of criticism has been heaped on the S6 for abandoning the microSD card, removable battery and water resistant design. While, those are helpful features for many people, personally I don't really have any need for these features and probably wouldn't have taken advantage of them, as my wife has not with her S4. For me, the major draws of the S6 were the new display, the build quality and the camera. The display is, to me, the most significant improvement over the S4. I may be picky, but I really can't stand the over-saturated colors on the S4. In addition to upping the resolution to quad HD on the S6, the display has been improved to reproduce colors vibrantly but accurately, with terrific contrast and okay performance in the sunlight. The camera is similarly close to perfection (for a phone), and finally has convinced me to stop bringing a digital camera with me on vacation. The new aluminum frame that surrounds the S6 may seem like a minor tweak to the S4, but it really makes the phone feel much more high end. The phone has a nice weigh to it now and just feels incredibly solid and looks great. Some of the other features that make the S6 stand out for me are the fingerprint reader, processor, UI and battery life. The fingerprint reader works well, but not perfectly and it is far better than having a password, which I wouldn't have bothered with otherwise. The processor is incredibly capable and does not get that hot even under heavy load. The UI is much better than that of the S4, more intuitive and more streamlined. Although it didn't work well, presumably because I had my phone in airplane mode the whole time, I was pleasantly surprised to come back from vacation to find a chronicle of my trip complete with the pictures I had taken. Battery life is great...almost infinite compared to my aged HTC One. It always lasts me a full day and even if it didn't, the adaptive charging is shockingly fast. Overall, I'm very satisfied with the S6. It is a huge step up from the One M7 or Galaxy S4. I imagine the HTC One M9 would also have kept me happy, just slightly less so. I feel that the HTC One M9 does have some strengths that may make it a better choice for a select audience, but the S6 seems like the winning choice for most users.

Textual Messages: This was the first time I decided to make the big jump into the android world with my wife who was skeptical. I did a lot of research and knew the negatives of this model compared to the last model which was no micro sd card and it's not waterproof. With that in mind I really wanted to give it a shot since it had 32gb of storage which was what most people used for storage when purchasing micro sd cards for previous Galaxy models that took them. Also I wanted out of using iTunes. Well my experience lasted less then a few days before we had it sent back. The man culprit was the horrendous battery life. No matter what you do it lasts less then 8 hours on minimal usage. Good luck if you are a gamer that likes COC or playing a little Candy Crush. Also I had to do 3 ID scans to make it start recognizing my thumbprint without having constant fails when trying to login to the home screen. The only positive experience was the camera. It does take amazing pictures, but the poor battery life was enough to make me and my wife swap it out before our trial date was over.

Helpful: 2 of 4 people found the following review helpful
Textual Messages: This is my first Samsung cell phone. I'm a sucker for specs first, aesthetics second but it has to function well with good reception. This phone packs all of those things. I've stayed away from Samsung mostly because they were unattractive and I have read many reviews that complained of antenna issues, weak reception. The galaxy s6 seems to have good reception so far. The beautiful glass over a brushed sapphire blue metallic backing is beautiful and the glass feels as if there is a coating that helps your finger glide over the screen yet it isn't particularly slippery in hand. I'm not a huge fan of square cameras on phones, purely on aesthetic principle. It also bulges out, protruding maybe 1/8" or 3 mm. Which I disliked at first until I used it. It takes such great photos! This is am excellent camera. Once you throw a case on the phone, which you will be hard pressed to do because of how nice this phone looks, the bulge can be an asset. No chance of a case causing glare that happens with flush mounted lenses in a case. The speaker, charging port and headphone jack are on the bottom bezel. Leaving the top clean and uncluttered. The top has a small black dot which is the ir blaster. The left sports volume buttons. I really prefer this two button set up over a rocker, even if the rocker is sleeker. The two button configuration makes for positive feed back knowing which way the volume will go. The right side has a power key. Simple with good tactile feedback. Along the base, you have a home button, oblong with a polished silver bezel. This houses a fingerprint scanner. This is an option I never saw the use for until I used it. This is the most convenient way to secure your phone ever. I've never used security on my previous phone, even disabling the swipe to unlock feature. It's just an unnecessary hassle. This phone, it's locked but all you need to do is press the home screen. It's fast enough that it's not a hassle at all. To the left is the multi task button, to the right the back button. I like that the keys are on the bezels and not taking up screen space. They light up brightly but they time out quickly and become distracting, I disabled the light. Since they're is no printed icons, it maintains the clean look. The phone is surprisingly light weight but carries enough heft that it doesn't feel cheap. The screen is gorgeous. The definition is really over kill but I'm not complaining. It's crisp, bright and colorful. Battery life has been fine for me but I haven't really put it to the test. Have not spent a full day away from a charger since I bought it. I get the impression it will be similar to my HTC one (m7) which was great for my needs. No external memory is always a bummer. I lived with it for two years with my m7 and found it was a non issue. It is convenient to have but not a necessity. No removable battery, again, lived without this feature on my m7 for two years and it was also a non issue. I used to carry around two spares with my HTC reZound which was a hassle. If this phone can make 12 hours with my typical use, I'll be thrilled, if not, a juice pack will be in my future. Touch wiz. I'm trying to give it a chance but I really don't like it. That's easy to fix with other launchers but I like the functionality of native launcher widgets. I have been on sense and living it for four years. I really like that ui. So it's obviously a personal precedence. The settings are a bit different to navigate too. Not fond of the way touch wiz does the settings but again, that's subjective. This phone also can take your pulse, count your steps and check your blood oxygen levels. Kind of odd but it's still a neat feature. This phone used a quick charge protocol. Very cool, you get a quick charge for like the first 30-40% of battery. In ten or fifteen minutes. From dead, it is supposed to charge in just over an hour. It supports wireless charging as well which is very convenient. Over all, this is a great phone. Not so sure I would
Awesome phone!! Extremely fast, very smooth function, stylish..
Yes it was exactly what I wanted. Came on time and I love it.
simple, intuitive, and great design. leading smart phone!
Excellent: Best phone currently on the market!

Textual Messages: For readers, my opinions on this device (ATT 32Gb version) is based off the experiences I had with this device for the passed few hours as today is launch day (April 10, 2015). I will continue to update this review in the future. This review should be the similar to Galaxy S6 on other carriers such as Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile. Pros: - No more plastics and cheap material. Samsung is finally giving us the hardware that we've long desired. By far, the best designed Galaxy phone to date imo - 5.1 in, QHD Super AMOLED screen. The screen is absolutely gorgeous that it hurts my eyes a bit. I'm still adjusting to it. - 16MP Camera with Smart OIS and 5MP front camera. Very well specs, but even better in performance. In short, the best camera on any android phones. I cannot believe that the picture came out so well in low light environment. You have to try it yourself to believe how great these low light pictures come out. - Gorilla Glass 4 panels for front and back (reminds me of the iPhone 4 and Nexus 4). Gorilla Glass are known to be tough and scratch resistance. - Comes in various colors: White, black, gold, green, blue (US only get the white, black, and gold unfortunately) - Comes in 32, 64, or 128GB of built-in memory. (For the 32gb - 3.7gb is for system partition, 25.2 for data/apps/pictures) - Less of the TouchWiz’s gimmicky features like the eye scroll, eye away from the screen pause. So we will not be experiencing the same slowdown or low storage as we did with earlier versions. If the GS4/5 were all about the features, this phone is all about the design. I do like the camera app and how they add a "close all" into the recent screen. - Rapid charging (need to use this more to confirm their claim of 4hrs of battery in 10 minute charge - UPDATED 5/1/15 i am getting about 1 to 1 1/2 hrs of use after the 10 minute charge, I'm guessing the 4hr claim is idle??) - Wireless charging - So if you have extra money that you want to drop for a wireless charging dock, you will be able to use it with this phone. Cons (Not necessarily apply to everyone): - No removable back panel. - No removable battery. I’m a battery hog, so I’m always draining my battery by 3-4pm. Not being able to just swap out my battery will be a pain, but let’s wait to see if the battery swap will be needed in a month when I fully test this device. - Lower battery capacity - 2550mAh compared to the 2600mAh in GS4 and 2800mAh in GS5. With the new processor, battery usage should be more efficient so it should not be a big deal, but end-users would rather the capacity to increase than decrease (Will update if this make through a day of normal usage, UPDATED 5/1/15 - I'm getting average about 8-9 hrs of normal usage, not ideal but I'll manage) - No waterproofing like the GS5, but I never used a smartphone that was waterproofed before, so not a big issue "to me" - No ability to swap out memory card – Might bother some Galaxy fans, but with the higher memory options, I do not think this is a huge problem. - Still no on-screen navigation button – Might only be a problem for "pure" Android fan. - Rear Camera and Flash sticks out a bit and not flush with the back panel. - Front and back glass is a potential problem as we all experiences with iPhone 4 and Nexus 4. Glass will break if you drop your phone at the right angle regardless how much stronger it is, so "case up". - The 1 speaker at the bottom is louder, however when you turn it on max, you will get some distortions in the audio quality. - There are some apps on there that I prefer downloading myself rather than them pushing it on me. There are some Social apps or Microsoft apps included such as OneDrive, facebook, etc. I personally use these apps, but there are people who don't. - I have been experiencing some weird stutters/lags while messing around the phone. This might because I'm loading a bunch of apps into it right now. I will need a few more days to look into this. Overall, this feels like a this is a solid de
